review_content:
Sour malt pils aroma with subtle bready notes and earthy hop
Pours a clear copper color with small creamy white head
Bready malt with some sweet malt  melanoidins, earthy hop. 
Medium bodied with medium co2, lingering bready dry finish.  
Easy drinking and basic. Nothing interesting stands out.

330ml draft to bottle from lowcostbeer.com.
Pours cloudy light gold, small white head, thin retention.
Aroma of grains, lemon, Taste also has notes of caramel, some raisin.
Nice smooth body, soft carbonation.
One of the more flavoursome Marzen beers I've tried.

I had it from the bottle.  The aroma is slight skunk, grain, and hay.  The taste is grain, caramel, nut, and some skunk.  It slightly creamy with some prickly carbonation.  It's a pretty standard and forgettable beer.  It's not bad.

Not one of the better out of the half dozen-ish new Marzens I tried this season.  Seemed pretty macro and missing both some malt and hop balance.  Thought it would be better based on Optimator and some other German beers I had in this style.  Can cross off my list now.
Keg. Clear pale golden color. Sweet, malty, caramel, very shy hops-like things in aroma/taste.

Slightly lighter in taste than other Oktoberfest beer, but a fantastic easy drinker.

Tasted on perfectdraft keg at home

As classic O-fest as they come. Big head when poured from a 12-oz bottle, beautiful lacing to track your progress, caramel and grass nose, sweet finish with an oh so polite little hop bite. From a bottle best consumed by 06.2021 (OK, so I'm guessing that's what the 06.2021 on the back label means). Could drink it all October.
A very good Octoberfest beer. Perhaps lighter in favor than other Octoberfest. But very well developed. It won our Octoberfest beer tasting. A little pricey but worth it.

Muddy copper color. Malty smell, dank like Heineken. Taste is surprising for the style, reminds me of european macro pilsner with hints of Oktoberfest malts. Not much sweetness or spice. Carbonation fades quickly but mouth is coated. Slight sour, cut grass finish. Would not buy again.
Love this malty sweet beer. Good head, clear  Amber color, low hop flavor. Finishes with a tickle on the palate.

Poured into a pint glass from a bottle. Decent head that lowered; has good lacing, too. Amber in color. Very attractive pour. Nose is surprisingly on a hoppy end, rather than malty. Taste is well balanced with a malt backbone and a spicy hop finish. Light, refreshing, and very approachable. I believe I had it ten years ago. Mostly have had Victory and Paulaner’s fest beers. This was perfect on a Sunday watching NFL games. Cheers!

Für ein Festbier recht hell und klar. Eine süßliche Note fällt auf. Das unterstützt den fruchtigen Grundgeschmack. Florale, getreidige und minimal malzige Nuancen folgen. Eine angenehm bittere, nicht zu dominante, Note liegt über allem. 

Da Spaten eigentlich tot ist und unter der Marke nur noch 2 Vollbiere vertrieben werden, hab ich nicht viel erwartet. Aber das ist ein durchaus schmackhaftes und süffiges Festbier.
12 ounce bottle from Total Wine Lexington. An amber brown like color in pour but light malt and some floral notes in taste.
Pours light mahogany with a two finger, light tan head.  Aroma is caramel, nuts and light roast.  Taste is caramel and light raisin, moving to cashew and roast.  Finish is the same.  Tasty marzen.
Adding in my 300 Beers To Try ticks because I want to see how they impact my stats and some of them I will never see again. Will however re-rate them when practical.
Keg at The Portland International Beer Festival on 19/07/2008.  A very easy drinking Marzen, with delicate floral aroma and caramel and biscuity malt flavours.

Pours a clear copper color with a thick three finger beige head. The aroma is brown bread crust and roasted barley malts. The flavor is The flavor is lightly roasted barley malts, brown bread crust, and cane sugar. The mouthfeel is medium and drink ability is quite high.
Malty bready with some off ethyl aroma. Pours bronze, good ring of head. Soft water, sugary malts, some toasted grain. Apples and grain aftertaste. Not really feeling this, but it's not all bad.
It pours clear amber with an off white head. It is a bit sweet with apple and spice. There are some bread elements but the apple and spice were the balance is.

Best before May 2020. Good thing I looked at the reviews; I didn't realize that I hadn't reviewed it yet!

It pours a lovely clear amber with a very healthy looking head of foam.

Smells of bread, caramel malt, some grassy hop notes. Excellent balance imho.

Bready malt, grassy hops, working in unison. Sip after sip, a true joy to drink. Light sweetness, which is overdone in quite a few domestics of the style. Not too hoppy, again, I've tasted that in some domestics. Simple, tasty, done right.

Smooth, almost creamy mouthfeel.

I haven't seen this very often in Casper.
This was part of a mixed case of the Premier Lager and Optimator Doppelbock. Cost me around $34. What a bargain!

Ein Prosit, ein Prosit 
Der Gemütlichkeit 
Ein Prosit, ein Prosit 
Der Gemütlichkeit. 

OANS! ZWOA! DREI! G'SUFFA! 

Ziggy Zaggy Ziggy Zaggy, Oi Oi Oi!

Bottle from Beer Zoo. Clear golden body with a thin white head. Steady carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of earth and a hint of sour grain. Flavour follows the aroma. Medium body with a watery, slightly oily texture. Soft fizz. Not bad, but not one I’d rush to have again.

Tap @ Slainte, Salamanca, Spain.
Amber colour with a thin white head.
Aroma is malt, straw.
Taste is malt, sweet, hints of toffee.
Medium body, average carbonation.
Botella 500ml Color Ambar,espuma blanca,fina,alta,resistente.Aroma malta,caramelo,frutal.Sabor una combinacion buena entre dulzor y amargor,malta,caramelo,frutal

Tap, Sharkeys Radford. Pours medium amber with light tan head that is not persistent. Aroma clean, caramel very light hopping. Taste is dry, light bitterness, sweet malt, clean finish. Not a lot going on here but clean, well made and drinkable (just ordered a second, if you’re counting). The Germans know how to make drinkable beer. The caramel distinguishes this from their Helles in a good way. I love the fall ... leaves turn color, the air turns crisp, Spaten Oktoberfest shows up, yada yada yada.
$2.25 bottle, GTGSP. Amber brown, clear, off-white head. Green grasses, brown leaf and grasses, cracker, caramel nose. Brown leaf, roasted malt. Dry. Decent.
Fun to find a true German octoberfest but...Lots of malt. Reminds me how much better American beer is than European. They beat us on tradition but their beer has been outdone by American microbrews.
Draft at Zieglerbrau Dachau. Tastes like toffee malt, dried fruits, and corn. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like corn, toffee malt, and dried fruits.
Pours clear dark amber. Falls short of being significantly memorable. Finding this ordinary.
Best when poured from bottle to glass rather than direct from bottle. A bit too sweet for me.
If it was my last meal, I would want this beer to be part of it. If I could only have one item as that meal, this would be it.

12 oz bottle. Smells of roasted malts. Light brown in color with a slight amber tint and clear. Tastes of roast malts, toffee, light caramel. Quite smooth, rich flavor. Light lingering semi sweet finish.
12 oz bottle. Pours an amber with a white head. Scents of malt. Leathery and malty with a mild bite. Average carbonation. A short crisp finish. Super drinkable.
Dorata, limpida, schima fine ed evanescente. Al naso è solo maltato, cereale, lieve mieloso. In bossa si aggiunge anche l 'erbaceo a fine bevuta. Corpo medio, carbonazione bassa.
Bottle, 500 ml at Cajt. Pours clear amber with white head. Caramel, malty, grainy, sweet, some bitterness in finish. Light bodied. Watery. Not my thing.

Pours dark clear amber with a thick head. Aroma of wood and sweet malt. Taste is malty and light, hints of oak on the back of the tongue. The palate has some caramel influences, fewer spices than is expected of the style. Sweet, aged malt dominates this beer.
Amber color, medium creamy head with low retention, sweet aroma, medium body, caramel flavour.
12 oz bottle.  Amber pour with a white head.  Aroma is bready, mildly floral, and with some vanilla, leaves, fig.  Tastes of caramel, light hops, toasted cereal.  A bit dizzy and dry clean finish.

This fall I have been working my way through a number of Oktoberfest beers after laying off for a few years from burnout. This one is the last of the group in the fridge, needs to be opened before it times out. I found Spaten at a local supermarket as a lonely 12 oz bottle. Opening now and pouring into a basic bar glass with a handle I detect a dark orange-amber body, a here and gone, off-white head while I do see a healthy stream of bubbles coming up from the bottom. A light candy and grain scent, nothing out of the ordinary. A drink finally, hey, pretty good. Malt, caramel, bread, less watery than most of the other Marzens. Full body relatively. Nice with a cigar I assure you.

Minimal caramelly roastiness in the aroma with huge note of cardboard which is unacceptable. Clear golden in the glass, frothy head. Taste is semi dry with really nice malty core – very flesh-y and tough. Also some bites of caramel and breadcrust. Very smooth, highly drinkable – tastes better than smells.

I rated this years ago under the German version. Just now realized my mistake and transferred it over. 

On tap at Oktoberfest at Daanen’s Deli Saturday. Pours a clear copper with a light-beige head with excellent retention and decent lace. Aroma is malty caramel, toasted nutty bread, grass and kind of skunky. Has a bittersweet taste with average carbonation and a medium body.
Bottle from 7-11. Dark golden. Malty, bready, soft and smooth, some sweetness. Slightly toasty, grainy.

Pours a rather dark copper color. Darker than most for the style. Very clear. This certainly looks like autumn in a glass. Two fingers bone colored head. Good retention and okay lacing.

Aroma is strange. Smells like euro lager. I mean it is, but haven’t smelled that from a German brewed marzen before. Malty, euro spicy hops. Caramel.

Taste is malty and sweet. Touch of caramel. Slight spicy hops, make an interesting counter to the sweet malts. But still sweet.<>Mouthfeel is light medium bodied. Only a touch of spicy finish, maybe a touch boozy. It’s good.

Overall, I had my doubts; you know green bottle and malt liquor on the label...but it delivers. I would recommend it and I would probably buy it again.

Bottle. Pours caramel color with off-white head that dissipates quickly. Caramel and biscuit malt aroma with some herbal notes. Biscuit malt with caramel followed by spicy hop bitterness. Medium-light body.

Backlog. Bottles and draft over the years. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head that lingers. Toasted malt aromas with bread and pretzel notes as it warms. Smooth and medium bodied. Well balanced with some light toasted toffee and light peppery hops.

A clear dark yellow veer with a little white foam on top. Malty and somewhat spicy nose with honey and aalspice. Sweet, malty flavor with spicy accents and a mild lingering finish. Quite rich mouthfeel with good drinkability and modest carbonation. A rich, warming and well balanced beer that is easy to chug.
Golden amber pour with a medium white head. Nice medium body, refreshing palate.

Color amarillo dorado, cristalino. Tres dedos de espuma con retención media. Aroma y gusto en la misma linea, cereal tostado y lúpulos nobles. Buen equilibrio dulzor/amargor. Una birra correcta, refrescante, pero muy lejos de las grandes Märzen.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a medium, well retained, ivory head with minimal lacing, over a clear dark amber (SRM 12) body......nose is toasted malts with bread and toast tones, slight dried fruit and caramel type sweet notes, minimal hop spice.......taste is dominant toasted malts which are bready and toasty, hints of sweet notes with fruit and caramel tones, dry throughout finishing with mild bitterness, with minimal hops otherwise.....mouth feel, medium light body, no alcohol high carbonation. Clean throughout, meeting the style. It is not a super interesting beer, but is drinkable. BJCP 8/3/15/4/7
From backlog. On draft at Schottenhammel Festhalle, München. Golden with white head. Malts, hops.

Bottle at home with Apollo, Caressa, and the wife. The aroma is dominated by a bit of skunk, not overpowering and actually welcome and interesting, thanks to the green glass. Also has notes of caramel and toasty malts. The flavor is cleaner, sweet malts, toast, bit of hops on the finish. Clean, simple, nice.
Poured from bottle amber with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt bread toffee and light hops. Taste is nice balanced toasted grain caramel balanced hops. Classic.
Bottle. Pours clear amber with a small beige head. Aroma is toasted malt with green apple notes. Taste is toasted malt, green apple, caramel, some metallic notes. Finish is sweet.

Tap. Clear golden color, good white foam. Sweet aroma, malt, light spice of hops. Taste: malt, sweetish, light bitterness, full body, very drinkable = золотое, прозрачное, хорошая белая пена, аромат сладкий, солод, лёгкая пряность хмеля, вкус солодовый и тоже сладковатый, легкая горечь, полнотело, очень питко, но не слишком ярко.
Arômes de céréales et de levures. Robe claire avec un fin col de mousse. Attaque sur des céréales qui restent en bouche. Bière typiquement allemande. Bien bonne.
Wygląd trochę nietypowy złociste piwo z niezłą białą pianą. Aromat i smak słodowy, lekko wytrawny, przyjemny ale bez błysku. Obecnie typowy przedstawiciel monachijskich piw ważonych na oktoberfest
On tap hazy brown with a white head. Aroma of toasty and earthy. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter.
Cerveza comercial, muy normal, según pone en la etiqueta respeta la ley de pureza, pero lleva extracto de lúpulo

12oz bottle pours a clear amber with a large off-white head. Aroma of grassy dry hops over light caramel malt with lager yeast. Taste of mildly sweet toffee and caramel malt, lightly nutty, with mild lager yeast and hops on the finish.

Btl pours a clear light  bronze color with big white head that fades fast leaving specks of lace on glass. Aromas of sweet bread and burnt sugar with floral and perfume notes. Tastes of toffee, toast, roasted grain and spice. Light to medium body, good carbonation, soft mouthfeel and a smooth dry finish.  Clean ,crisp hops pair perfectly with the malty backbone. Nice smooth, easy drinking beer.
On tap.  Amber in color with small tan head.  Malty aroma.  Sweet flavor.  Light bodied.  Straightforward but decent.
Golden with white head. Malty, light caramel and floral. Crisp, sweet and spicy finish. Nice.

I bought this bottle at the Alcampo in Sevilla. I tried it today during the meal in the cerro del aguila, Sevilla. In my point of view, it is a honest beer, pure tradition of Bavaria, 100% classical, making its job. The body is gold and clear, thin and white foam, regular carbonation. The taste is malty, bready, a bit
watery, not a lot of hop, well balanced, simple and drinkable with notes of honey at the final.
1 liter keg. Clear gold color with small white head. Smells barley and hops. Taste are average hops biterness with some barley sweetness and some dried banana. Aftertas are short barley notes

Golden copper with a small white head. The aroma is quite a bit skunky, with some light caramel and toasted notes. The flavor is similar, with some moderate sweetness and some balancing bitterness, pretty skunky though.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear, light amber with an off-white head. The aroma is of sweet malt. The taste is well balanced with some of the dark malt flavor coming through as well as a bit of caramel sweetness in the aftertaste. The hop bitterness is restrained, but there is a noticeable alcohol note as it is approaching 6% ABV and almost a Bock beer. This is an excellent example of the Märzen/Oktoberfest style. It is truly a shame that they no longer serve it at the Munich Oktoberfest where all of the breweries have decided to pour the cheaper Helles Lager style in its place.

500ml bottle. Clear, very pale golden with quickly fading white head. Aroma is very light with white bread, herbal hops, grainy malts and light grass. Taste is herbal hops, white bread, grass, lemon and hay. Medium mouthfeel, light carbonation and herbal aftertaste.
Pours a nice amber. The aroma on this is great, full and decadent. In terms of taste, though, it was only okay. I only bought this as I was told that this is the best Oktoberfest hands down. Meh.

Pours very clear copper, light brown head, pretty. Artoma is cookie dough, almost sour dough, herbal. Taste is sweet, pretzels, hops well integrated, definitely there but few obvious notes. Mouthfeel fairly light. A light sweetish drinkable beer, quite malt forward.

On tap at Mack's Golden Pheasant Restaurant in Elmhurst, IL., and mug served showing a clear, brownish amber color, with a decent layer of off white froth, and ribbons & spots of lacing. The nose was malty, toasted, subtle yeast, a touch of dried fruit, light tartness, and a hint of caramel sweetness. Medium bodied, with average carbonation, the taste was similar, with some creaminess to the mouthfeel, and modest earthiness and slightly roasted character to the bitterness. Clean, sessionable, and very food complementary.
12oz bottle. Clear dark gold with a small white head. Mainly malt aromas and favors, mild hops and caramel sweetness. Lively carbonation, smooth malt finish.

Bottle from Merchants. Not stoked it's green. Aroma is sweet, metallic, earthy hop, wheat, caramel malt, slightly skunked. Appearance is dark amber, almost brown, light tan head. Taste is robust, caramel malt, earthy hops, slight skunk, a deeper flavor and robustness than other Festbier, creamy, good. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light crisp carbonation, slick, caramel malt and slightly skunked earthy hop aftertaste. Overall, it's different from other Oktoberfest I've had, and it doesn't look quite right, but it definitely tastes good.
Bottle from Wegman's. Caramel brown clear, with medium body and mild hops nose. Bitter finish.

Aroma: herbs and malty.
Appearance: straw color and thin white head.
Taste: high herbal bitterness, herbs, malty, dry.
Palate: medium body and high carbonation.
Overall: decent maerzen, high bitterness, this is something new.

Relatively faint aroma of biscuit with hints of spice and fruit. Clear deep amber with a short cream-colored head, thick and bubbly, ending quickly as a thin cap with a ring. Stringy lacing. Lots of visible carbonation. Surprisingly bitter on the initial taste, continuing on through the finish. Taste, apart from the bitterness, is tart and a bit off-putting to me.

12oz bottle to tulip. Pours dark orange brown, soapy tan head. Aroma of corn, caramel, butter, biscuit, dried flowers. Taste of same with slight bittersweet caramel apple finish. I like it. Mouthfeel is spot on for style.

Aroma is toasted bread and caramel mixed with Eurolager skunkiness. Ugly pour, coming out a decent orange-gold but giving up a fizzy, brief head with no lace. Taste is better than the nose, full of rich caramel sweetness, buttered biscuits, and mild apple esters, but the skunky floral bitterness on the back end reeks of bad green-bottled German beer, leaving a vegetal aftertaste that clashes with the sweetness on the front. Good feel, lively but creamy. Still a little too old-school European Oktoberfest for my tastes.

Aroma: toasted bready malts and subtle caramel sweetness. herbal hop aroma notes.
Appearance: medium amber, almost copper with a nice half inch off-white head with good retention. bright clear.
Flavor: bready, caramelly, malt sweetness smoothly balanced by herbal noble hop bitterness. no hop derived flavors.
Palate: body is medium, texture creamy, moderate carbonation and mild to low astringency. the finish is short and moderately dry with lingering mild waves of bitterness.
Overall: very nice. so smooth that adventurous craft drinkers might find it uninteresting. a classic style. dig it.
No idea why this is rated so high. tastes like leinenkugel oktoberfest but worse. thin and watery, mild skunk, very little flavor at all. sessionable tho i guess.

From a new bottle...different label than in the photo above. Pours gold amber with small head and lace. Aroma of malt, grains, slight wet laundry. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of pale malts, grains, grassy hops, hay, light field herbs, minerals. I’ve been drinking this beer since around 1980 and it’s bee consistently respectable as a German Oktoberfest.

Aroma: 6 not too skunky, but a nice grassy aroma of Saaz
Appearance: 4 Nice white creamy head, golden, a bit to the greener side than reddish. Still, nice looking for the style.
Taste: 6 Grassy, malty, biscuits, better than expected.
Palate: 2 Thin, nothing exciting. 
Overall: 12 
Still struggle to understand why this is a special style on its own. Ordinary pale lagers.

Taste: Robust malt, semi sweet, smooth, some floral hop notes. Complex nose with hops and nutty malt sweet nose. Deep Amber/Gold color, clear with a nice foam head and average lace. Medium, almost full body. On tap beats in bottle any day.
Pues aprueba. Color pajizo con espuma ligera qur deaaparece pronto. Está buena pero no le encuentro nada reseñable.
500 mml bottle tasted on the 21/10/2016. Amber colour with a medium white head. Aroma of grains, some caramel and yeast. Taste is grainy and medium sweet. Next one please!
Lots of Carmel thick flavors. Taste is lots of grain. very very sweet. To sweet. thin fading head. Lots of mouthfeel for the abv. Not bad very german as it is very grainy. Meh.
on tap oro limpida buona schiuma naso delicato maltato tendenza dolce un po monocorde
Bottle @ Café Brecht. Clear golden color, full sized white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly sweet initially but a nice hayish and slight bitter finish. I quite like it.

11/10/19 - Bottle from Pig - Light, clear amber. Faint roasty sweet aroma. Slightly yeasty/funky in the taste - sweet, light roast, clean finish. Easy drinking.
10/16/16 - On Tap - Vanguard - Kinnikinnic Ave - Bayview/Milw - Pours brown, frothy tan head. Caramel malt, grassy aroma. Typical Oktoberfest taste profile but, unlike many US Oktoberfests, this has a slight dry finish which cleanses the palate of the sweet tendancy (the US versions tend to be too sweet for me). Light on the palate, drinkable, sessionable. Had just about sworn off Oktoberfests before this one.

12 ounce glass poured to pint glass	
Sight: light amber liquid, big white foam, clear
Smell: not a lot
Taste: very good, low bitterness, crisp
Palate: some tartness
OA: good beer , repeat: no, Look for: no
Drank: 10/1/2016	11:00 PM
Bottle poured into a pint glass. Amber color and a small white head. A clean aroma with just a little malt. Malty taste with a little zing on the back end. Highly carbonated. Good...but not great.
Dark brown pour, mild head. Rich and strong malty nose, nice bitterness that finishes fast and watery.

Draft at Porvoon Paahtimo, Porvoo. Thought I had the wrong beer at first, as I wouldn’t call it amber. More like light gold. Clear with visible carbonation. Grainy malty smell not dissimilar to a macro lager, but it’s fresher. Sweet taste with a suggestion of candied orange peel. Long sweet finish. Yest and vanilla notes in the aftertaste. Not too bad but not the best Oktoberfest beer I’ve had. Just that little bit too cloying.

Deep amber copper pour with a small white head. Aroma is metallic, some sweet malt. Flavor is also metallic with some sweet malt, mild fruits, maybe a hint of sassafras. Mouth feel is medium and silky with decent fizz. Finishes slightly malty but with a huge metallic twang.
Drank from a green bottle. Aroma is skunk and grain. Flavor is grain, caramel, earth, and skunk. Has a light body, well-carbonated. Okay.
14-09-16 // 500ml bottle from Stumpf Getränkeland. Clear golden colour, white head. Grainy-malty, sweet. Slight alcoholic notes in the finish. Average Märzen.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep amber with a small white head. Aroma is caramel malt and very light fruit. Taste is light malt up front with a mild hop finish. Low bitterness. Light body. Lively carbonation. Mouthfeel is a little bubbly but otherwise pretty average for a marzen.

It poured a burnt bronze body with some carbonation and a small head, no lace left on the glass. Aroma of sweet malts, flavor of tart malts almost like vinegar. Mouthfeel was adequate. Overall there are too many other oktoberfest beers out there that warrant my attention and money. Originally rated on 10/10/08

24 pack from Costco, bought on 01-Sep. 
Malty sweet, almost caramelly aromas with no hop aroma. Color is spot on and brilliant but the carbonation is too low for style. Taste is malty-caramelly, too much for my taste; hop bitterness is low as is the flavor. Finish is medium sweet.
Not my favorite style.
From 12 oz bottle. Served in clear plastic party cup. Amber color. Thin white head. Little lacing. Malty but balanced. Medium bodied. Average carbonation. Overall good Oktoberfest.

Tap at MacGregors. Deep amber, clear, medium head. Malty nose, light caramel, just a bit of hop, grassy and a touch of citrus. Sweet, rich malt, less caramel than the color would suggest, but enough. Rather straightforward. Low hop, but rich and tasty.

Rating #1960 2015.09.26 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 3, Beer 61 Draught at TapHouse Grill Seattle. Clear amber/toffee coloured pour with a bubbly white head. Aroma has a hint of malty sweetness, and a strong citrus/floral hoppy aroma. Medium carbonation. Bubbly, dry mouthfeel, medium-bodied. Light bitterness in the finish, quite smooth. Nice oktoberfest
How : tap Appearance : clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma : mild tones of stone fruits, citrus and grass. Palate : light body, lively carbonation.

On tap. Clear amber in color with a creamy head that lingers. Flavor is robust roasted caramel malt with a lightly herbal bitter finish. Floral notes in the aroma. An interesting and well balanced Märzen.

Aroma: floral hops and malt
Taste: pine, grass, sweet malt.
Bitter aftertaste
Aroma is some sweet malt. Taste is rich malts with a nice balance of bitterness. Overall a solid fall beer.
Für mich recht Standart. Nicht schlecht nicht herausragend alles sehr glatt gezogen. Etwas grasig ein wenig Getreide. Im Geschmack auch recht frisch hopfig. Abgang ist kurz und mildwürzig.

BBD 5/16. Pours a clear amber that is rather brown. Outstanding head volume and retention, normal lacing.

Light, but typical, Oktoberfest nose. Light biscuit, a touch of caramel and light grassy hops.

Heavy light body that has a smooth texture with a few creamy aspects. Superb carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a reasonable prickly finish.

The flavor profile is outstanding. It begins with light biscuit that flows into caramel that hints at sweetness. As the middle approaches, a light nuttiness is noted. The middle brings a subtle hop flavor and bitterness, mostly herbal. The finish is somewhat crisp and has a very slight mineral quality as the hop, caramel and nutty grains slowly fade.

On tap at Two Brothers Tavern, this was poured into a pint glass.
The appearance was a slight transparent amber to orange color with a bar pour’s kind of slim white head. Extremely minimal lacing, barely there.
The smell starts off with some roasty nuts, sweet glossy caramel tones and delicate toffee all blend nicely.
The taste was mainly sweet with a sticky sweet caramel aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a stickiness leaning to cloying, but gently allows some carbonation to ride into the balance of it all.
Overall, not a bad Oktoberfest, probably could have again.

Golden color with a white head with medium duration. Aroma hasnotes of noble hops, herbal hints and cookie hints. Flavor is slightly sweet at the beginning with good maltiness and mild bitterness in the final. Enjoyable.

Bottle pour at Palo Alto Networks in Santa Clara, CA. Nose is malts, honey, brown sugar. Taste is creamy / malty with a nice balanced hop on the finish. A little too sweet malts for me but also Your Standard Operation German Beer.

Malty clean aroma with mild hints of skunk from being in a green bottle. Has additional almost floral fairly pasture based pleasant aromas, cooking sugar aroma. Clear, copper/bronze color, light head, no lacing. Toasty, grainy, munich/pilsner type flavors, sweetish yet balanced. Unctuous palate, perfection. Goes down easy and dry begging for another sip. Truly a good brew but the green bottle costs a good bit in quality. It is super simple and straightforward which isn’t a put-down. Wonderful brew.
Amber colored, skunky, sweet lager that is seriously easy to drink.  A brown bottle would help this beer along with not letting inBev control the brewing.  Overall though, pretty good.
Caña en Cimmeria 17..10..2015 Color rubio con espuma blanca. Sabores a cereales ligeramente afrutados. Fácil de beber cuerpo suave algo espumoso. Bien. Refrescante.
Výčap Zlý časy. Zlatá farba, biela pena. Vôňa sladová, kvasnicová. V chuti na začiatku sladovosť, sladkosť, jemne ovocné tóny. Sladko - horká dochuť. Vyššia nasýtenosť.
12 oz. bottle. Pour is dark amber. Not much head. Aroma was toasted and nutty. Taste was lightly sweet.

Malty start. On tap. Nice mouthful with a bitter blooming. Very drinkable and good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep amber copper with no head; aroma is sweet malt; flava is sweet malt subtle sassafrass notes; feel medium + silky with decent fizz; finishes malty grassy

11.2 fl oz green bottle purchased as a single at Cork and Barrel 23rd Street in Lawrence, Kansas. 05.2016 on label. The pour is a clear copper brown with a 1 inch foamy off white head that lasts nicely. The aroma is skunk initially, then opens to a faint caramel malt. The taste is caramel malt, along with a bit of a nut flavor and then moves towards grass in the back. The palate is medium to light bodied with soft carbonation, finish is grass along with a bit of the skunk that reappears in the aftertaste.

Good aromas of sweet malt and yeast. Medium yellow/copper with a white head. Good Marzen taste and mouthfeel, but there’s a "light lager" quality to it that takes away from it a bit. Good hop bitterness that balances the malt well. A bit watery towards the end. I think this may be slightly skunked since it’s in a green bottle. Hope to try it fresh some day at the real Oktoberfest! Prost!
Caramel aromas, raisiny. Mostly clear, bronze, burnished gold highlights, a mostly fading white head. Pretty sweet, a little fruity, some toast. Light-medium bodied, a little sticky.

Bottle. Pours a medium brown color with white head. Malty, bready, slight nutty, slight skunked aromas. Bread, skunky, malty flavors. It has some skunked from the green bottle, but overall a very enjoyable beer.

Malty, slightly sweet aroma. Amazing appearance, almost burnt orange. Taste like what a marzen is supposed to take like, malty, great body. Smooth, clean, slightly dry. Makes you crave a nice warm pretzel, mustard, brat, and sauerkraut.
Flat with a very copper looking hue. Sweet and pretty dull. Maybe I do not yet get the style.

Crystal clear amber/brown beer with a head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is bready and toasty. Taste has dark toasty malt richness followed up by a surprisingly strong hop character. Finishes quite dry. Drinks a lot dryer and lighter than other Oktoberfest’s I’ve had, but that helps make it more drinkable.

Whenever you hear about authentic German Oktoberfests, it’s rare Spaten’s brew isn’t mentioned in the conversation. No doubt about it. This is the real deal. Burnt amber color, big head, moderate carbonation. Mild toasted malt flavors, lots of sweet caramel, and just enough hops to provide a clean finish. Not Germany’s oldest Oktoberfest and not the world’s best perhaps, but this is a solid example of exactly what the style should be like. Refreshing, easy to drink, and perfect with salty, smoky meat.

On tap at Prost! Pours out a dark cola brown with off white fluffy head. Sweet, nutty malts dominate aroma and taste. Sweetness, but a biting bitter finish. Slightly different than the norm, but pretty solid.

January 2nd, 2013 - Beers like the Oktoberfest Ur-Märzen make me want to brush up on my beer studies and BJCP progress, on account of having no clue what makes a Marzen Ur, or how that’s distinguished from an Un-Ur-Marzen. Or a Non-Ur? Whatever the difference, this does remind of all the malty, caramel goodness of an Oktoberfest, and the festival itself. Lots of nuts in the aroma, including honeyed peanuts, some burnt honey or burnt toffee, and a little sweetness that reminds me of Sprite - curious. Carbonation assaults the tongue at the tip of the sip, which suddenly wives way to honey and that strange Sprite flavor again. The body is thin, and given the flavors, this might go well with greasy or acidic foods, but by itself it’s a little thin, and clear, and sessionable too. And that might be the point, given the timing of this brew’s annual and celebratory release.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a deep amber orange color with a small beige head. Toasted malt aroma with notes of caramel and grain. Smooth caramel malt flavor with hints of bread and floral hops. Nicely balanced. A nice Marzen with decent character.

Supposed to be one the best Octoberfests available. Meh. Medium Brown with a hint of copper color. Highly carbonated. Does taste of roasted malt, but the overall effect is a bit thin and watery for my taste. Not bad at all but I was disappointed for the $9+ for a sixer (and 11.2 oz a bottle at that). Pours a clear amber. Lots of malt and caramel on the nose. Slight foamy head that persists. Slight bitterness with a semi sweet finish. Nice.

Pours deep copper almost brown but stays toward orange. Glows like red fire with an impeccable clarity. Head is thick and rich. Tan foam that falls slowly and leaves a thick cap and ring with handsome lace. The bubbles streaming up from the bottom look they they know where they are going . 



Nose is lager yeast with a touch of mineral. A nice light hop citrus scent and an earthy malt. The malt is lightly sweet, caramel with good bread backing , toffee undertones and nutty qualities. Hops are floral and bring a light citrus. 



Taste is stupendous. Complex malt character unfolds. First it’s smooth clean and rich. it’s soft yet firm and yields up toasted grains with a natural sweetness. Nutty qualities and rich layered sugars with a light caramel. It has a bit of soft spice character and a nice dry finish. The aftertaste is light and crisp and has the nice touch of lemon zest. Herbal hops and toasted grains come together so sweetly and the medium carbonation tickles them both on the palate. As it warms the grains really flourish with their toasted qualities but the sweetness remains light and the hops are perfectly balanced and grassy and full rather than bitter. The malt in this beer is so clean. It shines. it glows in the color and it exceeds in it’s taste character. It has a an elegance that is understood rather than understated. The hops and spice remain soft while the lager yeast dances light and a touch earthy on the tongue to contrast all that malty flavor without any hop oil or pine resin. 



This is a great oktoberfest that has all the right proportions. A beer that makes you want to drink more. It’s flavorful and kind. It is resilient and the aftertaste lingers dry with a light sweetness that is earthy like all the good and savory food to come on the fall table. It has the color of autumn fire, it has the presence of a crisp fall wind and the wet scent of yeast and bread. This is home and hearth, a fire and the warm glow of toasts.

16 oz. draft. Pour is medium amber, short lived head. Smell is bready, earthy, caramel and brown sugar. Taste is similar, clean finish, good malt flavors and balance, light on the hops. A great example of what the style should be.

Aroma: hop spice in the aroma and some bread but overall a mild aroma with a slight skunk

Mouthfeel: between light and medium bodied, watery, slightly chewy, with a mostly dry finish

Flavor: some caramel flavor but the hops dominate through the taste

Overall: good but not great. I am a little disappointed as I normally love the Marzen style and I hoped that this authentic brew from Munich would be the best I ever had. Perhaps my expectations were too high. Caveats: this was a green bottle with no bottling date. I would love to be able to try this beer fresh in Germany and then render another review. I just felt the beer lacked what I normally enjoy in this style (a malty, caramel dominance), instead the hops seemed to dominate.

S - Musty bready malt. Caramel malt, muted cherries, sweet husky grain, and almond notes.

T - Kind of an old wet grain, dark fruit, sweet malt, and amaretto. A weird thin caramel malt rides heavy and holds steady throughout the finish. Moderate carbonation adds a welcomed bite to balance out the malt. Hints of lemon towards the finish as well as the aftertaste.

The green bottle obviously adds a lot of the characteristics of this beer. The nutty malt is good but a little strange. Slight lemongrass notes come out on the finish. Not what I expected. Not what I expect out of the style. I wouldn’t seek this one out.

10-15-2010

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 7/4/2012.  Pours lightly cloudy orange copper color with a nice 2 finger dense white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation.  Aromas of caramel, pear, apple, biscuit, toast, floral, light pepper, and herbal earthiness.  Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of malt and fruity notes.  Taste of caramel, pear, apple, biscuit, toast, floral, light pepper, and herbal earthiness.  Lingering notes of caramel, light fruits, biscuit, toast, floral, light pepper, and herbal earthiness on the finish for a short bit.  Very nice balance of malt and fruity ester flavors; with good complexity and robustness of all flavors; and zero cloying sweetness present on the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a fairly creamy and very smooth mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice Oktoberfest style.  Very well balanced between malt and fruity flavors; and extremely smooth to drink.  A very enjoyable offering.

It’s very much on the lighter end of the spectrum of Oktoberfests that I, personally, am used to. It smells of a strong, heavy lager and tastes of a slightly chewy lager, with soft, muddy malt notes and a clean, enjoyable lager finish. The maltiness balances out the lager characteristics very well and makes for an easy to drink Oktoberfest that’s light and low on residual sugars and caramel malts. It finishes with a quality much like candied peat, spicing up an otherwise light-palated beer.

This was the marzen version export not what you will get at Octoberfest. Spartan has, in my opinion, best pils Octoberfest beer at Octoberfest. This spatan was decent but disappointed me because I lived in Germany and the Octoberfest pils was a catch even In Germany.

Reviewed 8/26. Oktoberfests in August? Tis the season, I suppose. 12 oz bottle poured into a stein.

A: Pours a crystal clear copper color. The head is a two finger barely offwhite head with decent retention (settling down to a finger).

S: Light toasted and caramel malts, along with a touch of toffee and noble hops. Not the strongest aroma, but thank Jebus it’s not skunked! My hopes are now moderately high for this one.

T: Truth be told, there’s not a whole lot to this as expected - a light sweetness, some toasted and caramel malt, and that’s just about it. The ever-so-subtle finishing hops give this an extremely crisp bite to it. Nothing complex, but it does what it sets out to do well, and that’s to be drunk by the pitcher. Only a hint of metallic-ness on the finish detracts from the experience. 

M: Light, crisp, and refreshing. The drinkability factor is excellent, and it’s not overcarbonated.

O: Honestly, while it’s damn solid at its job, I’d say look elsewhere for a marzen, simply because there’s too much of a chance you’ll get skunked bottles. If you can get it in a manner that doesn’t allow this to happen (read: on tap), then by all means, go for it.

Serving type: bottle
This is a very good Oktoberfest Beer.  They must be doing something right since 1397

I’m getting to the point where I’m starting to feel bad that I don’t like authentic German Oktoberfestbiers. Most likely this is due to the fact that by the time they arrive here they’re skunky, but also due to the fact they’re just not exciting beers. I really wanted to like Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Märzen, but I couldn’t find any genuine redeeming qualities in it. Not that it’s bad (I’ve had worse), it just has an overt lack of goodness.



I poured a 12oz green bottle into my OktoBEERfest mug.



Appearance: By far the darkest Oktoberfest I’ve ever seen. Dark amber/brown color; crystal clear; not much visible carbonation. Initially forms a large, beige, soapy head, but it quickly fizzles away leaving next to no lacing on the glass.



Smell: Since this is a green bottle it’s no surprise it emits a skunky smell as soon as the cap is removed. It’s not as bad as some others but it’s noticeable. There isn’t much else to it, though, just a generic dark lager aroma with a trace of sweet grain.



Taste: Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Märzen doesn’t do anything none of the other German Oktoberfestbiers don’t do. It’s mild, it’s straightforward, it’s only slightly sweet and slightly bitter. The palate is at least noticeably clean here. This is impressive considering how pungent the nose is. Still, I need more than a lack of overt flaws to truly compliment it. 



As for the actual taste, again, there’s not much to say. A clean, mild, familiar dark lager flavor pitches the palate. There’s a quick burst of typical German hop spice in the middle, but if you blink you’ll miss it. The finish is essentially the same as the beginning but with just a tad more sweetness. A hint of toffee I suppose, but nothing as robust as many American Octoberfest beers with toasty malts or nutty flavors. 



Drinkability: A thin, calm, wet mouthfeel with a clean aftertaste makes Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Märzen rather refreshing while it’s in the mouth. I’m actually quite surprised it’s 5.9% ABV as it does not seem to have the weight or body of a beer that big. Not that it’s a challenge to drink, but I don’t see much reason to throw back another.
Malty sweet aroma. Amber with white head. Light bodied and a little skunky. Not bad but I wouldn't go so far as to call it good.

Not the best offering from the Spaten brewery in general.

Review from notes at World of Beer - Fort Myers on 11/17/11.

Poured on draft into a shaker pint glass. 

Appearance: Pours a clear light gold with a 1/2 finger foamy snow white head. Decent lacing.

Smell: Light German malt with a touch of earthy hops.

Taste: Sweet German malt up front followed by a touch of bitter grassy hops in the middle before ending with a light finish. Aftertaste is sweet malt.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: High drinkability. You could easily have a few of these over the course of an evening.

Overall: Pretty good Oktoberfest beer overall. Nothing great, but you could do much worse.
Clear amber color with small white head. Malty flavor. A different Oktoberfest beer.

A: Rich, coppery amber body. Large eggshell white cap. Spotty lacing is left after the huge head crashed and burned quickly.

S: Spicy and grassy hops ride atop a backdrop of soft and sweet caramel malts.

T: A mellow caramel base comes through from start to finish as the grassy hop bitterness pokes in here and there. Slightly bready.

M: Medium bodied. Noticeable carbonation. Somewhat rounded finish.

O: Fairly good. The mouthfeel is a bit thicker than the flavor matches up with. A decent classic festbier.

One complaint is that in the picture on ratebeer it came in a brown bottle, I live in Tennessee and it was only available in green bottles so mine had a bit of skunkiness that I feel effected my overall rating for this beer.  Might be much better off draft or in darker bottles
Bottle, amber with a minimal head.  Flavor is sub-par with lightly toasted malts providing a light body.  A dry bitter finish.
Tap. Crystal clear amber pour with a very slight white head. Aroma is caramel with slight bread. Fairly light palate. Taste is also caramel and bready malts.
Bottle. Pours amber, with a white head. Aroma is malt and caramel. Flavor is malt, caramel, and hops. Medium body.
Amber with a fizzy white head.  Malty, sweet, fruity aroma.  Flavor is much the same with lightly toasted malts.  Medium, carved body.  A bit dry on the finish.  Decent.

Not a bad ocktoberfest. Definitely one of the maltier ones out there. Aroma is malt dominated. Pours a dark amber, bordering on brown. Dissipating off white foam head. This beer begins with malt sweetness and moves onto some earthy hops. Solid body typical of the style. Not too shabby.

12oz green bottle 9/27/11 (Binny’s Plainfield)-48° in Lager Glass-Pours a light to medium brown body with a small white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and sweetness. Taste of the same with a bit of hops. This light to medium bodied brew is not too shabby. Well balanced and goes down easy.

Poured a slightly dark honey color with a medium-sized white head.  Aroma is a bit skunky with rice and biscuit.  Taste also has a good amount of biscuit with lots of grains and bread in the finish.  Very crisp and flavorful.  Aftertaste is quite good too.  Overall a great Oktoberfest.

Of the Oktoberfest beers that I’ve sampled thus far, this Spaten is definitely right at the top of my favorites list!!! When I make it over to Germany, Munich and this brewery are definitely on my list of attractions to visit!!!  When poured this beer sports a hearty head that stays well with the beer all the way through.   Its deep ‘caramely’ brown body (much like a hearty cream soda from those old-fashioned soda fountains!) and caramel scent were just almost too much to bear while taking pics of the brew!  There’s a very well-balanced combination of caramel, hops and malt with this fine brew that sits well and proves to be a very easy drinkable beer.

500ml bottle.
Pours a crystal clear pale straw, with a white head.
The aroma is clearly malt focused, citrus, faintly buttery, lightly hoppy, honey.
Dry, medium body, low to medium bitterness, balanced CO2.
Malty, slightly buttery taste, faintly hoppy, a touch of grain, citrus, and an extremely light cardboard note.
Alcohol shines through slightly towards the end. Classic, but not mindblowing... (2011-09-25)

12 oz bottle. Poured a copper color with a small white head. Aroma was malty, with a touch of grass and hops. Flavor was malty, rich, sweetness, grassy hops. Rather bitter.
Is this all they can do after all of that time?

Aroma is sweet malty, caramel honey. Appearance is brown with small tan head. Crystal clear. Tasts is malt forward. Just enough tangy noble hops to keep things perfectly balanced. Honey and caramel, rich maltiness, some minerally-ness from the water. Palate is medium light, crisp and refreshing. Overall a great beer. A definition of the style. Extra malt complexity/slight skunk which I am convinced comes from the green bottles... it works though.

One of my first Oktoberfest beers, pretty malty, a bit spicy and only moderate hops with very little of the sweetness I see others have spoke of.  Overall full mouth feel from the extra maltiness and pretty darn gut.

On tap at Flying Saucer- Cordova.  Consumed in a session of half a dozen Oktoberfests, this stood out as my favorite. The amber pour, full nose, round maltiness cut with rich, satisfying hops epitomizes a good Oktoberfest to me.
Pours a light amber color with a medium white head. Spicy flavor with a lot of citrus notes. A good beer that I’m glad that I finally got to try.

Pretty darn good beer. Caramel and with varied and fresh hop aromas: forest and flowers in the nose, a little herby. Rich aroma. Flavor is moderately sweet, verging on quite sweet. Smooth and not too spritzy, but not dull either. Caramel flavor elements, some wood and astringency and almost no bitterness. Drinkable. An exceptional value, also.
Pours dark amber with a thin head. Nice balance of malt and hops. Not bad at home but even better in a biergarten.

On tap.
Reddish golden pour with a slight head.  Lots of malt in the aroma - bread and caramel with some spice and grassy hops.  Slightly sweet with more malt and spice.  I usually only drink this once a year at Addison Oktoberfest.

A very well made and hearty brew. Nice deep amber colour with a highly malty and slight pine aroma. There was a thin white head that faded quickly. Taste was a malt and a touch of citrus, will drink again!!.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. Color is hazelnut clear brown with thick bubbly white head. Lots of carbonation bubbles.  Aroma is strong sweet malt.  Mouthfeel is light but silky. Taste is sweet malt with a slight hop dryness in the finish. The carbonation isn’t as apparent on the tongue like it is in the glass, which is nice. It’s an easy drinker. Not the “best beer” like the passer by in the grocery store had commented.. but not a bad purchase for $8.99 I paid for a 6 pack.
Tastes like the regular Spaten, but with the skunk lopped off the back end.

On tap in half liter mugs at a German Restaurant that I tried for the first time today. Deep golden amber with a huge fluffy white head that survived for most of the night. Smells of malt in spades. Bready caramel and burnt sugar mixed with just enough earthy floral hops to keep it from being sweet. Tastes is rich and malty. Melanoids mixed with bread and grain with a spicy floral hop bite that keeps everything in check. Medium body and carbonation level, rich sweet malt y mouthfeel. Light and easy to drink these went down quite quickly and paired well with my meal.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into mug-like glass.

Appearance: Clear biscuit color (as proper) with light white head and marginal lacing.

Aroma: Biscuit, caramel, cherry and metallic/spicy hops.

Taste: While there is the expected biscuit and caramel malt backbone, a strong cherry presence rears its head and creates a very medicinal aftertaste. Light spicy hops on the finish as well.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, medium body, semi-dry finish that is a little off.

Overall: While it at least does not have the too sweet caramel backbone that many US examples do, the strong medicinal presence is just as bad. Not a particularly good Marzen. Still, it gets the job done and is better if paired with hearty food.

This is another beer from Tom Leonards.  This Marzen poured perfectly: frothy head with a clear reddish amber color.  Amber is my favorite color for beer.  Your expectations are so much higher for an amber beverage.  This one does not disappoint.    What a beautiful beer before drinking.  The roasted malts are the first impact on your nose and the flavors of carmel and bread are next.  This smooth Marzen is a good beer for any meal.  It is only missing some spices like some American Octoberfest beers.
orange-amber pour w/med white head.  aroma was grain with slight fruit.  taste was similiar with odd slight hop toward end - didn’t add to flavor.  ok beer but not greatest for style...
From the tap poured a brown color with a fair amount of head.  Spicy malty flavor with a quick finish.
Light and crisp. A certain amount of maltiness that is balanced with a nice, slightly bitter hoppy finish.

Clear brown liquid, thin off-white head. Aroma is nutty and grainy with a hint of cardboard. Bitter, roasted flavors just barely prevail over caramel sweetness. Nice balance. Long finish. The texture of this brew is thick and satisfying. It’s still August and this beer has infused me with the autumn festival spirit. Bring in the harvest!
12 oz bottle from Total Wine.  Pours amber-copper in colour, with moderate frothy white head.  Lots of lacing.  Nice sweet vienna malt, and noble hops. Good example of the style!

Bottle @ home. I really get a kick out of my older brother’s three favorite beers: Bud Light, Easy Street Wheat, and Spaten Oktoberfest Marzen! Seems a little perplexing to me, though I don’t mean to take away from this beer. Clear, golden brown appearance with an off white head. Toasty, lightly nutty, brown malty lager, grassy, noble hoppy nose. Pretty clean, grassy hoppy, lightly nutty, light caramel malty lager flavor. Not as much flavor as some of the other German Marzen/Oktoberfest beers. Not one of my favorite Oktoberfest/Marzen beers but it is in my bro’s top three of all-time!

Pours a nice dark amber with a thin ephemeral layer of head. The aroma is nice and sweet with a slight tinge of alcohol especially as the beer warms up. The taste follows the aroma very closely with more of the sweet malty flavor and a slight nutty backbone. Good beer with a great flavor balance.
Bottles poured into 1L stein. Amber with nice half inch white head. Aroma is caramel. Flavor is caramel. Smooth and delicious.

Spaten Oktoberfest has a thick, creamy, beige head and a clear, copper appearance with some bubbles streaming up and just a little bit of lacing left behind. The aroma is faint, but one can detect some water and mild bread. Taste is of roasted barley malt, light hops across the sip, and some sweetness. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Spaten Oktoberfest finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, and on the dry side. Overall, this is a simple, yet enjoyable beer.

RJT

A: The beer pours a light copper/dark amber color with a finger of off-white head.

S: There is a touch of skunk on the nose, but I only get it at first.  Otherwise, good sweet bread, caramel, and toffee aromas.  Nice toasted malts along with some floral hops and a touch of spice.

T: A smooth sweetness to the beer which is not overwhelming.  Spiced bread, toffee, and caramel are all present along with some floral and spicy noble hops to balance the beer out.  Very minimal bitterness, perhaps just a touch on the finish.

M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation.

O: It’s not my favorite Oktoberfest, but it’s not bad, and it’s readily available, so not a terrible choice.

Really really like this beer.  Tastes great and I can drink a ton of it!  There’s not much aroma at all, but it’s not bad.  Great light roasted flavor and a little hops, super easy to drink and finish is super refereshing.  If you want to know what octoberfest is supposed to taste like, this is it!

Caramel notes on this medium bodied beer were nice.  It was a pleasant beer to drink but nothing spectacular.  I believe this is due to it’s import status or the fact that I drank an Octoberfest beer in March.  Very sessionable too.
hay, floral, golden, clear, amber, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium body, thin feel, fizzy, long finish,
Nice aroma.  Malty, grainy.  The flavor is great.  Especially after the last beer I just had.  Lots of flavor.  Malts, bread, very clean.  Great beer.
Pours clear red with white head, aroma has notes of caramel, some pine, touch of earth.  Taste is nice mix of caramel, earth, some pine, and a slightly dry finish.  Pretty good.
Bottle. Taste was that of toasted wheat with slight hints of caramel. Aroma was balanced malt with a little hops. Nice amber color and nice head and slight lace.
Tap at a knicks game, best I could find. A bit skunked, probably because its old. Mal.t, caramel, bready, not bad

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, some caramel, & spice; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel, some hops, and spice; Nicely balanced; Overall, one of the better Oktoberfest brews.
12 oz bottle. Poured a copper color with a small white head. Aroma was malty, with a touch of grass and hops. Flavor was malty, rich, sweetness, grassy hops round out the beverage.

16oz Bottle. Pours a deep amber, nearly copper color, minimal frothy white head. Grassy notes with slight hop aroma. Tangy but slightly sweet taste of ripened fruits and some yeast notes. Smooth finish with slight hop aftertaste.
Similiar to Becks but amplified in every way.  A very bready beer, much more so when its not ice cold.
Bottle: Poured a golden yellow with a huge white head. Aroma is metal. Taste is bitter metallic with a sour corn finish.
Golden pour from bottle with a decent white head.  Aroma is grain and caramel.  Taste is bland with malt, grains, and a bit of sweetness.
Poured a clear golden/amber with a smallish head.. It has that "German" hop taste and a hint of sweet malt, but overall it not much there. Not what I remember from Oktoberfest, disappointing.

Deep gold to light chestnut color, little-to-no cream head.  Aroma is grassy with slight grain and malt sweetness.  Flavor strikes a nice balance between malt toffee and grassy bitterness.  Very appetizing, biting carbonation.

Not impressed by the appearance. To be honest, the only reason I’m drinking this now is because it has been sitting in my fridge for a few months, and I wanted to finish it before starting on my other winter beers. N
On tap Fox and Hound. Pours dark golden with white head. Aromas of caramel and bready malts. Flavor of bready malts, grain, and caramel. Solid marzen.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a brownish gold with a small white head. It has a pleasant malty aroma. This is a nicely complex malty beer. It tastes of caramel, bread and honey.  It’s very refreshing, slightly warming and very easy to drink. I enjoyed this beer and will try drink it again in the future.

Bottle.  I buy a case of this every fall as it’s one of my favorite oktoberfest-style beers. Pours a medium brown with average white head. Nose is earthy and bread malt with a hint of hoppiness. Taste is same, biscuity sweet malt giving way to old school, medium hoppy bitterness with a dry finish.

Pours a fairly dark brown, more resonant of a brown ale than an oktoberfest. The smell is quite strange--it reminds me more of a strong czech pilsner than a marzen. The taste returns to the world of German marzens, with a deep roasty malt character balanced somewhat by dry European hops. The mouthfeel is rather light with moderate carbonation, and the drinkability is pretty good, especially on this relatively-cool Virginia evening.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-20-2009

Pours a dark, clear coppery brown with a fairly thick, off-white, fine-bubbled head. Rich, malty, fruity aroma has a hint of caramel. Mouth-filling malty flavor has an undertone of apple and pear and a hint of hops. Smooth, strongly fizzy texture leaves a tingly and fruity finish.

Light amber, copper color.  Clear.  Fluffy, 2 finger, slightly off white head.  A few bubbles coming up from the bottom.  The head didn’t have a tremendous amount of lacing or retention.  The nose had an "earthy" grain mixed with some breadiness.  Clean fragrance.  Dry malt was subtle and hid more in the background.  The taste mimicked the smell with the grain and breadiness.  A smidge of bitterness.  Only a touch of the malt.  Only a soft touch of butter.  I do like that the grain didn’t overpower the flavor.  Medium to thin in the mouthfeel.  Dry at first, but after the brew warms it becomes just a bit watery.  Covers the palate in an average way.  This beer is ok.  Nothing I will seek out, but if someone offered this to me at a bar I would drink it no problem.  German brews are a nice change for me from time to time.

Pours a clear with color of pure Vermont maple syrup. Great white head lingers and remains full. Great malt on the nose and malt appears all along the flavor palate. A little weak with a watery mouthfeel.

Pours a clear amber with a nice offwhite head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, a slightly fruity nose. Taste is sweet caramel malt, bread with some nice hops. Palate is nice med body, good carbonation. Finish is caramel malt, breadiness, ending with some nice hops bitterness to add some balance. Overall a good brew.

Poured amber-brown with a white head.  Yeasty, bready aroma.  Palate was smooth, somewhat light-bodied.  Malty-nutty flavor, but with a somewhat skunky "off" taste similar to what was described in the previous rating.

Bottle. Aroma is skunky with a bit of caramel and spicy/peppery hops.  It tastes honestly pretty bad, in my opinion. To an extent, it’s pretty watery, with some malts in there.  A sweet aftertaste (that unplesantly lingers and sticks to my mouth, not a fan of the aftertaste at all), but overall this isn’t a beer I’d grab when I’m reaching for an Oktoberfest.  They actually had two different designs for the bottle when I looked, one of which is the same that ratebeer shows and another a checkered pattern.  I grabbed the checkered one, which I can’t be sure if it’s newer or older, so it’s hard to pass judgment on the skunkiness of the beer, as I can’t tell how fresh it is/which batch this comes from.  What I’ll say though, is from the bottle I had, this is hardly even considered a decent beer in my book.  5.9% alcohol.

Bottle and served in standard pint glass: Pale amber hue with a small but lasting head, almost no lace. The aroma has notes of grassy noble hops (Saaz perhaps?), caramel and pils malts, green fruits, and a hint of DMS. The taste is rather nicely balanced and not as sweet as many Marzens. There is a nice crisp bitterness to counter the pils pale malts and the caramel sweet malt. A light fruity components runs throughout. The mouth feel is sprite and lively, very refreshing for the style. Call me more than happy with this brew for it has depth and character not often found with many malt driven Oktoberfest brews. It has been decades since I had a Spaten Oktoberfest and I am left to wonder why.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $1.99 Very good.

Amber, good thick head.  Mostly a cereal malt aroma, not much hops.  Tons of good, nutty malt taste with on a slight bit of skunk despite the green bottle.  There’s some bitterness to it that balances nicely.  I’d like to try this one on draft.

On tap at a German restaurant in Sanford, Fl. Very small head, darker amber color, light mouth feel with a slight bitterness up front but finishes off mild. Light flavored beer all together. Loved it!
Bottle. Golden-red color, no head/lacing. Nice malt flavor, not too bitter - slight hop flavor. Aftertaste is short-lived. Refreshing overall.

Clear brownish orange with a decent head and lacing. Clean bready malt aroma with a hint of grassy hops. Flavors match, and include a tea-like taste. Slightly oily mouthfeel, medium carbonation, and a caramel sweet finish.

Pours a medium amber color with a rather fizzy white head.The aroma is of caramel with a skunky note due to the green bottle.The flavor was a light roasted malt balanced by a hopy bitterness.The body was medium at best and the aftertaste was bitter.Overall I could see this beer being better if it didn’t come in a green bottle.

12 oz bottle- Ur- MArzen.  Pours a deep almost woody amber with a  off dull gray/white head with some spotty lace.  Head stays nice for a while but then fades to a thin film.  Aroma is old peanut skins, bland macro-lager, hints of dust and metallic, grass, and strange odd dark malts- light burnt hint.  Flavor is caramel, light burnt toffee, toast, moderate sweetness from the caramel, then fades as it dries out- almost seems as if there is rice adjunct, grass, some green apple, a bit harsh in the finish with mineral, and metallic, but as it warms it gets softer in the finish.  Overall- a bit of a let-down.
Green 12oz bottle.  Dark amber color, white head.  Flavor of toasted malts.  Aroma of malt, oak, vanilla, and earth.  Finishes with a nutty character.  Aroma of fresh baked bread and toasted oats.
From the bottle, dark yellow and no head. Quite disappointing actually, pretty watery and void of any real substance.
Bitter caramel aroma. Deep brown. Very caramel malt, some hoppiness. Bitter for an oktoberfest. Decent but not spectacular.

bottle.  Pours a golden autumn red color with nice looking off white head, good lacing.  Aroma of wet leaves, caramel malt, candied hay.  Flavor presents a crisp refreshing caramel earthy body, with a skunkyness to the finish.  Medium to full bodied, pretty smooth.  Pretty good, although the skunk aspect detracts from what could be very good.

This one was great.  Smells malt, oats, barley, clear, lighy amber, high carbonation.  Light color like yuengling lager. Easy drinker.1 finger head disipates to thin ring.  Light density, great tingly mouth feel. Easy drinker, light sweetness, low Carmel, light skunkiness in aroma and taste. Excellent!

pours a beautiful copper with frothy head, nose of metal and skunk, fortunately it fared better on the taste and palate-malt forward as expected, smooth and very drinkable-a perfect pairing with the lamb stew i’m enjoying
Poured a light brown with a nice head. It smells grainy and tastes of skunked grains. I was disappointed by the green bottle and skunk from what could have been a good beer.
Bottle. tasted like a bud light with a seasonal twist. flavors were weak, leaving me very disappointed.
This one is a little more fizzy than I had anticipated... a good thing!  Grainy, a little sweet, a little malty.  Perfect pre-rehearsal brew on a crisp autumn night.
on tap.  Classic spaten taste with a bit more matly flavor.  amber in color and small to average head.

Bottle. In honor of October, I bought this bottle the other day. Very festive. Pours a very clear golden color with a reddish tinger. Very minimal head of white foam that coasters on top. Malty, grainy aroma with some sweetness. No real hop aroma to speak of. Medium mouthfeel. Subtle sweetness that has a very minimal hop backend. Slight fruit type flavors as well. Ends rather cleanly and dry. Pretty easy drinking.

Appearance:  amber and orange, decent head and lacing.  Aroma:  hops, roasted grains, some lighter notes of hay.  Taste:  a little bitter up front, then some roasted grains but a definite metallic note too, just like one of the raters below got.  Finish:  a little sweet grain, then lingering hops.  Notes:  A little more bitter than I generally care for in my Oktoberfest beers, and I did not like that metallic note.  Not bad, though.  Average.   Re-Rating:  Updating one year later, after having this at a beer tasting dinner in Cape May, NJ.  I wonder if I got a bad bottle first time around.  Really liked it a lot better this time, and it paired wonderfully with a pork chop.

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange with white head.  Smells of caramel, toffee, straw/grass.  Taste is similar, very sweet - not much hop character.  Some corn flavor, although I’m pretty sure it wasn’t brewed with corn.  Not necessarily a bad thing, just something I noted.

Bottle: Pours a Nice Golden/Amber, with modest whitish head. Aroma is of typical german hops, a little roastiness. I notice a little bitterness at first and a little metallic, flavors are typical german hop with a bit of roasted malt sweetness. Ends a little bitter ; not bad. But my drunken memory says its much different than what I had at Oktoberfest this year

Pours a clear honey brown color.  Aroma of yeast and grain.  Flavor is roasted grain with a hint of molasses.  This is the traditional Oktoberfest beer.  Fairly plain and quite easy drinking. I like mine with more character.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a copper brown with a bit of an orange tint.  Aroma is malts with a bit of hops and grass.  Flavor is stronger and heavier than anticipated with grassy hops and malts and a somewhat sweet flavor.  I’m not a big fan of Spaten and this is actually a fairly decent beer.  Good for a drink or two on a cool fall evening.
Bottle.  Aroma: bread, roasty.  Appearance: amber, clear, white foam.  Taste: medium sweetnes.  Palate: medium body, thin feel, oily feel, average carbonation.

12 oz. bottle- Pours clear ruby red to brown with a thin off white head, aroma is brown sugar, caramel, and German yeast. The flavor is sweet up front with a suprisingly bitter bite, much better than I was expecting. There is a bread like, maybe rye bread like flavor. Overall this is a style that I find hard to embrace, but beer like this could someday tip the scales.
(bottle)  Poured a nice amber complexion and developed a thick and rich head.  Extremely smooth and mellow with mild malt flavor.  An excellent example of this style.  Very easy to session.
bottled. pours light brown and with a medium head. smells of roasted malt, alcohol and grass. it’s fairly sour with a lingering finish. not bad, not good.

Light beige pour with thinning white head.  Aroma is strong with malt and caramel.  Flavor is oily malt, sweet caramel and heavier than it looks.  Finish is oily, very slight bitterness and lingering sweetness.

Tap. Pours a clear dark amber with minimal head and lace. Aroma is of grains, bready, slight roastedness. Flavor is interesting, starts out with a spicy bitterness soothing into creamy light sweetness falling into a crisp bitter finish.  Very clean soothing crisp finish.

24-09-10 bouteille: Brun pale, limpide et très légèrement effervescente. Solide mousse blanche disparraissant tranquillement. Premiers aromes sont de moufettes, due a la bouteille en verre vert. Sinon, plutot maltée et raffraichissante. Bonne oktoberfest.

Copper color with a foamy white head. Aroma of caramel and hops that is just a tad skunky. Very rich and malty body with a crisp flavor with a hint of caramel and a nice balance of hops. A nice Marzen that comes highly recommended.
Bottle.  Pours a clear tan orange color with a small off-white head with slight lacing. Aroma is toasted malt and grain. Tastes sweet and malty.  Not my favorite of this style.

Bottle.  Poured a deep golden color with a tiny white head.  Nose is toasted grain, caramel, and light soap and metal.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel and medium carbonation.  Flavor is dry and earthy, toasted grain up front, some caramel and grass help balance it out.  Finishes dry, slightly metallic, with light acidity and moderate noble hops bitterness.
Bottled sample at kellehers. Not my style of beer.  Would likely not try this again

Brilliantly clear amber and a creamy white head fading to a light film. Nose is some malt richness and grainy like a pils- I don’t think I’m getting any hop aroma but maybe. Taste is full of rich malt, some kilned malts and sweetness coming through. not bitter in the finish. Medium full bodied especially for the style. Pretty nice lager.
Clear amber with a small head. Looks, smells and tastes like a Yuengling. Good but what’s all the fuss.

Pours amber w/ a small white head that does not hang but does do some lacing.  Malts in the nose, caramel, bready.  Medium body, balanced finish between the malt sweetness and the hop bitterness. Malt sweetness, caramel, bready up front balanced with a spicy hop finish.

Dark, clear amber colored with a white head that gathers around the edges and leaves a touch of lacing. German hop aroma, a little German malt and toasted malt in the aroma. Light-bodied, medium carbonation, and a short finish. Lightly sweet with malt, noticeable hop presence, lightly dry finish. Not as malty as many Oktoberfests. More of a hop presence than seems typical for the style.

Nice color. Has tints of amber, yellow, gold, and brown. Not bad at all. Love this time of year when Oktoberfest beers are everywhere in grocery stores. Part of a mix 6 at K roger. Nice caramel malt flavors. Smooth drinking with just a touch of a tart aftertaste that is really nice.

From 12 oz bottle. pours deep copper with frothy head that rapidly dissipates. Carbonation persists. Nose is earthy, with a bit of skunk that vanishes once you take a drink. Taste is surprisingly mild with a clean finish. It makes me wish there was more. Not bad, but it’s lacking something...
From a tap,amber in color,white head,carmel,brown sugar?smooth, can drink a lot of these in one setting.

Poured from bottle. Pours red-brown with a deep, pillowy head. Nose is caramel, toffee, apple, and toast. Light sweetness on the front, then finishes with a more bitter close -- there’s still an overall flavor of brown or candy sugar. Good.
A clear amber-brown pour with white head.  The aroma is roasted malt and skunk (damn green bottles).  It has a medium body with average carbonation.  The taste is lightly sweet with a dry finish.
Nice color to the beer but the palate felt just a bit too thin.  Serving: Bottle
The aroma is full of sweet malts, a bit of yeast, and also some skunkiness.  The flavor is a touch malty, some grains, and skunk.

On Tap a Munich Haus ! Very light amber pour, small white head that leaves quick and laces little. Aroma is light, some light toast and a bit of flowery hops in there as well. Flavor is mostly some sweet bread, a bit of toast, and a very little bit of hoppiness.
I would rate this beer solidly average.    Some Oktoberfest beers have you waiting for autumn, but I found this beer to be wanting in distinction.

Appearance: orange-red; very long head stand; solid, slightly off-white head; good foam

Aroma: Good malt aroma; slight caramel note with bread and toasty cereal

Flavor: Initially, great rich malt flavor with toastiness; slight hop bitterness but not much; Good concentration; little sweetness

Mouthfeel: pretty textbook; medium body, creamy texture and medium carbonation; smooth, no cloyingness
Amber and nice medium bodied, with a nice full flavor. One of the better Oktoberfests for sure.
One of my favorite beers.  Dark, sweet, hoppy, and smooth.  Best on tap, but it still is very good in the bottle, if it is fresh and stored properly.  Very high alcohol content.
Malty and fruity mixed aroma. Clear orange color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning with a light dry hop finish. Lightly thick palate at the end.
Sampled on tap at SIB, pours murky brown. Flavour of malts, bread and wood. Not bad.

Purchased on my trip to Nashville. Second of two Oktoberfest rated tonight (the other one being Paulaner). Pours a clean rich orange colour with an off-white head that has average retention and good lacing. The scent is different from the Paulaner, as it does not have all of the dark fruits. More on the pilsner aromas. Soft caramel malt taste and hints of bread. Not much here compared to the Paulaner Oktoberfest.
Super nutty, bready. Caramelly. Nice grass/floral hop character, although quite light. Good balance. Sulfur.
Mild caramel, sweet malt aroma.  Clear, brown-amber, with sticking white head.  Mild Caramel, mild roast, and nut hints flavour.  Mild bitterness.
caramel, roasty, smoke, golden, amber, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, medium body, thin feel, average carbonation, astringent,

Spaten-Franziskaner Brau Munchen--Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Marzen

Oktoberfest--1998 12 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  (2.25 / 5.0)  Light rusty amber color.  Slightly sweet alcohol malt body.  Green bottle.  Sampled 9/20/1998.

Oktoberfest--1998 16.9 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Bright clear rich copper color.  Light fruit malt aroma and a hint of German yeast.  Richly flavored slightly fruity medium body with clean buttery texture.  Lingering tingly spicy finish.  Nice lace.  Sampled 4/5/1999.

1999 12 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Clear thin rusty golden color.  Light fruit front.  Very smooth body with muted rich flavor hints of caramel fruit and light smoke in medium thick body. Crisp laced light end. No green bottle stank.  Sampled 9/26/1999.

2000 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Green bottle.  Very clear true amber color.  Mild floral malt front with Bavarian notes.  Crisp German Oktoberfest smooth medium body.  Mild caramel fruit notes.  Minimal sweetness.  Ends smooth.  Lacy head.  Sampled 11/5/2000.

2001 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Green bottle.  Clear copper amber color.  Toasted malty floral front.  White rich laced head.  Crisp rich smooth toasted caramel fruit biscuit dry sweet body.  Dry malty end.  Butterscotch notes.  Mild hops.  Sampled 9/26/2001.

2001 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Clear bright copper amber color.  Nice laced head.  Crisp lightly toasted mild hop malty front.  Crisp smooth body.  Thin Oktoberfest maltiness.  Light sweetness.  Toasted caramel notes.  Dry slightly spicy mild end.  Sampled 4/18/2002.

2002 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Clear thin bronze amber color.  Slightly spicy Bavarian malt mild floral hop front.  Rich lacy head.  Thin tangy Oktoberfest malty light nut sweet caramel biscuit body.  Tangy malt citrus clean mild hop end.  Sampled 11/1/2002.

2004 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (4.25 / 5.0)  No Stank!  Foamy mild lace head.  Clear thin dark shaded amber color.  Tangy mild hop malt front.  Smooth crisp mild sweet toasted malty caramel fruit body.  Mild tangy hop end.  Smooth clean rich brew.  Brown bottle.  Sampled 9/30/2004.

2004 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Foamy lacy head.  Clear thin light red amber color.  Mild hop front.  Light Green bottle Bavarian stank.  Crisp smooth light toasted caramel mild sweet fruit biscuit body.  Clean mild hop end.  Easy Fest.  Sampled 9/27/2004.

2005 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  25+IBU’s?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Tight lace head.  Clear bright thin amber color.  Malt spice mild hop front.  Crisp dry sweet tangy malty mild toasted rich caramel Mild Bavarian fruit stank body.  Clean malt hop spice mild citrus creamy end.  Sampled 11/3/2005.

2006 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  25 IBU’s?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Mild lace head.  Clear bright thin bronze amber color.  Mild toasted hop front.  Hint of Stank.  Smooth mild tangy dry sweet toasted caramel apple cherry body.  Crisp smooth slightly tangy hop malt spice end.  Sampled 9/19/2006.

2007 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Foamy off white mild lace head.  Clear thin bright amber color.  Mild malt hop front.  Crisp toasted mild fruit dry sweet caramel Fest body.  Crisp smooth malt spice mild hop end.  Nice Oktoberfest.  Sampled 9/15/2007.

2008 Green 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Thin foamy lacy white head.  Clear thin bright copper color.  Mild hop stank hint malt front.  Smooth easy refreshing mild toasted caramel malty fest body.  Smooth mild hop malt spice hint end.  Smooth somewhat bland rich Fest.  Sampled 8/23/2008.  6-Pack $8.79.

Spaten-Brau Munchen--Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Marzen--brewed in munich Germany since 1397--2010 12 oz. green bottle.  5.90% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (3.5 / 5.0)  Thin light lace white head.  Clear thin dark copper amber color.  Green bottle stank hint.  Delicate caramel fruit light hop front.  Thin textured dry sweet crisp slightly tangy light toasted caramel fruit hint dry biscuit body.  Lingering malt tang mild hop dry end.  Classic German Fest is lighter in color and dryer than American Fests.  Sampled 9/15/2010.  Purchased 6-Pack for $8.99 @ The Ballard Market, Seattle on 9/14/2010.
