Nothing impressive here. Gold/amber color with a decent white head. Aroma is a very weak grainy one with some caramel. Taste is bland with grains, malts, and a tiny bit of sweet caramel. Carbonated and a bit skunky. I do not hate it, but I do not like it either. Disappointing offering from Spaten.
Not bad, I’ll be honest, I didn’t take the time to look at the color.  Aroma wasn’t too strong, but then again, I have a terrible nose.  Taste is alright, not too strong.  Overall, an average beer.
On tap at Loreley, NYC.  Pours clear amber with very thin, and short lasting, head.  Minimal aroma.  Crisp and malty, finishes clean.  Hops provide nice balance to caramel malt flavor.
caramel, roasty, smoke, golden, amber, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, medium body, thin feel, average carbonation, astringent,

Lunch at Oktoberfest in Epcot kingdom in Disneyworld.  Since i was eating here might as well order an Oktoberfest.  Pours and amber color and tastes smooth with caramel and malty notes.  Pretty enjoyable accompanyment to a german buffett.
Pours amber with a white head aroma is malt and a good bit of hop. Flavor is much the same.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark golden color with white head.  Taste is slightly roasted barley, some hops, and a hint of caramel.  Not great for a Oktoberfest.
This beer poured a dark yellow/amber pour with a nice white head. Good lacing on my glass. Smell of hops and hops. Flavor is malts and hops and a little sweet. A decent enough beer to drink again.
Pours clear amber with a frothy white head that fades. Aroma of skunk, apple, grain, and caramel. Taste is not bad, caramel apple, mild skunkiness. Thick smooth body

On tap at yard house ch. Poured an amber-orange; clear with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, brea and fruit. Soft and easy to drink. Bready and fruity. A light earthy bitterness in the finish. Ok overall.
12 oz. bottle. - Nice malty aroma with some hops.  Carmal and other roasted malts were well balanced wtih the hops; sweet malty finish.  Dark amber with white head faded fast.  nice bittering finish.

clear copper with a wispy quickly diminishing white head. aroma is caramel light and light graininess. flavor is fairly flat, with nothing really standing out. it drinks well enough but there is really not much too it.
A dark golden almost amber beer with a white head. Aroma is hoppy and malty. Taste is rich malty and sweet, notes of hops and roasted malt. Very well balanced. Drinkable but tasteful.

Pours dark amber with a nice off white head. The aroma is very dry and dusty. Pilsner like, really. The flavor is sweeter with a little caramel and spice to balance out the dusty hop finish. A very pleasant and drinkable oktoberfest.

Appearance is dark amber with a thin head, medium-full body, and high carbonation.

Flavor is roasty Munich malt and leafy noble hops, with some prickly minerality. 

Overall, it is well-balanced, but the hop character is more pronounced than the malt. This is partly due to the higher carbonation and minerality.
On tap; amber in color, good solid oktoberfest style beer. Rich with some sweetness; I would but this beer again
Pours  dark amber small white head.Average looking beer very transluscent.This beer is a treat this time of year medium body with great malt and caramel flavors.

12 oz. bottle poured into a lager glass.  Pours a beautiful clear, light copper color with a small off-white head that dissipates quickly. Fair lacing on the glass.  Nice malty aroma with subtle hops. Flavor is sweet malt. Balanced hop bitterness. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Short, slightly dry finish.
Had it on tap.  Pours a light amber color with a medium-sized white head.  Tastes pretty malty, with a bit of hops coming through in the end.  Very smooth and drinkable - a delight really.

Pours a amber orange color with a minimal white head.  Aroma is of roassted malt, baked bread, carmel, and a little hops.  flavor is malty with flavors of roasted malt, carmel, baked bread, and a little hops.  has a medium mouthfeel with a soft finnish.  overall, a good octoberfest.
golden pour with a small white head , fits the style perfect and it should it is  one of the seven true octobertest brewers.
Alright beer, but middle of the road in a lot of ways.  Not bad, but there are better Oktoberfests out there.

bottle: I was looking forward to this beer. Has a full malt profile, sweet and simple. Caramel malts and a little kick of hops. The only detractor was vegetal notes that I found unpleasent. Overall, a decent beer but I’ve had better.

Tap. Poured a light clear copper with a thin head.  Malty nose.  More flavor than I expected from this. Used to drink this as a kid and always enjoyed. And I enjoyed it tonight. Very drinkable with a hint of hops and a solid malt base finishes a bit bitter.
Roasted malts with notes of caramel in the aroma. Flavor is light caramel and roasted malts some ginger and maple. pretty weak  Marzen. I have had better.
ok festbeer nothing special, flavor really lacks any character..I thought it was on the weak side of the Oktoberfests i’ve tried..not as rich in flavor as Hacker...below average..
Pours an amber orange with a white head. Aroma of toasted malts and caramel. Flavor is of smooth malts and some hops with a sweet finish. Pretty decent beer.

A= dark orange-amber with thick head that fizzles fairly slowly, and lacing sticking to my 16-oz boot glass for a good long while.

S= Sweet caramel-ish malts, some tea-ish hops, maybe some nuts.

T= Malts, and malts. Some good faint hops in the background, but not hoppy.

M=Medium-bodied, with good carbonation, not too much, just the right amount.

D= Excellent. Can drink these all night.

A solid brew, in a great season. The most wonderful time of the year:Oktoberfest. From the nation that made beer what it should be, at least before the great American microbrew revolution came along. I love it. Spaten is always exceptional in my book.

From my beeradvocate.com review, under username happy4hoppybeer

Bottle. Dark copper with small white head. Aroma is earthy with malts, toffee, and roasted nuts. Flavors of caramel/toffee, brown sugar, maple, and salted hazelnuts. Smooth. Good body and carbonation. Roundness. Makes me want to go to Germany.
On tap. Clear amber color like a good Octoberfest. Mildly fruity and sweet with a nice touch of malts. Essentially, it plays it really safe, but I have had much worse Octoberfests in the past.

Bottle pour was attractive. Nice, foamy, off-white head that dissipated in short time. Looks great, dark, coppery amber color. Aromas of darker malts, with a slight champange/sweet fruit hint. Very smooth flavors of roasted malts, nuts, and carmelized sugars. A well balanced hops finish, with a slight alcohol bite. A good brew from one of my preferred brewers.
Draught. Clear amber color, off-white head. Sweet malt, caramel, some grassy hops, and a bit fruity. A little too sweet for me.

Bottle. Pour was light to medium golden with a nice off white head. Aroma was crisp with light biscuit and a touch of hop. Flavor was clean and smooth with more bread character. Dry and refreshing with a well balanced hop flavor. Good brew.
pretty typical Oktofest.  Sweet and malty with a nice shade of brown.  Aroma was muted.  Could have been a little drier for my palate.
Bottle, Refhills, Ncl. Very clean tasting dry lemon biscuit flavour. Cereal/wheat aroma, plenty of fizzy sherbert tingles around the mouth, with a decent creamy finish and apleasing bitterness.
Skunked mildew smell. Clear tea colored, thick head. Thin mouthfeel. Flavor is of light roasted skunked grain. A bit too sweet with a hint of bitter blueberries. Disjointed an rather unpleasant.
A pretty decent octoberfest, nice coloring and smell, but lacking a bit in taste.

Looks kind of like a Coke. Carmel colored, and no head. Aroma of fresh hops is a bit confrontational, and has no real character. Flavor is not bad, but also boring. I think the best thing about this beer is that it doesn’t suck.

Experienced on tap in a pub glass.  The beer pours a medium amber color with a moderate and reasonably thick white head.   The aroma brings some notes of floral hops, and some malt sweetness.  However, it has an obvious lack of the level of malt character and complexity that is found in the best examples of the style.  Far more Munich and Vienna malt would be of benefit.  The palate shows a reasonable level of malt character, along with some balancing hops.  At the same time, it lacks the complexity in terms of mouthfeel and flavor.  Overall, a disappointment.

Pours a brownish amber crowned by a frothy white-tan head. Aroma wafts malt, caramel and alcohol. Taste is malt with a slightly hoppy finish; medium bodied and well balanced. doesn’t knock you over but an above average beer. Pairs well with mild chili or cornbeef on rye.

Their is not much head upon pour, but the color is fantastic: light golden brown. It looks as if it is loaded with spices.

Taste: while it looks like it is loaded with spices, it is surprisingly light and crisp -no bite like other oktoberfest’s. Very drinkable (i.e. more than one is desirable). light to medium malt and lightly hopped.

smells like brisk fall day.

this is now my favorite of oktoberfest beers. it is spot-on.

Beer of the month at Winking Lizard. Clear amber pour with a big beige head. Nose of caramel malt, lager yeast and a touch of crisp hops. Sweet and caramel malt flavor with some noble hops contributing to a dry finish. Flavor is a little more full than the nose would suggest and I like how they avoid the overly sweet finish that some o-fests have.

Solid beer in all respects. Decent head, no lacing, amber color, malty aroma, well-balanced taste with nice malts, some dark fruits present (dates), but subtle, nice hoppy finish... It’s good, but I gotta say that nothing really stands out about it. It’s not ’average,’ but more like ’spot-on’ for the style, and it’s really good, but again, nothing really stands out about it, which is probably why it’s really good. It’s what a Marzen *should* be!

Had on tap.  Pours with a foamy head that dissipates rather quickly.  Has a nice carmel color appropriate for an Oktoberfest.  Taste is part bready, part bitter - not very complex, but very drinkable.  Has a somewhat sweet finish.
Not one of my favorites in this category.  Aroma of barley malt and yeast, color is opaque orange/amber.  Flavor is mostly malted, palate is fizzy and has a carbonated sting.

12oz bottle capped at a work ’Oktoberfest’ dealio.  Can’t quite tell for sure by looking through the green glass, but it appears to be a lighter brown color.  I will say that Spaten has a very traditional looking label.  Nose is a touch skunky with bready malt backing.  Touch of brown sugar notes along with some earthy floral undertones.  Very malty in taste with some grassy/hay flavor around the edges.

On tap this Oktoberfest pours a dark amber color with a foamy head.  Aroma of malts, molasses and caramel.  Taste was a rich malty flavor with sweet and earthy finish.  This one doesn’t taste nearly as skunky as many in this style tend to do.  Not bad - much better than I was expecting.
Clear light brown with a fluffy white head. Sweet slightly sugary molasses aroma and taste with a malty finish.
Dark amber pour sweet caramel aroma and taste with a slight bitter finish malty earthy roasted taste.  A quality oktoberfest out of the bunch.
Deep amber color with some brown notes and sparse tan lacing.  Spice and dark malts in nose.  Medium body with a clean aftertaste.  Very mild bitterness.  Easy to drink.

Good Marzen but tends to get a bit sweet and lacks the depth of better version.  I’m trying this beer against Ayinger’s version.  This beer pours a darkish brown-amber, completely clear with a small, white head.  Bubbles stick around nicely, though.  The aroma is malty and clean but quite light.  There’s no off note that can creep into lighter German imports.  There’s a touch of apples and grapes detectable, as well.  The flavor comes through more strongly vinous with a light but fruity malt.  It gets just a bit too sweet in the finish, but I’m sure that I’d lose sight of that quickly if I were drinking it any quantity.  While both this beer and the Ayinger would be easy to drink all night, I have to give the nod to Ayinger.  Still, Spaten puts out a nice marzen with a relatively low price tag.
(draft). Clear amber color. Small white head. Light malty aroma. Light roasted malt flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a light brown with an off-white head. Aroma was a little skunk and a little malt, bread. Taste like a cross between a Heineken and an Octoberfest. Not bad but not high on my list.
Tap at Old Chicago Uptown.  Reddish brown pour, malty aroma.  Tangy malty flavor with a sweet finish.

12 oz. bottle from Arnold’s in Cincinnati.  Pours orange brown, slightly cloudy, with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, bread, grass, earth, generic German beer funk.  Flavor is more of the same.  Sweet, earthy, grassy, slightly bitter, with funk and metallic notes.  Might be all right in the right environment, but this one doesn’t do much for me.

Copper color with a malty aroma.  Complex rich flavors that echo the aroma.  Sweet, but not in a caramelly/toffee way like so many other Octoberfests. Well balanced and fairly light, though the richness would not make this one for all day drinking.  Finishes cleanly.  You can almost taste the pretzels.........

Sampled at Lundeen’s Brew Ha-Ha 2009. Pours a deep orange color with a very spare off-white head. Aroma has a bready character with some caramel malt notes, toffee sweetness, grassy, flowery and herbal hops note. Flavor has an apple and grape sweetness, a strong hay note and a metalic ending. Body was good but the texture was very thin with a lively carbonation. Just not too good and a bit disappointed in a "true" German oktoberfest beer.
An average octoberfest... Caramel notes with a little toffee... Very bitter finish with an average palate.  Just average, I have had better octoberfests.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber/brown color with a miniscule off white head. Nose is light nutty roast and sweet malts and a hint of dirt. Palate is full and clean. Flavor is nutty, dirty, malty but clean and crisp and kinda nice.

Sampled from a 12 oz green bottle this beer poured a dark caramel-amber color with a small beige head. The aroma was lightly sweet, tangy and malty with a touch of pear. The flavor was light caramel, tangy and malty with notes of ripe cherries and pears. The finish was medium length fruity caramel. Rather enjoyable.
1 of my fave Lagers: Very malty and soulful -with a cool spicy ,buttery texture.  Sinkable ,flavoursome Marzen.

I’ve had this countless times and not rated it, so it’s high time I rated it!  Colour... orange-amber. Nose... sweet malt and an even balance of hops. Palate... plenty of C02, lightly chewy, nicely balanced between the roasty malt and hops, though not especially complex. I Like it on tap much better than the bottle.

Color:  Dark reddish gold, clear, thin white head that lasts.  Aroma:  lager with hints of malt.  Flavor:  moderate malt sweetness, distinct lager.  Light bodies, not hop bitterness.  Not a big fan of this style, but I am trying them to better understand.

12oz bottle.  Poured a dark golden color with a two finger soapy head.  Smelled moslty of sweet malt with a hint of hops.  Taste was mainly malt and grain with a hint of caramel, that finished with slight dry bitter hops.  Would have expected more for a German Oktoberfest.
Pretty standard Märzen fare. Nice amber color, medium head. Enjoyable, not remarkable. Would try again

Bottle. Pours a clear amber and  a medium white head.  The aroma is a lot of malt and metallic notes behind slight hops.  The falvor is smooth at first, nice malty body, but there is a nice bite towards the end.  There is lacking body though, a little too thin.
Not a bad beer, but I like other Oktoberfest brews so much better. Came in a glass with a tuba on it. Score.

Green bottle. Pale brownish orange color, thin foamy head. The bottle in the picture is brown, but this is not. Bummer. Came from a 12 pack&#40cardboard box&#41 so presumably not much light got in. Flavor is slightly sweet, with notes of mild roast and bread. Medium bodied with the trademark slightly metallic finish of the German hops. Doesn’t seem skunked, luckily. Pretty passable Oktoberfest, one of my favorite versions from Germany.
This might’ve been a nice beer, hard to say.  The green bottle kind of ruined things.  Aroma was all skunk, flavor was mostly skunk with a bit of malt and yeast peaking through.  Too bad.

Death by green bottle. Pours a pale copper with a thin white head. Aroma was skunk through and though with a hint of malt and bread. Flavor was also skunked. I’d like to try this one again in a brown bottle.
pours amber gold with an effervescent head. aroma is malty and nutty. flavor is toffeel, toasted grains and little tangy. flavor is somewhat hoppy and finishes clean. pretty good.
It smells skunky. Taste is malt and the finish is thin. a bit of a let down.

Bottle.  Pours a brownish amber color with a nice off-white head.  Faint aromas of malts and bread on the nose.  Has all the hallmarks of a marzen.  Nice roasted malt flavor with a flash of bitterness.  Medium bodied.  Not bad.
dark amber with fizzy bitter taste. but not so bitter to give you that ’bitter beer face’  overall a pretty good beer that I would drink again.
another excellent reprisentation of Oktoberfest. A nice caramel flavor.  blah blah requires more words blah blah.

Bready aroma. Deep amber in colour. Description says medium bodied but its pretty bold to me. Although a bit thin towards the back. Alcohol doesnt really come through which may or may not be a good thing. Very nice beer.
Floral aroma.  Spicy and malty flavor with a little skunk.  A decent Oktoberfest.
Bottle.  Orangish in color with thin white head.  Aroma is good, but I am not a fan of the taste of this beer.  Much too malty for my palate.  Perfer other marzens to this one.
12 oz. bottles purchased at Central Market in Shoreline, WA.  Pours a dark copper/bronze color with an off-white head.  Flavor: Full bodied, sweet.

Pours bronze with some slightly fluffy white head. Aroma has notes of malt and caramel but is a bit weak. Flavor is a bit more rich of roasted malt, caramel, and currants. Somewhat bland with little finish. It’s aight.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Very deep amber color with a foamy white head.  The head is gone in seconds.
Aroma: Slight metallic and wet dog notes.  A bit of caramel and toasted malt.  Could be better.
Taste: Toasty malt, a bit of grain and biscuit.  Mild bitterness in the background that helps even out all of the maltiness.
Palate: Medium-high, prickly carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Medium, slightly bitter finish.
Overall:  A middle of the road Oktoberfest that isn’t really spectacular in any way.
Rebuy: No, there are better ones out there.

Pours a deep orangish gold with a medium head. Aroma is mildly skunked &#40damned green bottles&#41 with a bit of nice hoppiness and a nutty maltiness, really a nice pungent beer if it weren’t for that skunk lingering. 
The flavor has some nice roasty somewhat grainy malt well balanced with a nice noble hoppiness, and just a touch of an almost nutty candy like sweetness in the background.

Fairly good for a marzen style. Pours out a ruddy brown with a respectable tan head. Aroma is lightly sweet. Taste is malty sweet, a bit of spice, and a touch yeasty. Not bad but it starts to get too sweet for me towards the end. I doubt I could have more than one or two of these beers and this style is supposed to be one of the more sessionable ones. Regardless, not bad at all in limited quantities.
Draft at Papa Jakes, Buffalo. Deep amber pour. Roasty & sweet caramel malt aroma. Taste is almost peaty like a scotch marzen. Very malty and balanced. One of the better marzens
Pours rust colored amber, light head, sweet malty with good carbonation.  I had no skunk or aftertaste.  Finished well.  Just a super fall beer with a brat and mashed potatoes, ummmmmmmm

Nice dark copper color with a light tan head. Nice malty aroma, sweet and rich. Sweet toffee malt base with a light earthy, grassy hop finish. Medium body, crisp and refreshing a tasty beer for the fall months.
33cL bottle. Pours amber with slight head. Slightly sweet aroma and taste. Solid marzen if stored properly many examples in the US seem to be spoiled.
Had this at a sampling.  Skunked Oktoberfest! Stupid Germans and their green bottles!
Pours to an amber color with aroma of barley and hops.  Tastes slight sweetness with a bitter aftertaste.  The beer got better as I drank it, overall a decent beer.
Pours to a small, golden head with an amber body. Has slight hint of barley perhaps. Goes down smooth and doesn’t leave any unpleasant aftertaste. Another good German brew.

Pours a nice golden amber with a white, quickly fading head.  The aroma is truly intriguing, grass, hops, a little toffee, and some light fruits.  The flavor is rather similar, if perhaps a little earthy. Mostly, this beer surprised me, especially in the nose, and as I’m not often surprised, that won this beer some points.

Bottle:  The aroma is light caramel, earthy hops, roastiness, and faint grass.  It pours a transparent amber with a small off-white head that quickly fades to a small ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with light caramel.  The finish has some light roastiness and some earthy hoppiness.  Medium bodied with lively carbonation.

500 ml on tap in the USA. Light amber hue with fine head and spotted lace. Aroma is malty-sweet and slightly yeasty---quite nice. Wonderful classic Marzen flavors combined in a great balance. The key here is the roasted malt flavors, which give the sweet malt the needed relief.

Radegast: pint glass: getting on in the evening but I remember this being no more than average.  The nose was farmy, lots of grains... the taste was mild and even, but I wouldn’t say balanced.  Just average tone and feel of the beer.

Not my style, but an ok beer.  On tap @ Brass Tap Wesley Chapel, FL.  Pours orange with a white head.  Nose is malt, lager, hops, bread, and hay.  Flavor is about the same with a lager flavor and bread.  Not a bad Marzen, if that’s what the occasion calls for.
Sampled at the 8th Annual Music City Brewer’s Festival.  Orange red with a big white foam.  The aroma is toasted malts, grainy.  Taste is toasty, caramel, light grainy finish.
Bottle.  Pours an orange amber body with an off white head.  Cereal notes, some light grain y notes with a dried fruit and earth y tones.  Decent.

Very delicious beer. I shared a pitcher of this stuff with some friends at a beer garden in Astoria, Queens, NYC. A nice middle-ground beer: not too dark, not too light. Nice amber color, sweet taste and smooth body.

Draught pours clear, dark amber with a dense khaki head.  Nose is primarily grain, and carmel with what seems like roasted almonds in the background.  Taste is slightly sweet, leading out front with caramel and brown sugar, but finishing with apparent baking spice and earthy hops.  The overall body is light/moderate with soft carbonation and a nice example of a marzen.
Pours brown with a big offwhite head. Nose is fruity,  spicy.  Taste is spicy and sweet, with notes of brown sugar and caramel.  Character doesn’t bowl you over, yet is very solid. Enjoyable stuff.

Overall Impression: 
I picked up a bottle of this last fall from Norm’s, it’s a solid if not spectacular Octoberfest brew.

Poured a solid, three-finger head of tan hue above a clear dark amber body.  Aroma was clean and clear but had nothing prominent, and the taste was a nice blend of hops and spices.  An okay mouthfeel with a sweet and spiced finish make for a nice, refreshing fall beer.
Draft pitchers @ Gustav’s. Amber pour with a cream head. Sweet with not quite enough hop. Smooth and fairly flavorful for a German beer on draft in a chain.
Great amber color. When poured it had a creamy head. Very smooth and little sweet after taste.

On draft at Gustav’s. Clear amber pour with a small cream colored head. Mostly sweet malt flavor with some light floral hops in there and a strange, buttery aftertaste. It was smooth and easy to quaff though.

12oz bottle. Lighter amber color with a pretty nice cream head. some lacing. Sweetness of the malt and balenced with hops. Very nice. The aftertaste was a bit like buttered bread. A little watered down so it shouldn’t get the highest marks but still a very good beer.
Bottle at Mr. Pickiwick’s in Stowe Vermont. The color is a clear amber with a thin beige head. The aroma is very strong of hops. The taste is also of hops and citrus fruits and a nice sweetness.

Sweet malt with a fading lightly hopped aftertaste and an impressive dark amber hue. A bit buttery?? probally wrong, but I swear theres something to that (going to have to sample again). Pounded this one back and was looking for more. Yea! Lets get ripped!

Draft @ Sommerfest.  Pours a clear amber with a good off white head.  Has a decent aroma of wseet malts with a touch of hops and pepper.  Has an ejoyable flavor.  Good balance.  Not real strong but very refreshing.  Has a medium body.  Good carbonation.  A pretty solid finish with a good aftertaste.  This is a real good beer.

Of course there is malt here, it’s an Oktoberfest.  What impresses me is the hops.  Just the way I like them: in the background.  The hops are kind of peppery, not that annoying grapefruit taste so many breweries here in the States are infatuated with.  This beer is very refeshing and tasty.  I like this slightly better than Samuel Adams’ offering, which is saying something.  Mine came in a green bottle for some reason, but surprisingly didn’t affect the taste.  18/20.

33cl bottle poured into a dimpled mug.  Pours clear amber brown with two finger off-white head.  Nose is dark fruits and nuts.  Flavor is bitter and malty.  Finish is medium to long bitterness.  Quite smooth and refreshing brew.  I could drink these all night.

Pretty amber appearance, which can be seen through the green bottle before you even crack it open. Tiny sediments can be seen. A mild maltiness, subtle sweetness. Restricted floral hop aroma. I must admit, I did not realize this beer had 5.9% alcohol at first.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, basic brown body with a thin cap of white foam. Gee. A bit of an inauspicious start, I must say.

Smell: Meager, dull maltiness with light notes of spicy, floral hops and fruit. This is both tragic and heartwrenching, like receiving news a dear friend has died recently.

Taste: I fought to keep a troubled, even wearied look off my face upon the realization that blandness would be the order of the day here. Sweetish, vague malts with, perhaps, even some pilsner malt hints to it. Very light fruity undertones of apple and grapes. Mildly bitter, faintly spicy European hops. Sadly, it’s just more of the same until the abrupt end. The finish is semi-dry and lightly crisp.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: I’ll admit, I was taken aback by how surprisingly bland and ho-hum this one was, being Spaten is one of the propagators of this noble style. I’m simply left wanting more (any) malt depth and complexity and even just a tiny bump in overall body to keep that nagging though of drinking brown water away. Perhaps I’ll give this one a re-visit sometime down the road so I can hopefully put this disheartening experience behind me.
Not a bad beer, but not a great beer either.  Slightly skunky flavor and smell knock the rating down in my book.  Yet still crisp and refreshing with a sweet undertone.

Poured amber from bottle, with modest beige head and good clarity. Cereal malt flavor with layers of toast and roast leading to floral hop notes and a slight drying finish. Medium-lean body and very smooth. Festive, indeed. 

4/26/2009 rating:
Good clarity from sienna pour. Malty aroma with sour note. Residual sugar in flavor, lean body and moderate carbonation.

Hmm, the bottle on the picture on here is brown and my bottle is green.  And with a green bottle comes… skunk.  The skunk is noticeable  the moment you pry off the cap.  There’s a bit of malt mixed in with it.  The beer itself isn’t black and white, but a light amber with a thin airy light tan head that goes away fast.  Taste of skunk, Munich malt, toasted malt.  Thin body has a gritty texture and finishes up with a vegetal/corny/dirty sox mixture.
Great amber-orange crystal malty color. Aroma is fresh. Flavor is well balanced hops, with some fruity overtones. Malt is delightfully understated. This was a pleasant surprise.
Amber pour with average white head.  Aroma of corn pudding, and slightly sour taste as typical of malt liquor.  So so.
On tap. Not much aroma. Golden brown in color with no head. Malty and sweet, with a bit of a bready taste. There is a mild hop finish. This is a great beer, especially on tap.
Dark gold on the pour. Faint smell, not distasteful. It has a bitter taste on the finish that isn’t too overpowering. Decent.

Bottle pours a clear copper amber color with a thick head that quickly fades to a thin layer.  Roasted caramel malt aroma with some spices.  Flavor is sweet and malty with a hint of roasted nuts and a slight hop bitterness in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a glowing dark amber with a one finger creamy white head.  The nose is heavy malt, some spice and light grassy hops.  The taste is toasted malt, some sweet caramel and grain with a slight peppery hops finish.  Medium creamy body.  Nothing exciting, just a well put together beer.
Ugly brown color, like tea; thin head dissipates quickly. Smells faintly sweet, taste is a bit sweet, a little maltiness, faint bitterness; watery. I am not a fan.
A fun fall back beer. Excellent for a classy game of flip-cup or beer pong, a wonderful chug. Malty, sweet, unobtrusive.

Despite the fairly high ratings, did not particularly impress me. Dark orange-amber color with a white head.  Lots of malt on the aroma.  Very malty; slightly sweet caramel malts and a tea-like flavor to it. Pilsner-like grain flavor and mild hoppiness. I’ll take a Sam Adams Octoberfest over this one.

copper color, 1 finger head. this tastes like it could be good, but unfortunatley it tastes as though i got a skunked beer...or at least i hope its skunked! i will have to give this another go when it comes back around.
Pours a light amber with small white head. Malty sweet aroma. Honey sweetness in the flavor. Good beer.

I have to say, I bought up nearly all the stocks at my local beer store.. kept going back because this one went down so well... would love to have it on a year round basis! Great malty aroma and flavor. excellnet hop bitterness to malty sweetness ration. Good head retention, and a really smooth on the palate! I have to say, this is my favorite Oktoberfest as of this review!

Pours a clear dark amber, with a light off-white head that doesn’t stick around too long. Nose is slightly bready, sweet caramel. taste follows suit - a nice, light, sweet breadiness couples with a lightly sweet caramel note. Very drinkable. Carbonation is middle of the road, over a medium light body, with just a hint of stickiness. Nice beer.

Slight caramel dates on the nose.  Deep amber color, frothy head.  Rich malt, some caramel, good bitter balance.  Big carbonation, medium body, sautéed raisin finish.  Malty with good bitterness, nice beer.
330 mL (green) bottle.  Transparent amber with just a ring of head.  Malty aroma.  Flavour is sweet caramel malt, toast, nuts, some earthy hops.  Medium body.  Medium-mild carbonation.

11.2 oz. bottle, consumed on 1-4-09. Musty aroma features bran muffin and continental European hops scents. Pours a clear, dull brass color with a small amount of thin beige head and good lacing. Flavor of lemon, butter, pie crust, honey, flowers, and pomegranate. Lingering sweetness. Light body. Creamy in the palate and reasonably lively. Not as crisp as many other lagers but still crisper than an ale. Easy to drink.
On tap. Light brown and filtered. Nose of malts and german yeasts. Taste is malty, a bit spicy, and a bit alcoholic for a 6 percent beer. Very thin. OK.

355 mL pours copper, clear, with small white head. aroma is a lager yeast, biscuit, malt. mouthful is sweet with caramel and malt with a touch of caramel. not bad... but not my favorite style either...
Pours a nice amber with a red tinge with a small head. Aroma of hops, malt, caramel, and bread. Flavor is malt, bread, yeast, caramel, spices. Decent octoberfest.

Sampled at the Second Cellar Reduction.  Pours a light amber with some white head and slight chill haze.  Nose is caramel malt and some biscuit.  Flavor notes of toasted malt, some honey, and a touch of nuttiness.  Medium creamy body with medium carbonation.  Very nice actually, Id drink this again.
Bottle with Butters at Second Cellar Reduction.  Pours caramel color with a pale tan head.  Smell like biscuits and honey.  Caramel and malt flavors.
Pours an amber orange with an off-white head.  Nose is very light with a touch of malt and marzen. Sweet malts and marzen with an earthy finish.  Nothing special.  6/3/7/3/12 = 3.1
Bottle.  Translucent copper with a small offwhite head. Smooth hints of caramel and malts, not too sugary, and a moderate mouthfeel.

Pours a very clear copper color with a very small slightly off-white head... Smells of sweet malts... Tastes of the same sweet malts with a subtle hoppiness... Wonderful flavor for a marzen(not my favorite style by a longshot)... Medium bodied, lingering sweetness, lingering mouthfeel... Top notch marzen...
12 oz bottle.  Poured a clear amber with a one finger off white head.  Aroma of caramel and some earthy hop notes.  Flavor is hoppy up front with a smooth malty finish.
bottle pour was yellow white head this was one of many i drank of this years marzens and i am trying to think if thier was any better oh yes I think that they all were better

On Tap-cloudy amber color w/a moderate tan head. Flavors of caramel, roasted malt, raisens, & figs. Sweet, pleasant brew; not complicated but an enjoyable sesson brew that went well w/my lunch. Had some carbonation to it. I’d certainly drink this again; good solid choice if you see it somewhere on tap. Long, roasted malt finish.

pours brown/amber  clear- This is one of the better Octoberfest brews that I have tried.  I still have not tried one that I ’really’ like.  Just not my cup of ’beer’.  Certainly drinkable - but not great.
Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweet caramel aroma with light toasty notes. The flavor is toast and sweet, not overly malty with some hoppy hints. Pretty good.

The aroma is sweet and malty, much like Optimator. Appearance is rusty and cloudy. Has some underlying citrus flavor and even a little nutty perhaps. The palate is smooth and creamy. Good enough, but nothing thrilling. Optimator is better, methinks.

Pours crisp medium amber with a 2 finger coarse foamy off white head that has great retention. Aroma is nice grainy malt, a little caramel, toast, and some sweet caramel, a hint of floral and citrus hops. Flavor has lots of grainy, straw like malts, caramel, a little citrus hops and an interesting fruity -berry like- taste that comes in just as the finish comes in with a caramel sweetness and leafy hops.

Appearance: Dark brown. Clear. OK amount of white head.
Aroma: Fruit. Nice malt.
Taste: Quite sweet. Caramel and malt. Some hops.
Info: 355ml bottle, 13/11-2008, 193/300

Bottled at my favorite JPM training burger place near Wall Street. 

Spaten Oktoberfestbier is a clear golden color with a nicely formed white head. The flavor and aroma are not ver good, but full of malt with hints of alcohol. The texture is smooth and makes for a nice burger compliment.
spaten is a pretty decent lager, nice and crisp, but this marzen is very mediocre, probably not as good as Gordon Biersch Marzen. Smell very lagerish.

Flaske. Lysegul gennemsigtig øl. Sur duft som en dårlig pilsner. Smagen er en kende bedre, men stadig ikke noget at råbe hurra for. Mundfylden er tilgengæld ok, med en anelse bitterhed der redder øllen på falderebet.
12oz bottle, ’08 vintage. pours clear copper with small off white head. earthy, doughy, and toffee malt aroma. a bit toasted, caramel, and earth. light to med mouth feel. not too shabby.

Presentation: It was poured from a green 12oz bottle into a dimpled mug.

Appearance: It had a dark brunt orange amber color which is very different from the light golden Spaten Oktoberfest that I remember enjoying a few years ago. The body had good clarity and the head was thin and faded fast leaving very little head or lace.

Smell: The aroma was light and had floral hops with a slight skunk popping out though sweet caramel and candy like malt notes. (My wife noted that is was like smartees candy.)

Taste/Mouth feel: It had a sweet candy like malt flavor with some mild floral hops. Hop bitterness was very light and coved up buy the sweetness of the malt. It finishes on the sweet side with hint of grassy hops. It was about medium bodied with a smooth texture and light carbonation.

Notes: Overall it was not bad but nothing like the lighter Spaten Oktoberfest that I remember which was very good.

Bottle from Total Wine. Pours a couple-centimeter off-white head and a standard amber color. Aroma of hops and a surprisingly funky odor of skunk. This tastes just like the smell: skunky hops, toast, grains, and biscuit. Medium carbonation and thin/medium body. A decent marzen, but very one-dimensional and boring in flavor and body.

on tap at metzlers in denton tx.  poured a amber/orange with an off-white head.  going off memory(which is not very good).  aroma of malt with a little bit of earthy spices.  flavor is right on with most oktoberfests.  this did have a nice hop bitter to bring out the finish.  a decent o-fest, but not my favorite.

This was really good for a nasic Octoberfest.  Maybe one of the best I have had.  It was alot darker then most of the others out there and very very drinkable.  Perfect on its own but i would have liked to have had some food with it.

Has a medium golden color to it. Strong malt scent with hardly any hints of hops.  Has kind of a metallic scent as well.  Good malt flavor.  Has a little bite in the end, but this is overall a pretty smooth brew.  Happy to have tried it, but I probably won’t get this one again.

Draft from keg at a party. I brought my own 1 liter stein to this party just for this beer, which I knew would be present ahead of time. I was not dissapointed. The head was big and beautiful as was the dark amber color. The taste was bold from a great balance of hops and malts that left a great aftertaste. A great fest beer.

12oz Bottle poured into glass.  Thin head on top of a deep golden-brownish body.  Strong malty presence in the aroma with a hint of oranges.  The smell reminds me of Franciskanner.  Taste is similar to what you would expect with the smell; strong malt presence with an aftertaste of caramel. LIght carbonation on the palate with an oily feel.  Not the most impressive entry from Spaten, but not the runt of the litter either.

Bottle. Largish, off-white head. Clear orange body. Good lacing. Aroma has lots of cereal, oats, some caramel, and orange. Taste is sweet, with lots of cereal, a slight citrus along with an off-note (rotten orange). Soft mouthfeel, lively carbonation.

To some October means Halloween, the changing of the leaves, and the oncoming holiday season such as Thanksgiving and Christmas. To beer geeks though it can mean only one thing: Oktoberfest beers. There is the annual huge event in Germany known as Oktoberfest where beer flows freely and in vast quantities. Not to be left out of the beer festivities, Oktoberfest gatherings of all sizes can be found during its namesake month throughout the great states of America. While there are some fine American examples of traditional German Oktoberfests, today I reach beyond my borders for the heartland of Black Forests and partake of the Spaten Oktoberfest.


She poured with a huge almost 2 finger thick head rushing to the top of my glass and threatening to overflow. Thankfully there was no spillage, and soon my glass was brimming with her dark copper and dull amber-orange body. The head fades into a thin layer on top. The nose has a surprisingly large amount of freshly squeezed lemons and citric aromas. Lemon upfront with hints of bitter nuts and a dank, wet malty finish. Repeated swirls leaves massive trails of brussels lace along the sides of my glass which last from start to finish. Not one to make my Spaten Oktoberfest wait, I delve into her coppery depths and discover that despite the bright lemony and citric nose, very little is found in the palate. Instead a rather thick and chewy mouthfeel and body compliments the overwhelming wet, dank and malty flavors. I’m surprised by how heavy the mouthfeel and body of this particular Oktoberfest. While it isn’t a detriment, I wouldn’t name it as a positive attribute either. The finish is clean and doesn’t linger which definitely helps. Just a faint fringe of bready malts and caramel. I was


Overall, the Spaten Oktoberfest was alright, but not great. I have yet to be bowled over by any of Spaten’s beers to date, and they always come across as average. It might be better on draft as the Oktoberfest comes in a green bottle which lends it to skunking faster. A good interpretation of the style, but a bit too thick and unbalanced overall.

On Tap.  Nice fluffy head, rich amber brown.  Roasted malty flavors with a little bit of hops.  Smooth and a tiny hint of caramel with a light sweetness.  Decently balanced brew.  Not a bad beer, but not that exotic either.
Poured from bottle.  Can’t believe i’ve never rated this.  Malty aroma.  Clear amber, thin light tan head.  Roasty malt flavor, but more hops that I expected.  Quite drinkable.  Mellows at finish.
On tap at Nach Bar.  Nice rich brown color with great oak and cherry notes in the flavor and aroma.  Highly drinkable.

on tap at American Flatbread.  The waittress gave me this since their own marzen had kicked.  Deep reddish amber in color with a lasting off white head- very nice appearance.  Aroma of toasted malts- almost a hint of roast, caramel, fresh bread, noble hops.  Taste is balanced very well: caramel, toasted malts, light molasses sweetness with some nice noble hop flavor and bitterness.  Very clean and well rounded.  Medium bodied, I enjoyed this more than alot of other marzens I’ve had.
12 ounce bottle sampled at a party. Good sweet malt taste. Some hops barely detectable but tasty. Easy to drink would buy again

On Tap at Annie Bailey’s, Nice amber color, aroma is sweeter... much smoother then had planned... sweet aftertaste... hint of hops...usually not a fan of oktoberfest brews, but this is a solid brew....
Great amber color with a little head. Balanced hops flavor with some malty notes. Very drinkable beer, reasonably crisp and decent aftertaste.
Pours amber, nice caramel aroma, flavor is malty with a hint of spice and sweetness, slight hop finish, overall not a great Oktoberfest but drinkable
Very clear body.  Amber in color. Sweet caramel aroma. Flavor is a mixture of caramel, malts and spice. Some hop bitterness at the end but not too overpowering.  Pretty good balance.
Yeah, aroma of chlorine and malty...chlorine.  Flavor isn’t too different.  Looks very very nice, but no rewards in this Oktoberfest.  Sucks something bad, aight?
Smells like malt liquor.  Bottle pours to amber body with very thick head that holds up well.  Taste is pretty smooth.  Not sure I will have this one again, but not bad.

Nice spicy hop aroma over caramelized malts. In a ceramic mug so couldn’t really see the color. Flavor is clean malty with fairly high bitterness. Medium/light body and mouthfeel. Finish is clean and malty with touch of residual bitterness.

bottle, clear copor color, good intial head with decent retention and lacing. the initial nose is a pilsner green bottle skunk aroma, sweet malt extract comes into the picture after a longer sniff.

medium to high carbonation makes for a sharp mouth feel. taste is much like the nose. a pilsner bite with a sweet smooth maltyness, some wheat characteristics on the back palate make way to a burnt malt aftertaste.
12 oz bottle, not impressed. Pours a nice amber color, with a medium foamy off-white head. Tastes of grain with a little sweetness. Some spice and hoppiness towards the finish.
On tap, clean, crisp roasted malt flavor. Nothing crazy, but nothing exceptional.
On tap at oktoberfest in yokohama. average really sums this one up in all areas. drunk my overpriced glass quickly and moved on to  better things
bottle. pours an amber color with decent amount of head. you can definetely taste the hops. not much aftertaste. good but not great.

On tap, Deep amber color, aroma is very bready and toasty with some spiciness in the background. All malt. Tastes very balanced with the complex malts coming out. There is some sweetness, but its not over the top. This is a very nice example of the style and obviously fresh because it tastes much better than some of the bottled versions of this one I have had in the past.

Bottle at Brother Tuckers.  Dark amber color.  Aroma is a malt bomb.  Flavor, yeah its a malt bomb too.  Smooth and a bit creamy.  It goes down well, but it isn’t something that I will remember in a week.

Poured a nice amber color with a good tan head that dissipated quickly.  The aroma was mostly malty, but nothing really stood out.  The flavor was also mostly malty and starts out very sweet, with slight hopiness and some skunkiness as well.  The carbonation dies quickly and the beer finishes malty.  Overall, nothing to get excited about with this beer, its a OK O-fest, maybe there was some damage to the beers I tried from the import.
Bottle. Coopers. Nice amber pour wiht a nice white head. Aroma of malt. Very crisp but also very malty. Nice, vry good.

Great dark lager.  Grassy aroma... pours amber with a fluffy head.  Flavor is crisp and green like a good lager should taste, but with the roasted malts rounding out the flavor.  Bready flavors as well.  Nice body to this one as well.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of hops, malts, wet basement, horse blanket, skunk, and corn.  Poured copper/amber in color with a small, off-white head that disappeared immediately.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes of malts, caramel, hops, bread, herbs, and corn.  Medium body.  Thin, watery texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet, malty finish.

Poured from tap a darker-amber with small head.  Aroma is mildly spicy with something like cinnamon and anise, bready malt, and some wet cardboard.  Flavor is slightly sweet with lightly toasted bread, malt, caramel, a touch of cinnamon, and some dry hay.  Overall, I enjoyed this beer with my food, it was good.  I could drink more.

The aroma was like a bad lager, but the flavor is really nice.  A crisp, malty sweetness with a rich creamy palate. The sweetness is cut with just a touch of hops to keep it balanced, but this is all about the caramelly malt.
caramel colored pour.  Darker than I expected.  Very mild aroma, not very distinct.  Light coffee and spice taste.
Light malt flavor. Not to much to the taste though.  I wonder if this just might be a lot better when fresh?

On draft at the Asgaard in Cambridge, MA.  I think this one suffered from poor handling and poor storage.  Nice deep amber/brown color.  Head was a bit thin.  Had some funk in the aroma - again probably not the fault of the good folks at Spaten.  Some roasty and sweet malty flavors, but it was a little bit out of balance.  Made me want to hop on a plane to Munich and have the real thing!
A good Märzen. Very clear dark amber color. Bready toasted malt/hop flavor with caramel and just a hint of licorice and honey in the back. Pleasantly bitter hoppy palate.

Pours a clear, semi-dark amber, with a nice big head.  Aroma is light (wheat) but fresh.  Flavor balanced, with a bit of hops and spice, but is mainly bread and yeast.   Palate is slick and medium bodied, but finishes far too dry for my tastes.  A good, highly drinkable Marzen.

pours amber gold with a thin white head and a strong skunky grainy malt aroma.
Flavour smooth pale malt and grassy hop.
Slight herbal anise tone in the dry finish.
bottle, medium amber color with a foamy rocky head, nose is malty, flavor is oddly bitter and medicinal with some caramel, finish is exceedingly bitter also
Poured a weak yellow color with a white head. Aroma was german skunkyness and malts. Flavor was really bland, weak malts and a hint of skunk. Blah.

A decent brew on tap.  Not much to the aroma, some roasted malts.  Pour is amber with a thin white head.  Flavor is interesting of coriander, roasted malts and hops.  Palate is rather boring, smooth but lacks anything else to it.
Pours medium brown with nice thick head. Great aroma earthiness, barley, and hops. Taste matches the aroma with rich grains and malt. Where’s a big stein of this stuff on tap when you need it?

It’s a nice dark amber color with a strong flavor. I am not much on heavy beers, but I can appreciate the beer for what it is. It’s definitely a one time drinker, don’t want to go throwing a bunch of these back.

Is a nice dark copper color with a real strong malt taste to it. Wasn’t really my type of beer but could respect what it was doing. Heavy to drink, best suited for a "one and done" type of beer drinking session. Finishes semi-sweet.

2008 Bottle - Pours almost orange with a small off white head that dissipates quickly, full aroma of prunes? and grain, flavour is lightly bitter and follows through with a malty and slightly spiced finish...clean mouthfeel and fleeting presence...a decent fall brew...
Getting notebook online. Pours a beautiful amberish, full color. Has a good refreshing smooth taste. Great beer.
Pours copper with a thin white head.  Heavy malt aroma.  Nice malt flavor with a little bit of spice.  Not amazing, but a decent beer for the fall.
Extremely complex aroma. Thick chewy maltiness. Good for the special fall occasion but very thick and not exceptionally digestible.
Dark amber, Malty, sweet, smooth, caramel, hoppy, little nutty, slight spice.
Good beer, Dark amber body, with a lacy head.  the head quickly goes away.  The flavor is of slight hops, and clean, not very sweet, and not a awful left over taste.  This is a good oktoberfest beer.
Very balance flavor.  A great mix of malt and hops.  Dark amber color with quickly diminishing head.  This is my first Oktoberfest beer so I will have to update this rating once I try a few others.

Very impressive.

This beer is unlike any other Marzen I’ve had.  The hops are apparent and it gives this brew a crisp flavor.  Not sweetness at all.  Yet, its still very smooth, easy to drink and it’s color is a perfect dark amber.

Single rom Three Cellars Milweaukee.
A pretty basic Marzen. Sweet malty straigt forward.
Great.  One of my favorite Oktoberfests, just because it brings me back to a festival we have around here.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear and golden with 2 cm white bubbly head that is quickly diminishing.  Aroma of a balance between hops and malts, although no particular aromas.  Initial flavor has a bitter bite, similar to heine.  Flavor balances out at the end with some malts and eventually over taken with sweet malt.  Medium body, light carbonation, limited alcohol, limited lacing.  Overall one of the best oktoberfest beers.

Bottle.  Pours a translucent amber, copper color with very small, receding head that leaves lacing around the glass.  The aroma smells of roasted malts, caramel, honey, nuts and alcohol (at 5.9% it is slightly more prominent in the nose).  The beers flavor follows that of it’s aroma:  the toasted malts and caramel really shine up front, followed by the sweet, honey flavor, some hops and just a tinge of alcohol.  The mouthfeel of the beer is rather watery, but it helps to make the beer refreshing and drinkable.  The alcohol and hops are actually masked quite well in this brew which leaves a sweet, roasted aftertaste in the mouth.  A good example of a german oktoberfest.
Bottle.50cl. A small fart aroma, not in a good way. :) Pale golden color with out any head. medium sweetness, lightly bitter.

Pours a clear dark amber with a medium thick creamy frothy off-white head.  Lovely lightly toasted malt, sweet caramel, a bit spicy, some nuts, and a generous amount of noble hops in the aroma.   This beer doesn’t let you forget that it is German or a lager at any point.  Flavor is similar to aroma, med/light caramel toasty malt, slightly rich and nutty/vinous, with noble hops playing off ever so "German."   At 5.9% the alcohol plays a small part in the flavor however just enough to know that you’re drinking a "strong" beer.   Nice medium body, silky carbonation.
Brownish pour with healthy, foamy offwhite head.  Light malt aroma with little hop.  Smooth and a little hop bitterness.  Pretty good and excellent stylistically.
One of my favorite marzens. The flavor was outstanding and very smooth. Perfectly balanced with the hops.
(draft): Pours a brownish body.  Small white head, creamy. Malty aroma, somel acidity. Sourish almost. Dusty malty taste.
(Bottle).  Malty yeast aroma.  Dark amber color, small head.   Taste is slightly sweet, malty and caramel, with a surprisingly long malty finish and just a touch of bitter hops.  Delicious.

pours amber brown with a light off-white head. nose heavy of caramel malt, bread dough, and light fruit/ citrus. flavor is well-balanced caramel hops and floral hops. earthy, bready, caramel, coppery tinge.  aftertaste is malty, just a hint of bitterness, and draws out nicely. lightly carbonated. goes down easy making it an exceptional session beer.

One of my favorite Oktoberfests for this time of year.  A strong, malty aroma with just enough hops and perhaps even lager crispness to temper it.  The flavor is rich, malty, crisp, and assertive.  Enough hops to give it a nice noble hop character, but not to overpower the maltiness.  I definitely prefer this to the Hacker Pschorr Oktoberfest.

(German) Courtesy of AFI96, thanks Waylo !!!  Pours a dark amber color with a sm-white head. The aroma is malty with caramel, grains, and raisins. The taste is of malts, pepper, spices, and a hint of hops. This was a pretty good oktoberfest brew !!!

Bottle.  Amber pour with a creamy head and creamy body.  Malty but with a hop presence.  Slightly flowery.  Sweet, and I swear I always taste mild pumpkin bread.  Perhaps because this was my first Oktoberfest many years ago, this is the standard, even if not the best.  Very solid, though.
A crisp and refreshing lager, with color. Not much more stood out than that. I guess if you are going to drink this for an entire week, this wouldn’t do too much damage.
Aber brown color, malt flavor, caramel and grains, aroma is like flowers, good beer.

Pours a light copper color with an off white head.  Nose has a definite underlying sweetness with light hops.  Maltiness shows through on the palate.  Light caramel and bread dough.  Year after year this is a sturdy stand by.

Bottle, pilsner glass.  Amber brown body with a modest white head.  Not much head retention and only minimal lacing.  Aromas of apple cider and cellar mustiness.  Flavor principally malts, mellow cidery sweetness with a touch of caramel.  Just a touch of hops in the bittersweet finish.  Drinks very clean, but a little thin on the palate.

Bottle bought at the Utah State Store. Today college football began, we actually had a 2 minute rain ’storm’ and the Fall beers are back. Pours a light copper color with a very thick off-white head that slowly goes down. A sweet malt and hop aroma. The taste is very nice; a ton of toasted malt flavors, some caramel, biscuit and grainy flavors, sweet, but with a bitter hop finish that leans toward metallic and peppery flavors. Very clean as expected and quite quaffable. Just good beer.

Ah yes, the first Oktoberfest of the year! Nice dark amber pour with thick off white head. Big malty aroma with a slight noble hop bitterness. Taste is a wonderful balance between the malt presence and the hops. Not the best in this style, but good.

First smell was like fresh flowers beer flowers that is! Taste was great and smooth 
And no additives!

Go Grab some

Pours clear, medium amber-brown, with a thin white head, not much lacing.  Sweet, fruity, malty aroma, like rasins and apples.  Medium body, very smooth.  Crisp, well-balanced flavor, sweet, malty and caramel at first, with a nice German hop zing in the aftertaste.
Amber with a sweet malty aroma.  Smooth tasting lager that is a bit feeling.  Excellent balance of hops and malt.

12oz bottle.  Transparent tan-orange color with a quickly dissipating head.  Delicate sweet aroma. Creamy and malty with a pleasant spicy hop crispness.  Displays a lot of lighter lager characteristics, in a good way, which make it quite a drinkable Oktoberfest.  This one is a Ur-classic, pretty much dead center in the range of Oktoberfests.
Nice amber brew, semi sweet undertone with just enough hops to keep me interested. Oddly enough it’s in a green bottle. It’s a nice way to show that summer is ending.
SLightly skunky aroma, flavor is watery, slight hops, and soap. Not really what i look for in my oktoberfest. Little sweet aftertaste, but overall a bit on the light side, needs more malt!
12 oz bottle Perhaps I am spoiled but this good quality beer is in my opinion standard for the wonderful  city of Munich.

12oz green glass bottle served in a lager glass. Green glass? Seriously, why? Amber-gold in color with a thin white head. Smells of grain, spicy noble hops, and a hint of skunk piss. Firm bitterness balance by sweet malts, earthy spiciness. Pretty big flavor from a lager. Very nice, just ditch the green bottles.
Quite nice lager her. Nice maltamount and balanced viscocity with minimul biscuitocity.

Ah yes, the first Oktoberfest of the year! Nice dark amber pour with thick off white head. Big malty aroma with a slight noble hop bitterness. Taste is a wonderful balance between the malt presence and the hops. Not the best in this style, but good.

12 oz bottle from Wine Warehouse. Hazy brown-red pour with three finger head, moderate retention, low lacing. Grainy aroma with sweet caramel notes. Grainy taste with notes of very faintly roasted malts and very subtle hops. Medium body.

pors nices amber color, with malty nose & excellant clarity. flavorss is nicely balanced between malth front, with hops drying out finish nicely, clean & very long on finish, althoough oktobers are just coming available this one is so far best oktoberfest yet in ’08.

Taste 8/8 Bottle (Date?) Looks: Nice gold body with a sticky white head. Aroma: Strong. Candy yeast, spicy hop, mild malt roast. Taste: Thin bodied. Like a malty pils. Sticky and caramel malt. A little spice.

Bottle at Oktoberfest party in Bangor.  Malts and hops co-mingle well.  The beer is a flatliner it has nice base flavor to work with but goes nowhere.  That being said its a good heavy session beer.  You can stay sober by eating wurst and pretzels.

Bottle.  Poured dark gold with thick white head.  Wonderful hoppy and malty aroma.  Flavour just drops off the table with a flat ending.  Thin body and a flattish finish.  Acceptable, but a disappointment after such a fine start.
Beautiful amber-colored beer.  Roast malt tones balanced by mellow (not crisp) hop flavor.  Finishes slightly bitter and sweet.  Unique.
very clear Reddish pour with a lite lacing. Typical marzen taste with some caramel and bitters.
Not my favorite style, but good. All caramel malt flavor typical of the style. Nice balance of bitterness made this beer much more drinkable than some octoberfests. No complexity, just a simple beer.
Bottle and tap. Rocktoberfest in a bottle! Well produced on the cheep! A solid drink for holloween!
Bottled. My first Oktoberfest/Marzen ever. No real hop aroma, but had a nice sweet malt aroma. Very malty with some bittering hop and alcohol notes. Tasty. Easy to drink.
Pours amber with white head. Light fruity aroma. Sweet malty and fruity flavors. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel. A nice, easy drinking beer.
Bottle pours amber with thin white head. Aroma is sweet malt and fruit, there is good carbonation. Taste is sweet malt with little hops and sweet finish.
Pours amber with good carbonation. Frangrance malty and nutty. Clean full body with a touch of honey and hops. Very pleasant.

Bottled.  My first Oktoberfest/Marzen ever.  Pleasantly surprised by this.  No real hop aroma, but had a nice sweet malt aroma.  Very malty with some bittering hop and alcohol notes.  Tasty.  Easy to drink. Definitely will get again.

Had this the only way it should be searved, by the "Mas" or measure (liter) at Oktoberfest in Munich.
Smooth rich marzen which natural ingrediants allow it to go down very smoothly!  Proust!

On tap at the Biergarten Restaurant in Epcot, Disney World.  A dark amber with a decent sized white head in the huge 1L mug it was served in.  At first, tasted very similar to Optimator, with the dark roasted, bready malt flavor coming through.  As it warmed, it got a little fruitier and the sweet malt came out.  A good beer, but maybe not one I’d return to anytime soon.

On tap at the Biergarten Restaurant in Disney World. Sort of like Optimator Lite. Lots of sweet, bready malt notes, sort of a mixture of pale and roasted. Hops aren’t really highlighted, just there to give all that sweetness a backbone. Very nice.

Imported from Germany.
Bottled.
Malty and with a caramel flavor. Hints of hops, fruit and spices

Bottle. Poured very clear copper with a tall, frothy, off-white head that leaves light lacing. The aroma finds fruits and light spices with a malty background. The flavor has caramel malts backed with hops and hints of spices and fruits. Medium body, smooth texture, and sweet throughout. (Rating from Sept ’07)
From bottle at my momma’s house.  Sweet malty aroma, nice amber color, not much head.  Strong malt flavor with a mild hop finish.  Pretty decent for an oktoberfest.

Aroma is minor, inoffensive.
Pours amber from the green glass 12 oz. bottle with a modest head and lacings.
Flavor is sweet malts, bitter dry hops, dry finish. The abv of 5.9% is apparent.
Some in the taste.
Malts are sweet and roasted for a rich taste. It has just enough character to keep you from just swilling it. Very drinkable beer, very refreshing.
All told a great session beer if your budget would allow. Surprised that it wasn’t skunky due to the green bottle.

A beautiful beer, amber in color, superb bubbling, Nice complex aroma that reminds me of spring water, light malt,, a little spice and some good hops. The flavor is so good and balanced. I really enjoy this beer. Nice pleasing texture, good bite, and very refreshing with a clean finish.

Upon further review, this is very good.away.  It has a nice malty aroma.  A nice medium amber color.  It’s flavor is hop and malt balance, with a bit of sweetness perhaps imparted by the yeast.  Very refreshing, could drink this all night.

Wow, I like this...  Beautiful copper in color.  realy clean nose with a slightly sweet malty aroma.  Tastes clean with a slightly hoppyness and a sweet malt aftertaste.  Not flat but lively on the palate.  Overall, I think this would be great during the summer months when a porter or stout would be too heavy in the heat.  A new session beer!

This beer defines its style, so what else can be said?  A beautiful amber color with dense head, to go along with a nice balance of hops and malt.  I’ve found that this is the perfect beer for my "not beer snob"  visitors, it’s not overpowering or complex, but not weak either.  A great session beer.

Bottle poured into lager glass- poured transparent dark amber, one finger off tan head formed and stayed for a little while.  Aroma of weak malt with notes of fructose and bread.  Hits the mouth with low-medium body, malt is noticeable, elements of caramel and maple, finish is crisp with a tiny hop note.

The beer is a copper amber color, very clear, producing an inch of white foam only because of an aggressive pour. Despite that, no lacing at all. Faint caramel malt in the aroma. A smooth taste, with some caramel malt and a little breadiness, but nothing overly compelling. The finish is a little drier with a hint of floral hops. No aftertaste to speak of. Medium body, okay carbonation. An okay beer, true to the style, (after all, it defined the style, right?) but ultimately too mild for me.

Pours with a frothy, initially fat-two-finger thick, light tan colored head.  The beer is a brilliantly clear reddish amber hue and shows a bright-metallic, deeply red tinged, copper color when held up to the light.  The aroma has a mix of sweet malty notes and dry, bread-like aromatics.  Light hop notes contribute aromatics of lemon zest and faint herbal / grassy notes to the nose, but this is mostly a malt focused beer.  Lightly browned soda crackers, fresh bread-crust aromas, aromas of fresh crushed malt and a touch of sweet, lightly caramelized grain character seem to be the main focus here.  Not a bad aroma, but somehow leaves me wishing for a bit more depth.

Dry and herbal as it first hits my mouth, it quickly picks up a lightly sweet malt sweetness and a round, rustic bread like character.  Each sip finishes with a herbal hop note that gets a bit metallic and a thin malt character.  The malt sweetness while light is actually fairly rich and satiating, this balanced sweet malt character is exactly what I want to see in this style of beer, though it can be a touch too muted at times.  I like that the hop character plays a significant role here in the flavor; it provides a nice balance to the malt character all the while contributing flavors of soft lemon zest, some light herbal notes, more hay / grass than anything and also a nice, biting bitterness that is found from beginning to end.  Light enough to be quite drinkable, but the malt provides some body and texture to it that allows for the beer to stick just a bit to the palate.

A solid beer, nothing that makes me get really exited, but a nice beer that I could easily quaff a liter of.  I definitely like that malt character here, even if it could use a little boost; it provides a nice biscuit-like, browned soda cracker flavored, rustic bread crust flavor to this brew that sort of defines things for me.  Tasty and quaffable, though perhaps a wee bit forgettable.

Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson AZ
Bottle. Pours a deep amber with one finger off white foamy head. Caramel malt is about all I smell. Taste is mostly malt with just a hint of hops. Tasty, but not much to it.
Amber colored with a pretty good head.  Nice balance in there.  Slightly sweet in the aroma and in the taste.  Some spices and malts.
An absoloute delight........ALTHOUGH the hangover is insane.  Keep the asprin handy for the morning.
Brownish-amber pour from a bottle. Smell of sweet malt. Taste was also on the sweet side, but had a hint of spice.
GREAT beer, especially if you can find it on draft.  Blows Spaten lager out of the water.  Very well balanced.
nice new penny complextion,  warm malts with a nice round middle, spaten is always on the top of their craft, another beer I would take home for the hdays.  oi

Draft at Flying Saucer Nashville. Pours deep amber with an off white head. Bread and caramel aroma. Flavor of caramel, sweet bread, maple, and dark fruit. Moderate amount of residual sweetness.  Finish has a balancing spicy bitterness and some toasty grains. Transitions were a tad bumpy, but still solid.  Not as smooth and quaffable as Paulaner.
Copper color with a nice off-white head. Aromas of caramel, bread and sweet malts. Flavors of almonds, caramel and honey.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a amber/orange/copper color with small head.  Light malty aroma, with an almost metallic smell.  Dissipated with warming, could’ve been initial temperature (too cold).  Had a grain/bread taste to it, that improved as you drank more.

refreshing sllck and sweet. mild carbonation does not make this easy with many foods. light citrus and spicy clove unbalanced to my liking. but then... i am an unbalanced fool! it is a good beer in and of itself. good caramel type malt and full yeasty body while still keepng refreshment.  a touch watery feel keeps this respectable year round.
Pours (on tap) an amber color with slight head. Nice malty aroma. Not what I expected, a little bitter compared to the other Marzen’s I’ve had, not bad but not my favorite.
12oz bottle: pours light amber with minimal head, aroma of sweet malt, flavor nicly balanced with sweet malt and bitterness not very interesting but decent beer.

Nice beer....had at German resteraunt on tap. Had a nice amber color with pretty nice off-white head. Flavor was malty with a nice sweet spicyness as well. Medium carbonation.....would have again.....
Pours a nice light amber with a small off white head.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Taste is sweet malts as well.  A great Marzen.
Poured medium-golden. Aroma was mildly malty and sweet. Flavor was likewise. Decent. Not great, but definitely drinkable.
this shit is cripp! so good. 3 of these and you are way chillen. I think the alcohol content is higher than it says though. I could be wrong

this is one medium bodies brew that i truly liked. when i first tasted it it threw me for a loop. i didn’t know what to think of it cause it had a more balancing taste to it. the hops and the malt didn’t exceed each other. dang germans.
Bottled and draught.  Hazy copper colour with no head and slight carbonation.  Aroma of sweet malt and caramel.  More caramel in the flavor with a hint of bread.  Filling beer.
Sweet syrupy nose and palate.  Lots of malt, amber in color, just a smooth sweet beer.  A little hint of yeast in the finish, a nice rounded beer.

Oct. 2006 - Kind of underwhelming.  Copper colored pour with nice head.  Bready aroma.  Flavor was roasty and toasty bready with some sweet malt.  Sort of nondescript.

Oct. 2009 - I have a bit more appreciation now.  It’s as I described in 2006, but it’s a nice crisp flavorful lager with a good balance of sweet malt and toasty/bread notes.  Dry finish.  Not bad.
Not too overpowering for the Marzen amateur I am.  Tastes nice and aftertaste is tolerable.  A better Oktoberfest than most.
Pours amber with a white head.  Has a mildly sweet flavor with a bitter finish.  Its ok.
Great Marzen! Had this on tap at Teske’s Germania in San Jose. Good stuff, goes down easily. Copper colored, and the malts and hops balance well.

12oz bottle.   I had the octoberfiestbier at the source, and was interested to see the difference in the version that they export over the pond.   Trader Joe’s still has six-packs in January, so lucky me.   A darker copper brown, with a maltier and toastier aroma.   Just way more malt and body, sweet and tasty.   I wish they served this at octoberfest.   Not outrageously better, but seems much closer to the style description than the lighter version served in Munich.   (3.5) Rerate: 2008 version.   Papery, stale notes in the aroma.   Toasty caramel flavor.   Just not as tasty as I remembered.   More traditional than the beir at the fest, but not as drinkable.

old rating: 6/4/7/3/15 - 3.5

pours a clear copper with a  medium size off-white head, some lacing.

smell of grain, malts, toasted nuts, some caramel, spice.

taste is sticky, heavy on the malts, few hops, spice, grain, end is thick and just a touch bitter, with a somewhat dry mouthfeel.

Overall, too "corporate" tasting.  I have learned that for me, with German brews, the smaller the brewery the better the result.
That being said, I find this Maerzen not completely unlikeable.  It’s not my favorite style, so perhaps I’m biased. 

A color I can only describe as "fishy" leads into a nose of sawdust.  The flavors are "woody" and there is a surprisingly nice finish on the palate.  Fairly tasty overall, I do have to admit, but it’s so doggone one-dimensional that I can’t consider it more than basically average. I’m not sure if that’s a style thing or a Spaten thing.
Smells like copper, tastes boring.  Drinkable, but not out of enjoyment.  Boring.

Bottle into lager glass.  Pours  brownish-orange color with about a 1" off white head.  Dissipates after about a minute.  A pleasing malt aroma.  Drinks slightly sweet but with a hoppy bitterness that sticks around, but not unpleasantly so.  Overall, a rich flavor that is easy to enjiy.  I’ll admit a weakness for this beer as it was my first Oktoberfest--style and opened my mind to new possibilities.

Amber-orange color, very little head or carbonation at all for that matter.  Malty, sweet aroma.  Smooth, malty Oktoberfest .  Slightly oxidized, but I won’t hold that against them as I have had this beer fresh on many occasions.
I’m not sure what it is with this bottle but the taste is very metallic. I’ve had this on draft and it was great but the bottle leaves a really bad after taste.
Draft, Flying Saucer, Poured reddish brown.  Tasted sweet.  Good German beer.

On tap at the Draughthouse.  Medium gold pour, very little head.  Smell is some malt, but more yeasty than anything, although somewhat mildly so.  Taste is sweet with hint of hops and a yeasty lager like flavor.  Decent, very drinkable, but nothing remarkable.
It had a dark golden body with a very malty nose.  The flavor had a nice bitter finish.

Light copper, head disappearing quickly.  Smells mainly of malts & molasses. Rich malty flavor, not too sweet, but thicker than most.  Hops slowly, but surely dissipate the malts. Good drinking. Smooth.
I truly enjoyed this beer. Great color, very nice malty nose and wonderful caramel/toffee malt taste. All I need is a bratwurst.

Beautiful deep amber with a golden-kissed head that displays excellent retention. Rich butterscotch malt aroma, a little earthy (dry leaves?). Very smooth and dense toffee malt palate, full flavoured, sweet but not sickly, with a touch of earthy Fugglesish hoppiness in the finish. Absolutely delicious!
Red. Beery aroma. Bitter dirty initial taste taht assaults the taste buds in a bad way. Tastes like aftertaste but doesn’t have an aftertaste.

Clear dark golden color, large foamy white head and small bubbles slowing rising to the top of a good looking beer.  Deep malty aroma compliments the appearance, the slightest bit of hops sneaks into the aroma at the end.  A real medium level palate not very carbonated though.  The flavor is like the scent, heavily malted with a sprinkling of hops.  It might not be the most exciting style of beer but like the fellas in the beer tents in Munich, you can drink alot of it.  Leading this beer to the finest represantation of an octoberfest - and why not, its made exactly where the festival started.
dark amber on the pour with no head and smells mostly of malts with a tiny bit of hops in the background.  very smooth malt aftertaste but not much too brag about.

On tap and served in a tall Spaten glass.  This beer poured a dark amber with a lasting tan head.  Some light lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma was made up of toasted caramel malt, bready yeast esthers, and also some light noble hops.  The flavor stayed true to the aroma.  Your typical marzen.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a healthy amount of carbonation.  Just your run of the mill Oktoberfest.

21 OZ. BOTTLE.  Pours out a very nice old gold color. Nice malt aroma with medium head. I am drinking this beer right now and it is leaving a little lacing behind.  Very good flavor. Nicly malted with the right amount of hops, but you can taste the alcohol. As far buying german Oktoberfest beers in America this is probably one of the best.

Bottle.  I picked this up for $1.29 at a local World Market here because I’d heard of the Optimator and wanted to see what Spaten was all about.  I’m not disappointed at all.  This is a very good Oktoberfest.  I like the Paulaner better but considering its my favorite beer thus far, I’m pleased with the purchase.  Beautiful golden-amber color typical of the style with a wonderful malty aroma.  Decent lacing but a wonderful thick head although it didn’t last that long.  I didn’t mind as I was ready to indulge.  Smooth, malty flavor that makes me wish I was sitting in a beer tent with a Stein of this stuff.  Overall, a very good beer.  Highly recommended.

pours copper gold with a one finger fluffy off white head. aroma is toasted caramel pilsener malt with a little grassy hops. has a light o medium body with descent lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger. has a little dry hop aftertaste and is a little different of an Oktoberfest. not bad i guess. i would gladly take a hacker pschorr or capital over this any day though.

Pours a nice see-through amber.  Nice aroma of malts and a bit of hops.  Pretty foamy head.  Nice lacing all the way to the bottom of the glass.  Toasted malt flavor comes through.  I’m not a big fan of the Marzen style, but didn’t discover this until I had bought a case of bottles from Costco.  Good original German beer.  I have more respect for this style after trying the Goose Island Harvest Ale and Three Floyd’s Munsterfest.
Crystal clear amber body.  Strong malt, molasses aromas.  Very malty sweet and clean flavors.  Good marzen, not my favorite style.
12 oz. bottle - Pours a clear deep copper color with a one finger thick off white head.  Aroma and flavor is toasted malt and light esters.  Medium body.  A good, clean Märzen.

Shifty amber body with a strong, thick white head that remains the duration of the tasting...aroma possesses that soft, nondescript presence that allows for pleasant drinking of multiple bottles in a night...light to medium body that is short, crisp and acidic once it hits the back of the tongue...relazed carbonation allows for multiple bottles in a night...overall, after having sample nearly a dozen marzens and ’fests this fall, an original still finds its place among the many imitators...not as sweet or intense as others, but comfortable in its balance and usefulness for multiple...bottles...
in...a...night...

Beautiful copper color with off-white head (one finger). Malty aroma with notes of bread. Medium bodied palette that balances bitterness and sweetness very well. Malty with hint of roasted grain. Finishes clean. Very satisfying.
Great amber-orange crystal malty color.  Aroma is fresh.  Flavor is  well balanced hops, with some fruity overtones.  Malt is delightfully understated.  This was a pleasant surprise.
Typical amber color of a Marzen.  The aroma is malty, some alcohol notes.  Flavor also typical to a marzen, with the malts dominating.   Kind of an abrupt finish.  Decent marzen overall.
Malty smell, amber color, white head.  Sweet and malty taste, with lots of doughiness.
Draught. Light and sweet malt nose, biscuity/grassy. Golden amber, thin white head. Nice malt flavor, opens sharp and folds into a smoother and sweeter beer with lots of drinkability.
