Pours a copper amber with a two finger creamy offwhite head. The aroma is grassy noble hops with some sweet malt character. The flavor is crisp, grassy, sweet caramel, a mild malt background. Not a very powerful brew. Sessionable at least.

It pours nice with a medium thin head.  It has a sweet malty, and ever so slight caramel nose.  The color is dark and golden.  Nice lacing, but it doesn’t hang in the glass.  Medium carbonation.  The taste is also malty, sweet, medium mouthfeel, and a subtle bitter hop finish.  8/30/09 update.  Yummy!!
Tap.  Pours a golden amber with a light white head.  Aroma is malt and grain with slight hops.  Taste is the same.  Smooth, drinkable, very solid.

Golden color with a light head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with lots of cereal sugary sweetness and fresh honey bread.  Taste is sweet, sugary, and malty with just enough hop bite to keep things interesting.  Good Marzen.
I tapped a 1/2 barrel of this last night for a Halloween party and the rich grains and malt stood out in the taste. While I did note the sweetness, the overall body tasted well with pronounced hops.

bottle poured a brownish copper in color with a decent two finger head. smell is malts, spice, and light roast. taste is medium-light in body, good malts, spice, light roast, and a decent brew. drank with the German guy after the inspection.

Draught at the Schnitzelhaus in Tampa. Copper/rust colored body with a creamy, 1.5 finger thick white head. Nice lacing for the style. Nose of sweet malts, bread dough, oranges, tangerines, floral hops. Smells very nice. Not nearly as sweet as other Ofest beers I have had, and I like that. There is a nice sweetness but it’s balanced very well by the citrus and floral notes. Also has a nice grassy/earthy flavor at the back end. Creamy palate, medium bodied. Finish is medium length and semi-sweet. Probably my second favorite Ofest after Ayinger. Well done.
Good poor with nice head.  Scent can be deceiving, good taste with nice aftertaste.  Good beer to come home and have after work before dinner.
Malty sweetness mostly in aroma and flavor.  A lot of nice bready notes.  Just balanced out by the low bitterness.

the beer pours a clear pale orange color with a nice thick head to it. It has  a sweet yet pale and bland aroma of nuts and fall spices. as you drink it, the flavors are a little spicy and mildly hoppy. it leaves a nice toffee flavor on the palate.
Aroma is very skunky. Flavor is smoky and a little spicy with hoppy finish and lingering bitter aftertaste. I would rate this as a decent Oktoberfest beer but not the best I have tried.
If it wasn’t for the skunk, this would be an incredible beer, but the skunk overpowers everything.
amber pour with a grayish white head...very yeasty aroma...watery mouthfeel...malts and very light sweetness...carbonation in the finish

12 oz. with a " L15521M " bottling code. Pours a clear amber color with an off white head. Spicy gingerbread, yeasty smell. Medium bodied with a rich, creamy mouthfeel. Has a malty, bready sweet taste with a subtle Euro-hop essence to finish. Classic German. 


Oct 2004

Poured from draft at The Sanctuary (Iowa City, IA) into a conical pint glass. Color a very pleasant crisp amber. Head is minimal - this is my third beer here and maybe it’s The Sanctuary itself that is leaving me "Headless" : P. Smell is faint (perhaps also due to The Sanctuary). Smell vaguely of sweet malts. Inviting - No hops in smell. Let’s be blunt. I don’t like Marzen/Okt style beers. Very nice initial taste. Sharp roasted malts combat a small hop flavor. Balanced, but not completely. Roasted breaks way to carmelized flavor and a nice sweet undertone in the finish. Extremely enjoyable aftertaste.

Bottle... I don’t think I’m a big fan of this style.  Too mild, too much malt, and even though, in the description, they say "the perfect amount of hops," I really want more of them.  This tasted like liquified hard candy with alcohol and a metallic aftertaste.  Good looking beer though... Ruby with a great big head.
Coppery color. Yeasty, rustic smell. Balanced, creamy, and soft. Slightly sweet and malty aftertaste but totally smooth and good: easy to drink. Aroma might be its most interesting feature.

On tap at Redlefsen’s in Bristol RI on their Ocktoberfest night.  Medium amber body. Head pours big but doesn’t last long. Caramel malty aroma. Caramel malty taste with mild hoppiness. Not too bad but nothing really stands out either.

Amber in color. This medium bodied beer has achieved its impeccable taste by balancing the roasted malt flavor with the perfect amount of hops. Having a rich textured palate with an underlying sweetness true to tradition.

12 bottle poured in a glass.  This Spaten pours a golden orange with a thin head that leaves soapy lacing.  It has has the delightful German beer smell that brings back a flood of fond memories.  It has an oily body and grassy flavor.  The malts are nicely balanced and there is a hint of sweetness to keep the whole thing interesting.  This is a great beer that is easy to drink, full of flavor and is a good example of what a determined German Biermeister can accomplish.
Draft. Pours a darker amber w/a small amount of head.  Tastes lightly hoppy, maybe a little thin for my tastes, got the characteristic Spaten grasssines though.

12oz green bottle from Tiger Town in Gardiner.  Pours translucent amber-red with a slight chill haze and almost no head.  Smells like toffee and leafy European hops.  Tastes malty, with a toasty toffee character and continental hops playing a supporting role.  Not overpowering.  Very well balanced, delicate full flavor.  Medium somewhat creamy body with a fair bit of carbonation.  I am impressed.  My expectations were not high but this is one of the better octoberfestbiers I’ve had.  Not as rich as Ayinger or Paulaner, this one is still a really solid and easy to find choice.  Very drinkable.  I could easily polish off a sixer of this without thinking twice.  A new favorite!

12oz.  Delightfully German.  This really brought me back to the time I lived in Germany.  Clear amber pour, with a fleeting head.  Moderate carbonation with a very distinctly german, maerzen malt combined with a sweetness that is hard to describe, slight notes of apple on the finish.  Probably not the easiest to drink liters of, but this really is a nostalgic oktoberfest brew for me.  makes me think of impeding weihnachtsmärkt mit glühwein.
Draught. Nice dark amber color. Light head. A slight caramel aroma. Taste has a little hoppiness. Not much else going on. Nice to drink but not great.
of all the Oktoberfest brews I’ve had, this one excels by far! A very balanced flavor by a fine German brewery

Bought a case of this at Costco.  Initial skunky nose due most probably to the green bottle(why, why why green).    Minimal white head with good lacing.  Very clear copper color.  Once the skunk is gone, there is a slight malt aroma.  Kind of thin mouthfeel, but finishes quite well.  Certainly not the best Marzen I’ve had, but at less than a buck a bottle, its way better than BMC.

A nice and drinkable O/M by the country who should know how to do. I’d take a Hacker Pschorr over this any day, but this isn’t bad. Aroma of caramel and sticky malt. Pour was very dark for an O/M. Medium to dark brown with no head. Taste was a little light in the carbonation-nice caramel and malt flavor but a little light in the aftertatste. Good as most of this style.
Bottle.  I picked this up after having enjoyed Spaten Premium.  I was pleasantly suprised and would try it again.
Light amber in color with a small white head.  Spicy nose that leans toward some skunk.  The flavor is sweet and full with a medium finish that is nicely hopped.  Best Oktoberfest I’ve had so far.

On draft at Cassidy’s in downtown Portland, 10/5/07.  When I drank it I didn’t know the brewer (thought it was a local micro; had to call the restaurant to find out) but I knew it had an "authentic German" feel about it. Has that rich warming malt "feel" you expect in a German beer.  One of the more endearing flavors out there for the lager style.
Had on draft at the winking lizard. Sweet smell of roasted malts. Taste was the similar. A very decent Oktoberfest, but I like Marzen’s with a bit more interst, and this one seemed a bit boring.

Bottle.  Small off white head that quickly dissipates.  Not very leggy on the glass, and aroma isn’t anything mentionable.  Mouthfeel is a bit light, somewhat watery, but smooth.  I think it is an enjoyable oktoberfest, it is what it is... I get what I expect of the genre.  Enjoyable with some sausage. :)  A good "drinkin beer."
Not too impressed with this Octoberfest, heavy roasted malt made it somewhat distasteful.  Not one I’d choose again.

355 ml. Huge creamy and lasting head on this gold amber beer. Initial aroma is skunk (green bottle) that blows away to reveal some malty spicy goodness. Malty herbed molasses flavor with some slightly spicy cocoa in the finish. Palate is soft and light medium.
Draught. Medium amber colour with small off white head. Aroma is roasty, minor malts & stale hops. Initial taste is malty, spices, and slight bit of yeast. Finishing with a mild hops finish.
Had this one on draught in St. Charles, Illinois.  Nice, hazy deep amber color, tan head, toasty malty nose, carmel and milk chocolate throughout.  Smooth finish.  Nice work!

Bottle. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, grain, dust. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (250807)

Amber with decent white head / Weak malt nose / Light body, dry, with fair finish / Flavors of honeyed grain, pilsner-like, with a touch of burnt sugar on the finish / Possibly more in the German style, but weak compared to American Oktoberfests.
I’m not very experienced with the Oktoberfest style but this was quite tasty.  Roasty, warm & malty.  A nice standard, drinkable beer.

Pours a burnt gold color with a mild skunky nose and a nice bite of malt.  This one is a typical German Lager, its a little too carbonated, but it gets better as it warms.  There is some caramel flavor in this but everything is pretty milld. It goes down extremely smooth, and its just a well rounded marzen beer. Nothing special, but they stayed true to form on this one.  I could see myself drinking a couple of these on a fall saturday.

On draught : Pours a copper amber color, semi-clear, with finger wide offwhite head.  A spicey aroma with some malts.  Taste is malty with spices, much like th aroma.  Palate is thin to medium bodied, goes down smooth with a nice aftertaste.

No date on bottle. Pours copper color, super clear, with sub-par head. Aroma is malty and maybe a little spicy. I think it’s a bit over-carbonated. Flavor is a bit on the dry side, which is fine with me. Good malt (very light roast) as you'd expect, but not quite as rich as the best of them (e.g., Ayinger).

Pours medium amber with a small head. Aroma is a tad skunky at first but settles down pretty quick (thanks for using a green bottle). After the skunk goes away it is a nice sweet malt. Flavor is also quite malty with touches of grains and corn.
Grainy malt nose on the golden body.  Lightly malted body that went down quite smooth.

Bottle.  Body is a brownish amber and has a two finger high head when I get done pouring.  Aromas are a little on the skunky side (think Becks) but not unsettling.  Flavor is malt heavy and thin, at the same time.  The caramel and bready malt dominates the palate with the hops picking up the finish with a slightly skunky and bitter note.  Not bad, but a little thinner than my tastes would dictate.

Pours a two-finger white head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Crystal clear amber color.  Sweet malty nose.  Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is sweet but balanced, smooth, good oktoberfest.  Not skunky as some reviewers have noted. 12oz bottle $1.50 from Capitol Convenience Concord, NH.

Pours a clear amber-orange with a frothy beige head that leaves patchy lacing behind. Another green bottle. Green glass must be running at a discount, in Germany, these days. This is the third German Märzen that I’ve tried this week that has come from a green bottle. Like the other two, I wasn’t terribly surprised to find this one skunked, only not quite to the extent of its predecessors. Given time to "air out", the aroma reveals a solid nose of bready malt and little else. Medium-bodied and almost creamy with a dry, almost astringent finish. The flavor is of toasted bread, light nuttiness and a dry finish that just barely hints at earthy hops. Aside from the initial skunk, this one is pretty nice. InBev, please switch back to the brown bottle!

Draft at The Sanctuary, 9/25/07.  Copper amber with a one finger off-white head, fair retention.  Aroma of some fruity and caramel notes.  Flavor added a bid of juicy raisins, but not in the imperial stout or barley wine type of way.  They were moderately sweet and not boozy.  Minimal bitterness.  Moderate carbonation with a light to medium body.  A good Oktoberfest bier.

From a 12-oz. bottle--Poured a light to medium amber body, clear with some hues of orange in there. A medium-sized frothing white top and a nose of sweet, roasted malts and a mild spicy hoppiness.  Finished clean with residual sweetness and maltiness. Grassy with a slight Pilsner touch to it.  Very drinkable!
The beer pours mid range amber with notes of spice and hops.  The mid to light body gives a very muted note of malt and hops with a very light finish.

Green bottle pours a clear orange amber body with a modest white head. Spicy and floral hop aroma with a hint of wet cardboard. Light body feels somewhat watery. Toasty caramel malt and spicy hops taste. Not my favorite German fest bier.

On tap. Copper amber color. Light roasted malt aroma. Very Smooth, a toasty malt flavor, and German hops. Not too sweet and very balanced. Very drinkable with smooth finish with a little bite of hops, but never overly aggressive. Good beer!
A good smooth drinking well balanced malty lager.  Looks real good in a  dimple mug....really easy drinking - better than Paulaner’s version for my palate.

Bottle: Smells skunky and off-putting.  Pour is highly carbonated with a finger high head.  The taste is malt and molasses.  It was an okay beer, but I can’t get that skunky smell out of my taste buds.
Overall a good beer, drinks better warmer as it allows the sweeter flavors out. Drunk cold its really smooth but tastes more like a pilsen than a oktoberfest. Either way its a really beer.

I Love the Spaten for it’s drinkability, approachability and inexpensive tag. Oh yeah...it freakin’ tastes great! Oktoberfest beers done right are the most beautiful. This is very well balanced and not too sweet. You can have three or four in a row if you’re not careful. If you’re at a festival have more!

Tap.  Pours a brown tinged gold, with a nice off white head floating on top.  Nose is marginally malty and just smells like beer.  Flavor is clean but nothing much happening.  It is pretty underwhelming in every area, not unpleasent,  just not much to speak of.  I would pass on this in the future and this reaffirms that Oktoberfests are just not my thing.

Pours a copper color with very little white head.  Aroma of grassiness with none of the caramel and fruitiness that you expect in a Marzen.  The aroma is almost pilsner like.  Taste is grass, light caramel, sweet bread, and very light fruit.  This is almost like a marzen/pils hybrid.

has a pale amber color with small white head. light roasted malt aroma. interesting body, it’s not really light but, not really thick either, goes down easily nonetheless. lightly roasted caramel malt flavor that has a light floral spiciness to it. good flavor and easy drinking
good stuff..  well balanced.. overall impressive seasonal.  Hops and malt flavor with average palate

Rated while drinking: Pours a light amber color with a nice medium sized, white fluffy head. Heavy malt aroma with some roastiness and hints of hops. Smells tasty! Lots of malts in the flavor, tiny bit of hops near the end, and actually a bit of alcohol too. Roasty-like with a nice aftertaste. Solid. A bit bodied, with most of the mouth feel coming in near the swallow, but very drinkable. Can be a little harsh between gulps from the alcohol kicking in, but a very nice Oktoberfest.

On tap at local restaurant...a bit darker than the average Marzen.  A bit bold in flavor, there was definitely a burnt malt characteristic to this brew, but was balanced nicely by the sweetness of the drink.  Very little hops on the palate and somewhat bitter, even with its characteristic sweetness up front.  Would probably tend to try something different next time, but nothing to scoff at
bottle 12 oz. decent oktoberfest. amber color. little fizzy head quickly fades. no lacing. tad bitter for the style but a good drink overall.

On tap, 9/11/07.  Deep amber color with somewhat quick dying foam that leaves decent lacing.  Aroma is lots of Vienna malt.  Flavor is malt, malt and more malt, just a little hint of spiciness form the hops in the finish.  Very drinkable, spot on carbonation, near silky mouthfeel.  I think they have really cleaned this beer up from about 5-6 years ago when it when damn near Helles in color and flavor.  Mark that down as one thing In-Bev has managed to do right.
355 ml bottle.  Pours a clear amber with an adequate off-white head.  Sweet malty nose.  Medium body with an initial sweetness leading to a full malt body.  Nice lingering crisp finish.

Pours an autumnal reddish orange into a shaker.  Offwhite conglomerate head quickly pancakes with no lacing.  Malt aromas.  Crisp and slightly sour and vegetal with a lasting malty spice finish. Wanted to like this one more...really enjoyed the Spaten house at Octoberfest...

12 oz. bottle, poured a clear copper colorwith tight head.  Aroma of malty wet dog. Not sure why that is, but it’s not a very pleasant aroma. Malty taste with bready middle and light, crisp hoppy finish. Palate is substantial for a lager without being too heavy. This would be a great beer with some of the heavier flavored foods of the fall, beef, garlic mashed potatoes or even a caesar salad. This beer can hold it’s own without overpowering the taste of a more robust and flavorful food.

Light brown with little yellow arange glow. Airy head, small, retains. Sweet malt and pine aroma. Light warm orange like they sat in the sun on the tree. Woody but maybe not pine.Nice spice and malt taste. Little clove and allspice, some cinnimon hints. Some hop bitterness lingers. Smooth, quick, mouthfeel not much, goes down fast. Some alcohol on taste and tastes ike fall in a glass (J).

split a pitcher with some friends but kinda had to chug it being as i had t be somewhere else. looked great in the glass, nice big white head on top of amber beer. sweet caramel and malt, crisp hops finish but with some kind of a spice or herb. wish i could have really enjoyed it.

Spaten makes some pretty badass brews, this one is no exception.  Hazy pour, malty, surprisingly easy to drink.  Maybe my favorite okt.   Rerate... thought it was pretty boring actually.  Had a Heidelberg in NYC.
The sum is not quite equal to the parts.  The aroma and taste is good, but something is just lacking.  Very flat.
I’d call this one average across the board. Average taste especially...not too spicy nor dull. Slightly skunky nose.

Poured a nice orange/amber color with a decent white foam head. The nose was sweet with nutty malts as well as a light citric hop twang. The taste started with some sweet caramel and nutty notes with a distinct fruitiness throughout. The finish was dry and had a good spicy/citric hop presence. This was a pretty decent autumn beer. It wasn’t exciting in any way, but worth a try.
Yet another good Spaten product - solid malty flavor comes through with little else around it.  Miss a bit of the Bavarian character others have, but still entirely respectable beer.

Name: Spaten Octoberfest

Date: 09/11/1997

Mode: Draft

Source: Taco Mac, Cumming



dark clear amber, whispy head, slight spicy hop and sweet malt aroma, rich malt flavor with a bit of finishing bitterness

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Name: Spaten Octoberfest

Date: 10/09/2003



bitterness? hops? nothing but good sweet carmel malt flavor and aroma, the definitive and original octoberfest

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Name: Spaten Octoberfest

Date: 09/29/2006

Mode: bottle

Source: tasting



sweetness fades quite a bit once it reaches room temp but still the rich carmel malt



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 11/20

Rating: 2.9/5.0
Drinkability: 8/10

Score: **/4

On draft at the Saucer.  Pours a deep copper with a lasting off-white head.  Aroma dominated by lightly kilned malts.  Taste is sweet with caramel, balanced by noble German hops with herbal/minty character.   Very satisfying.

Notes of caramel malts and a little nuttiness in the nose. Pours amber in color. Very malt forward with flavors of caramel and a little roast followed by a sweet breadiness. Finishes crisp. A very good oktoberfest bier.

draft.  brown-orange with thin off white head.  light malt aroma.  taste is sweet mollases and malts.  palate is thinner than i expected.  a decent beer but the flavors didn’t blow me away and tended to hang in the mouth a bit.
beautiful looking beer on tap! amber and a thick fluffy head that reached past the lip. rich and smooth flavor that hangs around pleasantly down the back of my throat.

At first the aroma is a little musty when youi pop the lid on this green bottle. No wonder!  The date code is 1397, aged well!  Good clean friendly marzen.  Nice carbonation. A little darker than the regular pale yellow american lager. Lemony citrus flavors without any hop bitterness or bite. Finish is long but well behaved and agreeable. An almost tasty unique metallic palate for a few minutes. .

I couldn’t pass this one up.  Bought from my work (Party Source). We had a few six packs left over from last years Oktoberfest and so were marked down to $3.99 a six pack.  Thats an awesome price for anything from Spaten!  Also, due to the care that was taken it retained it’s freshness and I definitely couldn’t notice any signs of spoiling.  It pours with a big, rocky head.  The color is deep amber with an appealing hue. Smell of roasted malt with a sticky caramel, molasses sweetness.  The taste is smooth, toasty and has an amber ale bittersweetness.  Great Oktoberfest, absolutely definitive of the style.  After stocking up on six packs of this and drinking it for a couple weeks, it has definitely found a soft spot in my heart... and stomach.
Mini self tapping keg from the liqour store.  Pours a nice golden color with a white head.  Aroma is slightly grainy and sweet.  Flavor is crisp and smooth with a surprising maltiness.

Had this in bottle at a German restaurant in Victoria.  Didn’t realize I hadn’t given it the RB treatment.  Very good beer.  Bright dark amber colour is bang-on.  The aroma and flavour are clean and well-defined earthiness and caramel.  There’s a touch of toastiness as well.  Full body.  The finish is excellent sweet caramel and I love the way the earthy hops sneak in there as well.  The bit in the commercial description about "rich textured palate and underlying sweetness" is very apt.  This is really, really good marzen.  Now the question - if I can find it at a restaurant in Victoria, why not any bottle shop in BC?

One of the first German beers that I had. Amber in color with mild carbonation. Very hard to acquire in my region since it only around from October till about March. This is a good consistent beer always a comfort to come home to one of these.
After trying Sam Adams version I’ve had to lower the rating on this guy. Still love it but in comparrison to Sams its a bit too sweet. Can only have one of these a day (just too sweet tasting to me).
i dont care much for darfk beer but this one hit the spot. very strong full flavor

Pretty good, The bottle and labels itself looked kinda cheap.. Label was crooked on every one of the 12 in the box and didnt have the blue foil like in the pic. Skunky, tasty and good and cheap. Not bad with a good sweetness and malt/hop flavor
Bottle. Amber coloured with a slight white head. Aroma of sweet malt with a touch of caramel. Flavour also had a sweet edge with a decent bitter finish. Good.
Nice Marzen.  Bright amber, not quite orange, in color.  Nicely balanced, medium bodied, and sweetness that you’re looking for in a Marzen.  Very drinkable.

nice sweet aroma. deep copper hue. malt is sweet, bready with hints of caramel. medium body. hops are present towards the end- grassy bitterness. ever so slight. more crisp and less sticky than i expect from marzens.
Honey, toasty,and doughy.  Brown Slight hop, resinous.  Sweet, very drinkable.

Pours brownish amber with medium sized frothy white head. Aroma is bread and honey with a touch of vinousness. Clean flavor is dominated by toasty malt flavors, a hint of honey-like sweetness and muskiness along with light grassy hops and a touch of bitterness in the aftertaste. Quite a nice brew.

Bottled. Beer is dark medium-brown with a small, white, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, toasted bread crust; Hoppy with light /moderate notes of lemon zest, resinous herb; Yeasty with a trace note of dough; Light miscellaneous note of tropical fruit/peach juice.The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, warmish, lightly bittersweet, trace acidic finish.The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.Pleasant.

i suspect the bottle i bought was from last season’s oktoberfest.  Aroma was skunky.  2 finger head with a decent amount of lacing.  nice malty flavor too few hops in my opinion.  very drinkable.  i was quite worried once i smelled this but flavor was decent
Pours a deep amber into the glass with a small white head.  Great malt aroma.  Very tasty with a little malt sweetness on the finish.  Would definately buy again

Would have rated higher if it wasn’t as skunky...MAN that smell really kills Beers for me...I’m thinking it was old AND light struck it all day long for months..lol...I just don’t wanna believe Sam Adam’s version is better than this...
12oz bottle, clear auburn pour, smells and tastes of roasted malt, decent and drinkable.
Bottle.Clear amber with a white head.Caramel aroma.The flavor is sweet with a good amount of bitterness.Nice balance.Very drinkable.Good.
Bottle.  Amber pour, decent head.  I’m not usually a big fan of Marzen beers, but this one surprised me.  It was better than expected.  Kind of sweet so I couldnt drink a bunch of them.

Bottle at Oveja Negra pub, Argentina. Excellent beer.Ambar colour.  Lovely parfum aroma. Citric and flowerly.  Taste is perfect: bittersweet combination is super. Citric, bread yeast, and hops. Lovely aftertaste. Perfect.
xxx a very good brew, a good oktoberfest, not the best, but definitely one i would be happy drinking.
Bottle. Decent head with amber body. Nice aroma - perhaps some malts. I really enjoyed this Oktoberfest. Good solid brewski.

Draft...beautiful coppery color with decent white head, nice balance which is hard to describe as it is not too thick but not too thin, just right really. There’s just something good about it, and it’s refreshing right down the line.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a thin white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is very hoppy with some malt. The taste is bitter with a clean finish. a decent brew.
Really amazing beer. Great flavor! I’m surprised this beer is not as highly thought of. I enjoy it.
bottle.  Nothing special here.  A little maltyness a slight hoppiness.  A little bitter and sweet.  Feels very thin.  I’d defintely pass for the money.

Bottle sampled. Pours amber with a decent size white head. Aroma of caramel malts, lightly toasted malts, and mild traces of hops. The flavor is sweet and toasted caramel malts, and finishes somewhat dry.

Bottle.  Pours brownish-copper with a small beige head--mostly diminishing with not much lacing.  Nose is sweet: raisin... some apple.  Taste is caramel malt with a hint of hops.  Light to medium body with quite a bit of carbonation.  Mouthfeel is somewhat thin with a very subtle finish.  Not too complex, but not too flat either.

This is a very typical German marzen.  Nothing too crazy here-- just that nice balance of malt and hops.  I’ve kind of lost my interest in this st yle, but I don’t remember many others that were significantly better than the Spaten.

Bold amber appearance, a little head. The aroma is fairly mellow, kinda weak. The flavor is definitely that of a lager, but it’s also reminiscent of a brown ale. Either way, it is refreshing and crisp. The palate is smooth indeed. In general, it’s a good mild beer.

Slightly roasted malt flavor. Deep coppery color. No real head. Sweet malt flavor. Then enough hop comes up to balance the malt; almost anyway. Medium bodied, but tends to thin. Carbonation is light to medium. The hop finally gets a chance in the finish, when things finallly seem to balance. Decent drink.

Rated 9/11/06:  Typical average German Lager with a decent touch of sweet malts and some balancing hops. Skunky-sweet aroma, rather tame. Typical bronze color, didn’t get a very large head but what came about did stick around. Filling on the palate and crisp. Flavor is tame and different from most other Oktoberfests. Decent example but not grand by any means.
Draft-Ludwig’s Beer Garden in Center Philly.  Poured a nice golden yellow, slight head.  Slight aroma of hops, slight malt taste. Very drinkable, nothing outstanding still
A clear brown with light tan head.  A sweet cinnamon aroma is very pleasant.  Taste is a bit matly and watered down.  Not exactly what I was expecting and rather bland.

Brown color with a small white head.  Aroma was sweet, malty, hints of bread and earthy smells.  Initial flavour was lightly sweet with a light bitter finish.  Light tastes of malt and chocolate.  Medium body with a slightly oily palate.  G
good oktoberfest.
Draft @ Trenton Thunder AA baseball game; caramel, and roasted malt dark Oktoberfest with mild bitterness.   Weather at the game was mid-50’s, perfect weather for an O-fest.

Tap at Bohemian Hall-Beer Garden: Pours a deep bronze color, with a creamy beige head. Nice Munich malt aroma, with subtle chocolate hints. Has a great creamy texture. Nice malty flavor with subtle chocolate notes and hints of raisins. Bready chewy body. Has a slight metallic hint also. Finish has a light balancing bitterness. A decent sessionable brew.
bottle. dark copper.  nice clarity and thin head.  fruity hops, roasted malts.  lively and creamy.  malts solid but mellow as it warms.  sweet.
Nice balanced blend in the taste. This is a very dirnkable beer. Prost!!!! .
Aroma of sweet caramel and hops.  Amber pour with a white head.  Nice refreshing flavor of sweet malt, caramel, roasted grain, and hops.  Quite nice.

Appearance: Copper gold good head retention tight bead.Aroma: Lots of toasted malt. Low sulphur rich biscuity aroma
Flavour: Soft pilsner and munich malt flavour. Strong toasted not roasty character.Big dry malt flavour balanced with a fairly agressive but not dominating bitterness. Very clean, no sulphur in the flavour.
Mouthfeel: Medium light bodied and fluffy carbonation
Overall: Very toasty and clean except for some yeast sulphuriness in the nose. Good bitterness with little hop flavour or aroma. Dry toasted malt flavour dominates
Pours copper, white head.  Very nice, malts balanced with hops.  Not a lot to say, it just tastes good.
Not a bad brew, but also not the best Spaten. Pours a clear amber with a good scent of hops, i would buy again in the late weeks of September to feel as if I was in Germany

Purchased a 24 pack at Costco over the weekend to celebrate Oktoberfest. A great beer. Pours smooth with a nice head if you want it. Mouthfeel is great as the beer is very pure and the flavor is accented by mild hops and spices
On Tap at Brau Haus a local German bar in Hot Springs, Arkansas.  Amber in color, a great tasting beer, one of my favorites!

On tap.  Poured a clear copper with a decent white head.  Slightly foamy.  No real lacing to speak of.  The aroma was a mix of sweet malt, some hops and a bit of brown sugar/caramel.  If there is any spice, it’s not much.  The flavor was a less hoppy version of the Spaten Premium.  They ramped up the sweetness and backed off the hops.  Not in the same class with the Optimator and I think given the chance I’d just as soon drink the Premium.

On tap at TapWerks in OKC.  Pours copper with very little head.  The beer lines had obviously not been cleaned in a while, because there was a sourness and sharp bite to this beer.  Tapwerks needs to clean up their act - - - AND their beer lines.  They’ve ruined what is a very nice beer.
Bottle. A nice nutty malt smell with notes of molasses/sugar. Taste is slightly sweet with a decent finish. The head lasted about 10 seconds, but the carbonation was perfect for this beer.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear pale orange color with a decent layer of off white bubbles.  Sweet malts and subtle hops.  Light to medium bodied, well carbonated and smooth.  Ending is slightly sweet and lightly bready.

Bottle. Poured an amber color. Smell from pouring reminds me of Peroni due to slight skunk smell. First taste has a malt flavor. after i swallowed i could taste the hops. I liked that aspect of it. First impression, not too great. Final impression, this is a good beer.
Very rich munich malt slight sweetness and great lager like character, very little hops but great balance none the less. Great mouthfeel

This beer is almost as good as the Optimator!! with a liitle less KICK - same price $10.99 a 12 pack.. if you are looking to try Spaten for the first time....DO IT!!! you will not regret it, all the Spaten products are kick ass

The beer is a copper amber color, very clear, producing an inch of white foam only because of an aggressive pour. Despite that, no lacing at all. Faint caramel malt in the aroma.

A smooth taste, with some caramel malt and a little breadiness, but nothing overly compelling. The finish is a little drier with a hint of floral hops. No aftertaste to speak of. Medium body, okay carbonation.

An okay beer, true to the style, (after all, it defined the style, right?) but ultimately too mild for me.

Green bottle poured a clear amber with a minimal offwhite head. Aromas of carmel, bread, hint citrus and a light hint of skunk. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, sweet malt, carmel and a light hint of citrus with a crisp clean finish.

I think I expected too much from this beer, and to be honest I don’t know why.  To me, it just tastes like Spaten with some carmel/malt flavors added to it.  Not bad, but it wasn’t great either.  I enjoy just regular Spaten more than this beer, which I was dissapointed about.
One of the best Octoberfest beers I’ve tried. Nice amber color. A very distinguished German flavor to the beer.
Nice amber-brown color with a somewhat persistent white head. Fair malty flavor with a nice, refined hop finish and fairly solid body.

Great frothy, white head on this one.  Light brown pour with a strong pale malt aroma.  Rich, sticky mouthfeel.  Flavor is a bready, sweeter malt, but still with a good deal of paleness in there.  Long bite in the aftertaste.  Great German Beer!
Only had a few Oktoberfest beers, but this one had a nice crisp taste. Not too malty but just right.
Last Wednesday at Trooper Thorn’s.  This just goes to show I still don’t get the Oktoberfest style, because I really didn’t enjoy this when apparently it is pretty good.
On tap.  Golden brown appearance with a nice white head.  Aroma was mostly caramel malt.  Bitter taste that reminded me of rye malt.  Not bad.
Amber color, nice medium white head.  Solid Okterberfest for a seasonal treat.  Really strong aftertaste.
This beer resembles the color of an amber beer, has a slightly sweet aroma to it and is very tasty.  Definately a good drink.

Amber color, with a fluffy, off-white head. Nice lacing, too. Sweet, toffee aroma, and a really good, malty taste which is characteristic of this style. Slight hop flavor in the finish. Very satisfying!
Reddish Amber color with tight white head.  Tasty...thickish malt with a sweetness of pure Munchen.  Sehr Gut!  I do love Spaten.  A top choice when I’m looking for German Marzens.
Out of the bottle into a pint glass amber color. tastey oktoberfest! very well balanced bee. I would defenetly love another one of these.
MY FAVORITE MARZEN.  Amber color, bready, and great for celebrating.  This is definetly one to look forward to all year.  Thanx Munchen
Bottle Copper-colored with a nice off white head. Kind of sweet tasting as Marzen beers generally are. I like Marzen beers and to me this is one of the better ones widely available.
i liked everything about it, yet something was missing, on tap, winking lizard fairlawn, the zing wasn’t there

Bottled. Light copper with really no head at all. Maybe I had a bad bottle, but I taste yeast much more than I taste hop or malt. Either that, or I’m just a total hophead and rarely does anything else satisfy. This is better than mass produced crud beer, but certainly nothing special.

Nice crystal clear color. Kind of a light copper. The head was a creamy white. Good looking beer. Aroma is spicy hops and some grain malts. The flavor is sweeter than the aroma led me to believe. Mmm, malty sweetness, pale malts and a firm noble hop spiciness create a well rounded taste profile. Very tasty beer.

Excellent Oktoberfest. Brought back a bottle to my father from Boston, so good. Beautiful orange pour without too much of a head. Goes down malty and smooth. Truly there is exactly the right amount of hops. Very nice and balanced beer that is perfect for this time of the year.
orange under a small white head.  toasted malt aroma.  malty and smooth palate.  toasted malt and buttered bread make up the flavor.  average brew.

Bottle, malty fall aroma.  Copper colored with a good thick head.  Taste is balanced towards bitter and has a slight metallic finish and ever so slight skunkiness.  Malt is evident.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Tastes like an ancestor of American pale lagers.  Not bad overall.
Had this out of a botte. Had a decent nutty flavor. Not as much going on as you would expect from an octoberfest. Sessionable.

Had this on draft at the Bowery Bar & Grill in Franklin, WI.

I hadn’t had this beer in years, and it seemed time to try it again.  The beer certainly looks like an Oktoberfest, with white foam and a tan body.  However, foam was not very abundant and head retention was not very good.  Odor was practically non-existent.  Flavor was not very full-bodied.  Marzen/Oktoberfests seem to emphasize a maltiness that this beer just did not demonstrate.  I thought it was decidedly mediocre.  All things said, I’d prefer another Oktoberfest, such as the offering from Leinenkugel’s.

I must not have been drinking the same beer that everyone else is rating so highly. The smell, taste and finish of this all reminded me of a pale lager, similar to a Stella or a Chinese Tsingtao. Almost a skunky aroma, and the taste was more of the same. If I see it, I may try again, just to make sure I didn’t just get a bad bottle, but based on this one, I could not find too much good to say about this beer.
This beer pours a light amber with a small tan head.  The aroma is strong on the malt and spicy.  Flavors are the same.  Pretty normal for the style, but not a bad beer!  Cheers!
Very biscuity and bready, slight harvest veggies. Very drinkable, perfect body for the style. Probably the most perfect fit for the style I’ve had yet.

Had this on tap at  the Winking Lizard Tavern on 10/18/2006... Amber color with mild carbonation and a white crown. Aroma is light toffee-like malt. Flavor is caramel/toffee malt, mild, and some alcohol. The finish has some slight bitterness shining through. The mouthfeel is quite smooth.  This is a solid Oktoberfest that is very well balanced and true to the style.

22 fl oz draught, $5.30 from the Winking Lizard Tavern - Crosswoods.



9/26/2007: The color of Spaten Oktoberfest Ur-Märzen is deep golde/plage brown. It has an off-white head that is dense, foamy, and long-lasting and leaves thin lacing. This beer has a mild aroma and flavor that contain soft, slightly toasted "European" maltiness and a soft hoppiness. This beer has a medium to medium-full body and is smooth on the palate. It is a solid Oktoberfest brew.


Sample(s) from bottles shared at the September 2007 Jundale Beerklub Tasting.  Thanks!

Dark amber pour with a creamy and long lasting white head.  Light roasted malt aroma with some underlying sweetness.  Mouthfeel is robust, with caramel and wood notes.  Little bit of sourness towards the finish.  Slightly bitter finish.  Good for a fest beer.
A suprisingly great beer.  A great balance between sweetness and spice.  The flavor changes as it warms up.  Medium in body with a tan head.  Great aroma.

Perhaps someone could tell me why the hell they would take a nice German Oktoberfest and put it in the awful green bottles.  Smell and taste are light-struck/skunky, but it seems less offensive than in most lighter beers.  Flavors of straw and caramel, but mostly skunk.  Thin mouthfeel.  Very disappointing following the Hacker-Pschorr.

Single botttle from Trader Joe’s for $0.84:  Deep clear amber color with a medium white fading head. Aroma is sweet and lightly grassy. Flavor starts light honey sweet with some hop spice finishing lightly dry and bitter. Medium bodied and smooth with lively carbonation.
Draught. Clear golden colour with a large longlasting white head. Malty grassy, slightly bready aroma. Sweet malty grassy flavor with some bready hints. Malty bitter aftertaste.

Draft - Poured a dark reddish amber in color with a small whitsh head.  Relatively low carbonation.  Beer was a bit too cold, but aroma was malty with some fruity hops mixed in.  Flavor was of caramel, lightly roasted malts and medium hops.  Easy drinking... not bad.

On tap and the winking lizard cleveland: Orange gold color with a small white head. Aroma caramel, grassy hops, some spice to it as well, a bit of yeast. Flavor, caramel, some bitterness, yesty, and on the dry side. Some lingering bitterness on the finish.

Poured a rich, clear amber brown with substantial pale tan head (vigorous pour). Sweet aroma of mild hops, cloves, and bright wood of some sort.  Palate is bright, dry, and yeasty, with hops and fruits way up front. Delicious, although palate and carbonation seem a little off. Lighter than I expected.
Bottle. Nice amber to gold with clean white head.  Good lacing.  Big nose of malts with some fruit.  Nice on the tongue, and smooth flavor of hops.  Excellent balance.  Nice finish.

On tap at the Winking Lizard in downtown Cleveland - Pours amber with a big offwhite head that stays quite well and laces the sides of the glass.  Aromas of smooth caramel malts, and light toffee as well as some light orange.  Flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma.  Smooth creamy palate makes this a pretty nice Oktoberfest brew..
Amber-gold pour with a big white head.  Perfume-like aroma with light malts.  Nice crisp taste with a good balance of hops.  Bready and sweet flavors as well.  Nice, clean beer.

This one seemed a little more full bodied and complex than other Okt. I’ve had.  It showed more hops than expected in the palate and finish initially, but then as it warmed, I noticed some caramel notes, along with with the usual bread dough in the nose and the maltiness really started coming through in the palate.  Sticky sweet - nice.  One of the best I’ve had and I’ve been sampling as many as I can get my hands on.
Draught at Sharkeys, Blacksburg VA. Light amber color. Light malty aroma. Good balance, very smooth and crisp. Sweet malty flavor with some molasses notes. Great Oktoberfest.
I did get the faint asprin-like medicinal note but still like this session beer. Clean, crisp.

love it .wish the head lingereed a little longer. great with food. nice dark amber color. medium body. the malt raost is just right.doesnt get much better than this. been told this is one of the oldest octoberfest beers.

Sample at Octoberfest Tasting at Sarandys In Roscoe, IL. Pours a nice rich amber color with a minimal biege head. Aroma of malts and caramel. Taste of malt and molasses. A very well balanced brew.  This was one of the better Octoberfest brews sampled.
Over all the best Oktoberfest Beer I have had.                                                                                                                                     Nice Amber Color
Pours amber, little head. Not much aroma. Flavor is a nice sweetness with a bit of bitterness.
This is a nice easy drinking beer without anything really standing out but just a good solid session beer

One of the best marezens I have ever consumed. Pours with a ruddy amber hue, directly indicating it is going to be a solid Oktoberfest beer. The semi sweet malt flavor was nothing short of appealing. Subtle hints of orange citrus are present. This beer is most enjoyable when served around 45 to 48 degrees F.

Bottle.  This year is the first year I am trying to get into Octobers / Marzens; so I am drinking as many as possible and this has been my favorite thus far.  Dark amber color, clear and shiny - nice off white head.  Malty brew with a touch of hops on the finish. Clean, refreshing and balanced.  A very tasty beer.  I’ll come back to this one.

I really enjoy the skillful way
You beat the other girls
to the bride’s boquet

Pours a bright amber color with a fairly thick off-white head.  Sweet malty, bready aroma.  Sweet lightly roasted malt in the flavor along with some maple syrup and hop spiciness.  There’s something medicinal in the aftertaste, like the bitterness of aspirin.  Pretty good, but far from the best.

Pours a translucent amber with a creamy off white slight lacing head.  Aroma of malty grains, light citrus, toasted malts and light hop presence.  Flavor was kind of fruity, sweeter malts, some caramel.

On tap.
Pours a clear rich caramel-brown; big white foamy head sits atop and sticks around for a while. Aroma is rich bready, caramel, sweet malt, hint of grassy hops, and a bit of ever lightly toasted grain. Flavor mimics the aroma with the addition of a delightful fruity character. Medium palate with a lingering hint of hop bitterness. A fine go-to Festbier.
Hoppy aroma; dark amber color; medium bodied with hint of molasses with the bitter hops
Nice dark amber color.  Quite a bit of malt and a light molassas flavor.  Nice example of the type.
Rosy amber colour, medium creamy head.  Hoppy scent, nice palate, intense bitter malt flavour.
Draft - malty aroma, as it should be.  A beautiful looking beer.  Burnt orange to amber body with a full two fingers worth of creamy beige foam.  Flavor is also malty and sweet.  A nice Oktoberfest.

Pours walnut into the glass, deep brown with a non-retentive head and sudsy lacing.   The nose is sourdough and earth.  Roasted malts upfront, a bit dry by the hop back.   Flavors seem well-integrated, and complement one another quite well.  Finish contains remnants of nut skins, bean/legumes, and sour grains.  The mouthfeel is slick and round.  Complexities aren’t outstanding, but every aspect works well.  Good brew... great for a session.
Clear dark amber body with a large creamy off-white head. Sweet molassas and dark malt aroma. Sweet dark malt flavor, a hint of caramel and molassas and a touch of spice.

I was a nervous with the green bottle but the beer is good.  Light malty aroma with some nuts as well.  A light orange beer; initially large head that fades to a thin lace on top of the beer.  Flavor is sweet and malty, with light hops that go well with the malt rather than overpower them.  This beer is on the heavy side for the palate, and significantly better than many American attempts at this style.
tried this one at old chicago in their octoberfest tour.  minimal head and lacing, mainly a malt aroma and taste.  enjoyable but not loveable.

From a 12 oz. green bottle with no freshness date, but I know this is the fall ’06 release.

Poured a clear amber with a foamy white head with good retention, slowly settled into a thin lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Clean aromas of toasted grain, sweet malts with a little fruitiness and spicy hops.

Moderate carbonation and a crisp, slick and smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

A nice Oktoberfest taste, toasted grain with a little huskiness, a subtle fruitiness, herbal spicy hops that are very mild, a little malty sugariness in the middle and a grainy and sweet malty finish.

Not a great, but a bad Oktoberfest beer, tasty enough, good quaffability, a seasonal well worth trying.
Amber/copper translucent.  Malty carmaely aroma.  Big malty, lightly roasted, caramael, raisins, and nice spicy hops, Yum.  I love this time of the year.

Draught.  Pours golden orange with a small white head.  Aroma is sweet, bready, a little grainy, and oddly a little like cider.  Flavor is basically the same, with some caramel and just the slightest bit of aromatic hops coming in.  Decent.
Lightly burnt orange color, not much head. Faint bread aroma with hops and light caramel scent. Medium carbonation. Taste is malty, lightly bitter. Dry finish. One of my favorite beers.

Pours an orangish amber with a bit of awhite head, thinning quickly.  The aroma is a little skunked with sweet malt and a caramel subtext along with a hint of flowery/peppery hops.  The palate is about appropriate for the beer.  Average carbonation, a bit creamy, with low viscosity.  The flavors are in line with the aromas, though the skunk is a bit less aggressive.  The sweet malt has some caramel character and is balanced well by flowery/peppery hops.  The aftertaste is a bit skunked up combination of caramel lingering and the end of the hop note.  This might be better fresher, but this hasn’t been in the liquor store for long.  Oh well!

This beer has a copper- yellow color with a thin white head.  Smells sweet and malty, some strawberries or general berry fruits, faint caramel.  There was also some skunk in both the aroma and the flavor, which was difficult to overlook.  The flavor is similar with some toasty flavors, some citrus, the same malt balanced with some hops.

This is probably my favorite or very near favorite of the Oktoberfest beers. Deep amber/copper colorwith a moderate head that dissapates rather quickly. Malty, but not too sweet, with a dry hop background and finish. Quite delicious.

My first beer in this style.  Generous frothy, creamy head...dissipates quickly but leaves behind some foam and bubbles on the surface.  Mouth-watering aroma of malt, hops, and some breadiness.  Nice clear dark amber color.  Definitely a predominantly sweet and malty flavor, but hops are also present to some degree.  The mouthfeel is extra crisp and refreshing, with an extremely dry finish.  A prime autumn session brew.

Yup, green bottle.  Sweet, very malty nose, but that’s it - very simple. Initial skunk fades.  Copper-amber pour with a rich beige head.  Mild hoppy bitterness in the taste well balanced by a firm maltiness, caramel the lead flavor, faint fruitiness in the bg.  A little dark veggie / "earth."  Medium body.  Crisp with a smooth memory.  Clean and fresh, buuut......boring!

Pours dull copper w/ medium spritzy froth. Aromas of sweet malt and wet hay. Medium nectar / ample residual effers. Flavors are doughy and fruity w/ tobacco and vegetal goings ons. Slight tart on finsh w/ a light acidic bittering. Leaves an undesirable cooked malt flavor in the mouth. Overall: I am not a fan.
(Tap) Pours amber with beige head. Smooth beer. Malty notes, with hops just slightly noticeable. Rather thin mouthfeel. I’ve had better German beers.
nice malty red lager, a better version this year than last. a little dryness to keep it interesting. got this on draft at the Bodega downtown La Crosse. Who’s getting a Jager bomb
I’m usually a "hop head", but I have a soft spot for a malty/sweet Oktoberfest---as long as it can be had on a sweet deal. ($20.99/case at Costco) I enjoy this brew!

Pours copperish with a nice off white head. Aroma of sweet malts and slight hoppiness. Has a nice toasty malt sweetness with a nice balance of bitterness on the finish. One of the better Oktober fest beers I’ve had so far this year.
very nice.  a local german bar has this on tap and it’s definitely my favorite of the seemingly endless variety of spaten lagers.
On tap at Mt. Angel Oktoberfest. Very well balanced and smooth session beer. Nothing stands out, but it is smooth, sweet, and hopped just right.

A very pretty beer. Copper body with an off-white head that quickly dissipated. Nice lacing on the glass, though. Bit of a toasted and floral aroma. I can barely taste the toasted malts or the hop characteristics.  A bit thin and watery.  I’m not impressed.  Might do well with the Millcooweiser folks.

I was surprised by how dark this poured; I expected a lighter beer. A nice head and healthy lacing give way to a very drinkable and enjoyable brew. I could drink many of these and never tire of the flavor.
This beer is very well balanced. The roasted hops perfectly accent a subtle hops undertone. There’s a hint of caramel here as well.
I would love to try this on tap in Germany.
amber in color, lighter in body than what I had expected. Nice crisp taste to it (along with some spice). Goes down smooth and overall enjoyable. Decent amount of lacing and head.

Pour is a tea brown with a big white head.  Aroma is slightly malty with some breadness in there.  Nothing really stands out.  Flavor is some caramel and banana.  Again nothing really overpowers.  I’ll admit i am trying this is July and this bottle is probably from last Sept, and its is a damn green bottle so this could be better fresh.

bottle.  Aroma:  Light aroma overall.  Toasted malt and maybe a touch of hop spiciness.  Appearance:  Light amber in color bordering on dark orange.  Head was off-white and abundant.  Head dissipaed quickly, though.  Surprisingly good lacing.  Flavor:  Malt sweetness upfront, with a hint of toastiness.  Hoppiness (both flavor and bitterness) is light. Some spice and floral flavors from hops.  Nice clean finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied, with slight creaminess.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  A nice, easy to drink beer.  Was expecting a little more punch from flavor and aroma.
Dulce y con sabor a caramelo. Perfecta para refrescarse y para acompanar un piqueito. Se ve preciosa a la vista y no embota pero el sabor del caramelo se puede hacer pesado. Con una basta ;)
This has an amber body and roathy head of foam. The flavor of this beer is just not my taste..It would probably be better on tap.
Rich and deep amber pour. Plenty of spicy hop aroma. Great session beer for the occasional Munchen moment.

Amber in colour with medium carbonation. Grainy malt aromas, along with some herbal German hops. A bit of caramel in the mouth which is balanced out by both a herbal and spicy hop presence. Medium bodied with a short clean finish. I never really got the typical strong malt, bready, roasted malt Oktoberfest punch, but this is a very mellow and drinkable beer. More like a generic (yet well made) amber lager than an Oktoberfest.

Was surprised to find an Octoberfest on tap in June but a German restaurant in St. Louis, MO. offers this one.  I’m glad they did.  It offers subtle Fall flavors.  Some pumpkin and coriander can be found.  Nice beer.

12oz bottle from lee’s liquor: aroma of dark malt, but pleasant.  very proper oktoberfest color, with great flavor as well.. but still lacking something.  perhaps because the bottle i have is long expired.  leaves a very nice aftertaste which is not the same as the taste.  something almost fruity about it but not quite.  still excellent brew.

Poured like ginger ale, phony carbonation, off yellow color with almost a green tint. Aroma was malty, grassy, caramel, and some skunk. Flavor was much of the same, sweetness accompanied by some level of spicing. The "balance" of hops may have been there, but as soon as it gets a bit grassy, I’m not into hop balance, especially within this style.

ad this at the Taste of Cinci over Memorial Day weekend. This was a pleasant suprise. I wanted the optimator but it was like 92 degrees outside and my dad wanted try it and i thought a darker beer was a bad idea. Overall very tasty and I would probably try this again.

What a great beer!! I’ve quaffed a few Spaten products in my time, and the Optimator is one of the beers that started me down the path of beer nerdiness. At any rate, I’ve popped this one open and here it goes! Aroma is malty sweet with a strong caramel tone. HUGE head comes pouring forth from the glass. Mouthfeel is soft and lively, not harsh at all but soft and medium-bodied. The taste is an incredible balance of hops and malt with a slight roastyness and caramel that is a delight going down. I’ve yet to have a Spaten product not deliver. They are like Unibroue, only with lesser products.....and in Germany.

Bottle 42F Lager Glass.  Aroma is sharp, and aspartic, larger yeast aroma, very light notes of barly.  Bottle provided a large billowy white head that lasted for quite some time.  Pours a very light amber color and very clean and clear, moderate to low lacing.  Tastes rather light, with a slightly bitter finish, that is semi dry.  Just mild notes of sweetness and a slight tanginess.  Semi aspartic.  Good amounts of carbonation, provides a nice mouthfeel but not too large.  Quite drinkable, too be enjoyed in the cooling weather of autumn.
Gold appearance- almost no head -nose is honey, caddied fruit and ending with skunk- banana, sour bubble gum- a little oily – sweet skunk aftertaste
On tap, amber in color with thin white head.  Nice balance of flavor with malt middle and light hop ending.  Medium body, decent lacing.
Your run-of-the-mill decent Amber.  It is a very balanced beer, not a heavy flavor... a nice spring/summer beer that is refreshing and can be drank in large quantities.  Not bad.

Had an average head.had a yeasty,grapefruit aroma.color clear brown.No dead yeast sediment.flavor.Barley hops and malt influenced.mainly malt.slightly sour.nutty.medium bodied beer.good beer.might buy again.
Bottle. Pours amber with a decent sized white head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, and slight hops. Flavor is sweet up-front, caramel, slight hoppy bitter finish. Good body decent brew.

Nice amber color present with a medium whiteish head.  Flavor is malty with hops, plum, brown sugar, and spices.  A bit sweet for my liking.  Other than that, a balanced brew that can challenge the palate.

Had this sitting in the fridge since, well, the last oktoberfest time ish and now I am trying to thin my reserves out so this is what I had to drink. Overall it is pretty much just a marzen with all the standard nothing too exciting about it. Id say that if I were to drink an oktoberfest again it would be one that I would do, but in the middle of spring it just doesnt do anything for me.

From Bottle.  Transparant, honey amber pour with a nice, tall off-white head.  Lightly roasted malty nose with a hint of summer squash and a touch of nutmeg.  Thin, slightly watery mouthfeel with a sweet brown sugar flavor with a hint of stewed tomatoes.  Simple, clean finish with a mildly sweet maple syrup smack.
bottle :  Poured nice amber color with hints of pumkin/nutty aroma.  Taste is increadbly smouth with light bitterness

This is a kick ass beer.  It really rules.  It had a good smoothness mixed with a biting carbonaton, it was crisp, like a head of lettuce.  I could forsee drinking 1000000000 of these in a night, not getting tired of it, just geting wasted.  And I picked it up for 3.99/six pack.  I rule so much.
Great example of an Oktoberfest.  Pours a rich orange/amber color.  Flavor is malty with hints of pumpkin with a desirable  hoppy bite finish.
Clear medium red-amber with a tall beige head that laces the glass as it recedes. Malty aroma with a sweet malty-nut taste and a little bitterness from the hops coming through in the aftertaste.
Clear amber with a fluffy head. Malty caramel with a touch of hop bitterness.
Poured an amber brown, with thick white head.  Flavor and aroma taste somewhat stale, still good maltiness and spice flavor.  Very clean while being full bodied.

Bottled.  Pours a clear copper with a bright, ivory colored head.  Lager-like yeast aroma with a bit of sweetness.  Bland flavor with a bit of maltiness.  Lingering dry aftertaste that has a watermelon note to it.  Not a bad beer.
Bottle.  Poured a reddish-amber with a light fluffy short-lived head.  Aroma is tomato juice and pumpkins.  Tastes like fermented V8.  Good Oktoberfest although that’s not my favorite.
Bottle. Poured a nice orange amber color with a nice white head.  Clean drinking beer.  A very nice Oktoberfest.  I would drink this again and again.

I had this beer back in ’04 from a local liquor store and was delightly suprised.  I recently picked up a case at the same liquor store a week ago for a mere $14.99 (yes, a case), because they were trying to liquidate it since the season is over.  Even at the regular $7-$8 a sixer, it is still a worthy Oktoberfest from the land of the Oktoberfest.
Delicous.  Reddish brown color, tan head, very creamy texture, finishes strong with a malty flavor, one of the finest octoberfest beers i have ever had. was a great find.

What is marzen as a beer style? Marzen is a reddish to deep amber, malt accented, hearty brew, that was traditionally brewed in March, and consumed in the Fall. Wild yeasts would reek havoc with brewers yeast centuries ago, the conditions, and state of brewing beer, at the time, made it impossible for German brewers to brew in the summer months. So they would brew huge batches of beer in March(which is Marzen in German), lager (the German word for store), these huge batches in cold caves, containing natural ice, in the Bavarian Alps. Spaten was the first brewery to do this beer style, UR meaning original. 

So why go with the Germans? The reason is simple, a step in the brewing process, called decoction. All the German brewers of marzen use this step, and in my opinion, it is a vital one. It gives marzen its signature malt character. Decoction is a process where a portion of the mash is taken from the mash tun, heated to a higher temperature in another vessel, and returned to the mash tun. This step gives marzen very deep, toasty and nutty malt flavors that are the soul of this beer style. Some will argue that these flavors can be achieved through the use of special malts, but I have to disagree. That is why I think the German examples of marzen are by far my favorites, and the best examples. There are domestic breweries that do take this extra step, and their beers rival the Germans. Breweries like Old Dominion, and Victory use the decoction method, and you can really taste the results in their versions of marzen. 

Other domestic breweries choose not to, and you can tell. That is not to say that these versions are not, delicious, hearty lagers, or excellent brews. They just are not the best examples of marzen. Some breweries feel the need to put an Octoberfest beer out, but do not even bother to use a lager yeast strain. Breweries such as Harpoon, and Otter Creek make Octoberfest "ales". I fail to see the point of these beers, and I really think they should be avoided if you are looking for a true marzen. In fact, if you check my reviews from September and October of last year, you will see I did a series of reviews on marzen/Oktoberfest beer. 

Spaten UR Marzen, the original, and the one marzen I believe you should start with, pours to a deep amber color with a thick white head, and a moderated amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is very malt accented, with aromas of sweet malt paired with toasty and nutty aromas. The palate is firm with more good malt character with lots of toasty and nutty flavors. This beer finishes malty up front with a nice bit of hop bitterness to balance this beer. Spaten UR Marzen is not at all cloying, it is a delicious, hearty lager that is smooth, drinkable, and has plenty of great malt flavor. Again, these signature deep malt flavors come from that extra step, decoction. This beer matches perfect with spanfekel(spit roasted) pork or chicken dishes, sauerbraten, and of course grilled bratwurst. Enjoy this beer, and this great beer style during the Oktoberfest season and beyond.
"Poured a nice orange/amber color. Huge fluffy head. Aroma was of malts and some citrus hops. Flavor was a little to yeasty for my taste in a fest beer. Overall a good beer."

Old notes from a bottle from Octoberfest last year.  Medium to dark coppery color with a present but not large head.  Big caramel malty aromas and flavors, and a bit fruity.  Almost fruit juicy, which didn’t strike me as wonderful.  Decent.
Dark golden color, with a great head.  Ok lacing on the glass.  Fruity taste, seemed just right.  Not very bitter ( a plus for me)  Clean finish.  i wanted a second.

Good color, translucent and murkey mahogany color. Nice, hazel/creme head with light lacing. Aroma is rich with the smell of cherries, oats, rasins, pecans, peaches, and bananas. Flavor is fruity and woody, low bitterness. Nice full, but not thick, plate and velvety feeling after dinsih with a nutty, sweet aftertaste.
Nice copper color with a thin head.  Not much aroma.  Taste is big on malts, but has a decent balance with hops.  Not a favorite, but for casual drinking-a fine choice.

bottle - Nice.  Big malty character as one might expect from this style.  The finish betrays some hops, which gives a good balance.  I heartily approve and would be glad to raise a toast to the autumn with this very drinkable brew.
12oz bottle-pours a foamy off white head, nice appearance: copper color. Aroma is malty, backed up by a bit of hops.  Good flavor and balanced, nice sweetness.
Clear amber body with a small head. Aroma is typical for style with malt domination = carmel with hints of earth and grassy hops. Typical for the style but enjoyable.
Pours a clear amber with a nice big  head. Sweet wth lots of malt aromas. Some caramel. Creamy fullness.
Pours a medium golden orange color.  Aromas of roast malts, caramel, and some hops.  Flavors of sweet malt, wheat bread and some nice hopping.

Bottle-Unusal, the aroma was well, off.  However the rest was wonderful, pours a light brown with a small/medium head and light carbonation.  There was a small amount of lacing on the glass too.  The taste was slight roast with caramel.  The beer was better and better as I traveled down the glass.  asheville wine, 1.30

From bottle. Nice appearance: copper color with excellent head, good legs. Not much aroma, slightly wet-raggish. Good flavor and balance, though perhaps somewhat hopper than the style demands. Good stuff.

Still have a soft spot for this. Always reminds me of football and autumn weather, great session for that time. Brilliant copper, off-white rocky head, great lacing. Nice bready, toast, faint caramel notes, herbal hop background. Flavor just as aroma suggests. Medium to high carbonation/mouthfeel.

Pours amber-red with a large, off-white head. Sparse but long-lasting effervescence. Aroma of smoke, toffee, caramel, and, oddly enough, a little bit of plastic. Smokier than most Oktoberfests I’ve had. Decent malt flavor, but you can taste that damned plastic, and it’s even worse than the metallic taste of some Fests.

Poured a small tan head that faded quickly, little lace. Clear, light chestnut colored brew. Lightly sweet malt nose, grainy, faint. Light/medium body. Medium sweet malt flavors, caramelly, nutty and lightly bready. Maybe a touch of hop there? Finish is quick, lightly sweet. A ho hummer.
Light amber with a big white head. Aroma is kind of skunky with a little malt smell. Sweet flavor with a decent malt body. Some hops towards the finish. This beer is too sweet with not enough malt.
Amber with a nice two finger standing head.  Aroma is of wonderful full malt.  Taste is sweet with a bit of emphasis on the hops in the finish.  I detect no roasted character.
Great fall beer.  Nice sweet taste that gets better as you drink.  Much better on tap than in a bottle -- although, the bottle isnt bad either!  No harsh smells and a fine after taste.

bottel.  Poured dark tan with a thick long lasting head.  Aroma was decent but predominated by alcohol.  Flavor was good but again, alcohol came through towards the finish.  Exhibits the bright, somewhat fruity flavors typical to the style.  Not bad but not great.

A nice, rocky head formed over a clear, orange/copper body. Aromas were musty, bready & herbal, with light spiciness, leaning towards the aroma of many European Pilsners I’ve had recently. Flavor is sweetly malted with a dry finish, but rather... "blah." Purchase Paulaner for traditional Märzen enjoyment, and Avery for over-the-top Oktoberfest splendor.


500ml bottle purchased at Sal’s Beverage World, Elmhurst, IL

A nice copper body with a good head, evaporated fairly quicly.  A sweet taste of caramel with a great finish.  I have found it to be much better off tap than out of a bottle.

A great beer with wiener schnitzel, or brautwurst.

on tap at Bier Stube in Moline.  great looking copper in color with a small off-white head.  served at cellar temp. this had a smooth toasty aroma and flavor.  nothing special, but still a solid easy drinking marzen.

Huge layer of fine off-white head that settles in lumpy tops, and leaves sticky tons of looking lace. Bright copper body. Yeah, this is purdy beer. Herbal hops, warm toasty malt. Soft carbonation, eathy, bready, understated hop bitterness. Clean, medium light palate. A beer that doesn’t demand too much spotlight. Solid, well-made, but not a beer to ponder.
Pours with a good head that evaporates fairly quickly.  Somewhat sweet but well balanced and very drinkable.  Underwhelming aroma.  Poured from a bottle in Illinois.
Nice floral smell, very little head but lots of co2. Carmel flavor, somewhat malty and sweet. I would buy again.

I haven’t rated for a while, since I returned to Panama, the land of lousy beer.   However, the Riba Smith grocery seems to have the best selection of beer in the country.  So, I’ll have three new beers to rate this week...

I drank the Oktoberfest from the bottle, but poured a bit for appearance.  A creamy head dissipated quickly and left an amber beer.  The aroma is heavy of carmelized malt and banana yeast. On the palette is is VERY sweet, with the malt taking over and little hop presence.  That being said, it blows away the corn-mash bombs that people drink here in Panama, so I am happy, but I am hoping that the other Spaten offering is better. Bottom line: I’ll buy again in Panama, but not in the US.
Bright copper color. No head. High carbonation. Sour smell. Tastes of hops and malt but little else. A decent German beer. Unfortunately I’m not much of a fan of German beer.

Bottle in Florida. Clear copper color with an average creamy white head tha was lasting. Average sweet roasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Moderate bitter sweet flavor with an average finish. Above average oktoberfest.

Amber color with a nice off white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of malt with just a touch of floral hop.  Flavor is sweet malt, but not overly so.  Llittle hop bitterness.  Very good example of the style.

Mild brown pour descent head.  Simple octoberfest brew, slight hop, malt, skunked but just slightly.  Something to drink in a situation you are going to be doing a lot of drinking, it goes down similar to bmc.

Great floral nose, great appearance of deep clear brilliant amber with a huge foamy tan head.  First thought was that taste was thin and simple, mouth was thin.  Overall just not especially interesting.  Let it warm up even a couple of degrees, though, and the sweet malt comes through, balanced by floral hops and a long bitter finish.
Good deep amber color, but almost sweet from the maltiness.  2 more of these and a headache would have certianly ensued.

Bottle:
Aroma smells nice, malty, sweet with some spiciness to it.  Has a darker amber color and a nice frothy off-white head.  The flavors was sweet malts, spices, a touch of hops, a pretty standard oktoberfest (not saying its average but a good fit).

Clear amber, whitish head. A little malt aroma. Slightly fizzy, and a little thinner feeling than I would prefer. Malty base, with a faint hop spicness noted, and a little bitter in the finish. Pleasant, drinkable, just a little less body and flavor than I would like.

Re-rated 9/24/07 Noticeably better body and mouthfeel. Nice rich caramel flavor, with very light bittering at the finish, although the finish is not by any means dry. I liked this better this time.

Poured a lt orange with a large head that diminished in a few minutes.  Lacy hints on the glass.  Sweet and malty aroma and flavor.  Long, sweet finish.  A good Marzen, but not the same beer that is served at Oktoberfest

smell is carmelly in this light brown brew.  taste is mellow and smooth, with just hints of skunk creeping in at times(green bottle).  this is well balanced with a small bit of roastiness.  quaffable, but that is really most of what it has going for it.
Draught at the Federal in Durham, NC. Clear amber color with thin off white head. Spicy, caramel nose and flavor. Full bodied, moderately carbonated. Good representative of the style.
golden hue w/ huge off white head. strainght forward oktoberfest..., decent.
Pours a nice brown with small white head.  Malty.  Hints of maple.  Medium bodied.  A little too much carbonation for my taste.  Slightly bitter, then sweet finish.

Amber in color with a nice head.  Nice aroma, with a good hoppy character.  Flavor is full of hops and slightly sweet.  Relatively light beer.  Rests nicely on the palate because the hops just seem to sit there and linger for a minute or two.  Give it a try.

This is truly a world class beer from some world class guys.  I think the Spaten people do a fantastic job with all of their beers, this one especially.  Each year it is a little different, and has been too pale in the past for my taste, but 2005 is perfect (so was 2004)  A malty nose and the perfect crystal clear amber color are topped with a creamy lasting white head.  The mouthfeel is laden with texture and a slight chewiness for such a light beer.  The finish is long and malty, reminding me of the smell of the mash on brew day on the back porch.  This goes down too easily, I drank at least 4 half lites at my local German restaurant a few weeks back.
Although more flavorful to me than the original Spaten, I like the crispness of the original better.
I like this one better from the tap, but the bottle is nice too.  Also goes well with a cigar on the porch on a cool, clear fall night.
light brown small white head light carmel malt aroma hints of some spice even well coated palate.. flvr light yeast & carmel fairly blah.. ok beer.

12oz Bottle - pours a clear but very deep amber/copper color, with a two finger head. The head disapated to a topping only, rather quickly, however, the lacing was nice and lasted all the way down. The aroma was on the sweet side, mostly malts with a tiny bit of hop. The flavors were mostly sweet with spicy nuances. Mouthfeel is light and not very rich. This is an easy drinking beer, very pleasant but a bit too light for my taste.
Malty, but has enough hops to make it a great beer for me, flavor is rich. I like paulaner better, but this is good too.

Drinking this beer makes me wish I was atthe real Oktoberfest.
A wonderful assortment of malts with uplifting caramel and medium sweetness, the bouquet is one of lightly toast malts. Its been a good year for marzen
Sample at Decatur Beer Fest.  Amber in color.  Malty and sweet taste.  Rich textured beer.

Light brown and  flat in appearance; clear pour- looks like apple juice.  Malty aroma with hints of cinnamon.  Similar taste with moderate sweetness and malt.  Syrupy finish.  More lively than other Oktoberfest I’ve had.

Sweet malty and some nut aromas. Darker gold/ amber body with decent white head. Texure was good not to sweet, not too bitter, and mils spice. Left a sticky sweet aftertaste almost like those fruit rollups. My brother bought a sixer so I had to have one.
Minimal head and aroma, slightly sweet.  Pretty deep copper color.  Medium body with light malty taste.  Drinkable, but for an Octoberfest I prefer Ayinger much more.

Beautiful reddish-golden color, adequate head. Fruity, sweet flavor, but doesn’t take away from the malts. Hops are there, but not in the foreground. I bought a 6-pack of this stuff, and I have no regrets.

Pre-gaming for the World Beer Fest?  Is it possible?   Yes, my friends.  Yes it is.  Say sayonara to non-tastey beer.  Sayonara.  I am no familiar with this style at all but it seems really solid.  Very good.  Not a whole lot of hops.  Medium bodied, not a whole lot happening on the palate, but some really nice malt character.

It’s no wonder this is called Oktoberfest. This concoction pours out and settles into a deep woodstained hue, beautifully golden and ruddy. It’s crisp taste is cool and refreshing. It has a very smooth, slightly bitter taste that glides in and out with each sip. It could be very well be the perfect rendition of Fall in a liquid form. At any rate, is it a good drinking companion to accompany the season.

sweet full bodied taste, light hoppiness, clean finish

made me want another one

the FINEST GERMAN MARZEN OUT THERE
Bitter smell with a hint of sweetness.  Pours dark yellow, thick white head.  Spices, bitter,  malty.  Hoppy finish.  Smooth, nothing unusual for the style.
i will have to try more of this style beer  i wasn’t very impressed by this beer, but i didn’t expect that much......kind of bland, but definately drinkable
Spaten has a slight malty aroma and is amber with a off white head.  The flavor is light with a malty beginning and a very slight bitter finish.
12 oz bottle.  Amber color with a big foamy off white head.  Classic Oktoberfest flavors and aromas.  Very malty and a little bit of sweetness.  Hops is barely noticeable.  Not too bad.

Bottle. Pours an amber red with a fairly small off-white head. It was surprisingly flat with a medium body. Fairly malty, roasty, and a little hoppy. I expected a more substantial flavor, but since this is my first Oktoberfest style beer, perhaps my expectations were unrealistic. Overall, decent. Pleasant to drink and fairly thirst quenching.

Amber pour with a nice orange tint and a solid layer of rather well-retained off-white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma had a healthy dose of skunk.. likely from the bad marriage of light and green glass :(  Nose also picked up some sweet roasted caramel underneath.  Nice and smooth mouthfeel & medium-bodied.  Flavor picked up the smooth caramel and a nice complement of noble hops.  Decent brew.. I’d like to have it on tap.
