Bottle. Amber with a minimal head. Fairly sweet, clean, dry finish. Mostly devoid of toasty toffee flavors that were present in the Hacker-Pschorr or Paulaner, which I enjoy in those better choice beers.

On tap at the Firkin, Libertyville, IL.  Large white head with excellent lacing. Dark amber color with a clean hop aroma. No discernable carbonation.  Medium bodied with a smooth creamy texture that starts with slightly sweet malt note and finshes dry with slight bitterness.  An enjoyable Oktoberfest beer.

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a lighter amber with little head. Nice malty aroma, with a medium body and a clean aftertaste.  This was a very smooth beer for a Marzen, and was extremely enjoyable, but could use just a little more flavor.

Bottle: This German classic pours a clear amber with minimal head.  I poured it too cold and at first it had a metallic aroma.  But as it warmed up, sweet malts seemed to dominate.  The tastes were similarly sweet, that of sweet spices and fermented, autumn leaves.  It has  a nice full body and is pleasant to drink.  The downer about this one is that I wished it had more flavor.  The appearance and palate were great, but missing something on the flavor.

Poured a light amber color. The taste was weak for a Marzen-style beer. No noticably flavor. It drank like a normal lager beer. FLAT from a German brewery! If Germany is Oktoberfest..this is rotten Kraut!! DU HAUST!!

Amber body, white head. Not too great to look at. Aroma is...soap, wheat, fall leaves, faint spice. Decent. Taste is really good, especially balanced with excellent malt, a little spicy, caramel, fresh vegetable like hops, clay. Nice beer. Warm aftertaste, needly hops. Thanks to Jer for picking this one up at Norms in Vienna. Excellent fall beer.

Bottle: Clear light-medium colored amber bodyshining a muddled orange when held to the light.  The head is a nice looking medium white head, but it quickly dies to a small ring around the outside of the glass that DOES stick around for the duration of my tasting.  The aroma is lightly peppery caramel, cold weak yeast scent, toast, light dough, and barely perceptable floral hops.  The flavor is a mix of near-impercievable grassy hops, toffee, and a tiny hint of either cooked vegitable or grains (it’s so subtle that it makes it difficult to pick out the flavors).  Then comes a hint of biscuit, grains, and a fleeting grassy hops flavor.  Finishes sweet with notes of light grassy hops and mild toffee.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation (bubbles feel large on the tongue).

09.17.05  Tap at Andy’s.  Hard to judge color because of opaque mug, but has a lasting, even head of medium-sized, white bubbles.  Aroma is not as bold as I expect in a marzen, rather subtle, toasty, peppery, lightly floral.  It’s a mild flavor, too, and not as dry as I’d hoped.  Light pretzel, touches of peppery lager yeastiness.  Smooth feeling, medium body is coating across the middle, but dry to finish.  I’m glad I got a tap version rather than a bottle as there was no evidence of damaging oxidation.

Bottle. Light amber color with quickly fading head. This is very coppery; smells like a penny, tastes like a penny. Not really offensive, but fairly one-dimensional. Some faint aromas of light toasty grain lurk beneath the copper, and a mild nuttiness comes through sightly in the flavor. Aftertaste is like having a penny in your mouth. This beer is saved by a well-balanced carbonation and decent medium body.

Hallo. Guten tag. Ich werde dieses Bier einschätzen. Ich habe ein Deutsch in der Schule genommen. Aroma is faint, but there is some malt and maybe a dash of alcohol and hops intermingling. Tea colored with a thin head. Very lager like fore followed by some caramel malt and a fizzy pale lager finish. Maybe it is the original, but that just prove that the first attempt isn’t always the best.

So far, this is my favorite Marzen style. It has a terrific flavor compared to any imported or local Marzen I’ve tried. The Hacker-Pschorr Marzen comes close, but I find the flavor of the Spaten to be more bold.

This goes very well with grilled food and is enjoyable with pizza and meats in general.
On tap at Old Chicago.  Malty aroma.  Red in color.  Taste is bready, caramel and toffee.  Needs just a tad more hops, but otherwise a very good brew.
Enjoyable beer, malty and now the marzen makes sense. I plan to try this again, then I’ll rate better.  on tap @ saucer

Bottle.  Pours bronze with a tall foamy light brown head and lined spotty lacing throughout.  Sour yeast (sweat) and light roasted caramel malt (grain, straw) aroma with faint fruit notes (pear, apple).  Sweet yeasty flavor and acidic caramel malt body that has fruity notes.  Medium bodied fizzy palate with a dry finish.  Very drinkable.

Rate Blind. October 2013. 12oz Bottle. Coppery glare. Pilsner malt nose, inflected with a bit of bread yeast and cut green grass. Flavors drop off quickly after an initial warm blast of mineral and cracker. The alcohol is prominently noticeable in this and there’s a lack of developed malt flavor that I expect. Dry and hot. Tiny notes of darker malts prickle in the back of the throat. Clean and okay, but not my favorite example. 




9/16/2005. Clear burnt amber pour, topped with a frothy crystal white head. Slightly tart, lemony malt aroma. The tangy distinctive malty rich flavor  of an Oktoberfest is the true harbinger of fall for me. I love it (fall that is). This is my first autumn as a ratebeerian, so this is my first rated Oktoberfest and it could use a little more. Some fruity hexane notes. But, this beer gets a few nostalgia tenths for being my first Oktoberfest of the season. Palate is smooth, sugary and lingering. 6/2/8/3/15

Perhaps not the best Oktoberfest out there, but it may be the best looking.  Most of my beer glasses being on stand-by in the dishwasher, I poured the bottle into a hefeweizen glass.  It filled it nicely, a deep amber color, well carbonated, with a thick creamy head.  I looked at it quite a while before eventually smelling it. Rich, sweet malts with a gentle floral hopping.  It was creamy in the mouth and fun to swish around for a score of seconds before swallowing.  The flavor is a bready, caramel and toffee malt with a light hop bitterness, straight arrow and simple, but quite tasty.  It finishes on the malt sweetness with a modest hop bitterness.  Not the best, but it shore iz purdy.

Sal’s Beverage World, Elmhurst, IL
Good aroma which quickly falls with the head.  Hops and malt are very well balanced.  Crisp and bubbly.  Slight spicy notes and hints of toasty caramel.  Weak flavor, but what’s there is good.

fresh for 2005.  nice aroma with flavor hops.  lighlty bitter, followed by major top end flavor hops, then good strong malty middle, light aromatic finish.  tilted toward the hoppy end of marzens, malt is plainly obvious, but not the star. good fest.
Good & solid entry for the style.  Slightly sweetish roasted malt flavoring with a fair balanced hop presence.  Not too syrupy, sweet or heavy.  Amber copper hues; emminently drinkable.
Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells of toffee and caramel with some light spicey notes.  Taste is somewhat spicey and bland.  Godd for a session beer, but that’s about it.
Light caramel brange brown color.  First taste is malty caramel with hops kicking in at a low balanced level.  Very smooth drinkable  beer.

It’s the color of fall, the orange of a leaf depleted of its chlorophyll.  But autumnal leaves don’t taste like this.  Heavy caramel malt profile makes this brew quite sweet.  Absent any heavy hop-bitterness this really finishes quite smooth.  Quite chewy on the palate.  This was an excellent part of my German dinner of schnitzel, spaetzle, and red cabbage.

Enjoyable octoberfest.  Sweet (too sweet?)  malt profile with the emphasis on caramel/toffee.  Very mild bitterness in the finish.  Sweet worty aroma is interesting and unusual.  My sample was on tap and it seemed a little flat.  Aren’t these supposed to be more lively?

This is a really good beer. The aroma is toasted malt and herbal hops. The appearance is a medium brown with a nice head. The flavor is cereal like malt with the perfect amount of hops and sweetness. The aftertaste is lightly bitter but mostly light with some malt.
Honey Smell but not overpowring..Light copper-dark tan colour..a healthy head, settles nicely..very nice balance, flows easily down the throat, definetly an enjoyable oktoberfest bier.

On draught at Tulune’s. Good malty nose, mild hops with a smooth milky aroma. Clean and fresh, with sweet Twizzler and raisins. Clear caramel brown, with medium off-white foamy lacing head. Medium body with medium-heavy carbonation. Starts with nice malty sweetness, light caramel and  some Twizzlers, mild raisiny malt. Good dry hops toward the end, dusty and mild bitter. Smooth and pleasant Oktoberfest, fresh.

Poured a nice orange red with a small amount of fizzy white head.  Aroma is sweet matls, caramely, and sugared oranges.  Flavor is nice and smooth and sweet, though it has that same nagging yeasty undertone flavor that i get from all spaten beers.  cant lay my finger on if it really is yeast or not but something about it i dont like.  even with that though, i found this brew to be very refreshing and it went well with the spicey taco salad i was eating.

Bottle...

Not the typical beer I go for but It was ok. I couldn’t finish it to the end as it got a little bitter by then. For the most part it was smooth and drinkable. Hints of caramel, and a lightly sweet taste.

This is the best of the Spaten brews in my opinion.  The head and carbonation are both minimal, and the beer pours a transparent orangeish amber.  The nose is not necessarily memorable, but it is not as skunky as most German brews.  The light caramel flavors are the main influence, but they are not overbearing.  Indeed, while this beer feels relatively light, it is very balanced (though obviously more malty and sweet than hoppy or bitter).  I can get this fairly regularly on tap in Tallahassee and it is a go to for sure at its affordable price.

Bottle - August

Pour a beautifull copper color with a medium head that rapidly diminishes to a white rim. Arome is sweet of malt, grains and a hint of perfumy hops. Palate is medium bodied, bittersweet flavor with a solid malt background and some bitternes. 
Overall a really nice marzen.

Ok my 3rd attempt to rate this bastard with some SHAAAADDDDYYYY connection. No wonder Adelphia’s two top thugs went to club fed. Caramel Amber colour reflecting the nose. nice and smooth. enjoyable bread taste with a little hops here and there. Serves the ultimate purpose keeping that chewy beast, the optimator...make some noooissseeeee!!!!!!! company...

Amber / brown body with a white head.  Aroma was a bit skunky, but not too bad, also grainy, and slightly hoppy.  Taste was sweet and herbal.  Mouthfeel was like carbonated syrup.  Overall, this was pretty good.
Oktoberfest wouldn’t be the same without this classic german beer. a little sweet but just the right amount of nuttiness. very smooth and great at any time of the year, not just october

this word ur i think it means original or different...very fresh herbal malt nose wiht fruit lingering in the air.  rich malty flavors with a clean finish....classic sweet maltiness you would expect, one of the best marzens.
Poured dark amber and the aroma wafted malts. This is a sweet beer, but not overbearing, with a touch of sourness. Medium body and smooth drinking.
Normal german oktoberfest color, dark amber red. Slight nutty/ slight butterscotch. Very smooth, very drinkable.
A good beer.  Loved this with a big bowl of fondue cheese.  It goes down smooth and it perfect for those hot August days.  Color is a little pale for my liking.

Had from a bottle so appearance and aroma were very difficult. It was a very enjoyable beer that went down pretty easy. Had a good finish-- not too short and not too long. This is what I would call a "mowing the lawn" type beer (perfect for a hot MN day)

(500 ml bottle: $1.99 at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) When I first ventured outside the realm of American swill beers back in the early 90’s, Spaten Oktoberfest was the first beer I fell in love with.  In fact, I’ve considered it the de facto standard for Oktoberfest beers all these many years, but that may change because, while I still like and enjoy this beer quite a bit, it has clearly suffered quality loss in recent years.  The problem is, it’s pretty tough to find a really good, readily available Oktoberfest these days, and so Spaten’s may still be my standard, but by default.  It’s malty, caramely, and sweet, but whereas I used to think it was a really malty beer, it seems less malty and more sugary sweet than years ago.  However, the one thing I do love about this beer is the standard German malt profile that reminds me of wort.  You rarely get that in beers brewed in the USA.  There’s not a whole lot of hops in this beer, and bitterness is pretty light, which I think is fine because the sweetness isn’t overbearing and the palate isn’t cloying.  The malty and moderately sweet nose is a good lead-in for this beer.  Medium body, easy to drink, but carbonation levels could be a touch higher.  Amber/copper in color.  Good size to the off-white head, settling down to a thin layer, and leaving randomly shaped patches of lace on the glass.  I still enjoy this beer and will buy it on occasion, but it’s kind of fallen from the pedestal I used to have it on.
not very much taste to it.  I bit of a lager type after taste.  wasn’t too impressed pretty average.
Pretty good beer, not too many flavors going on, but the taste it has gets the job done for sure. Very enjoyable session beer.
Better than the Paulaner Oktoberfest.  Lots of sweet malt in flavor and aftertaste. Medium bodied.
Pours gold with a nice head. A caramel aroma aroma with a similar sweet malty flavor. A nice fruity hop finish with a syrupy aftertaste. Pretty ordinary, but a nice beer.

Dark golden with subtle hints towards orange.  I would not call this amber, but then again I’m not a color expert.   Aroma is delightful when first poured and exhibits mild hop flavours.   But once the head recedes the beer emits a light malt aroma.  Has a great deal of body and feels very rich on the tongue.  Well balanced between sweet and roasted malt flavours.   Malt rules the day, but it doesn’t have much else going for it.  A session lager, but nothing special.

This was pretty good.  My last beer in new york.  :)  It had good strong malty flavors with hints of citrus fruits and yeasty flavors.  it was yummers... but very basic.  and it tastes way better going down than coming up

I was lured to Octoberfest after developing an affinity for Optimator, and I was left wanting.  The head pours light, and ends frothy, with a sweet light smell of fruit.  The taste is very weak, not too bad... but, for the same price as Optimator, I have to Opt for that from now on~

Copper colored with a big loose white head. Spicey sweet malt aroma with some caramel and raisen. Thin in body for the style and lacking in overall flavor. The green bottle doesn’t help and one should never forget the distance factor. Who know how long these bottles sat in the belly of a hot-ass freighter. But I can rate what is offered.

Pours lovely deep copper with two-finger off-white head that beckons you to savor the flavors.  Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, some hops.  Tastes the same, with a firm, crisp finish.  Shows more caramel and even some corn flakyness as it warms.  Very good.

This bottle poured a beautiful amber-colored crystal clear liquid with an ample white creamy head that lasted nicely. The lacing on the edge of the glass was impressive as well. The aroma was simple and straight forward ... roasted malt sweetness. There was a smooth mouthfeel. The initial flavor presents sweet malt with just a hint of hop bitterness in the background. The middle displays notes of toasted malt and the finish is slightly bitter.
5ooml bottle...looked decent...malty nose...light and malty beer...OK overall...maybe lacking a bit of life...decent finish to it...but mostly just a decent malty beer.
Unimpressive aroma and less flavor then I was hoping for left me disappointed. A little sweeter then it should have been.

Green bottle poured a dark amber with a nice thick creamy head.
Aroma is skunky with a note of hops.
Flavor is malt and light hops with a slight metalic flavor on the finish.
Malty with slight hopped aroma and flavor.  This is a nice light amber ur-marzen with a kinda creamy off white head.  It’s subtle complexities are nice.

Smells horrible - almost like St. Pauli girl.  It gets better from there. Perhaps the most exciting and flavorful marzen i’ve had to date. Hops are evident but almost overpowered by the other flavorings.
Mild, but highly drinkable, and very cheap. I keep buying it for those reasons.
Golden yellow color with medium white head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with hints of raisin.  Flavor is malty, nutty, and toasty.  A touch of hops balances the brew well.

Pours a glowing golden brown.  Head is closely cropped.  Aroma is mild, but surprisingly floral.  Flavor is nutty (macadamia) and buttery, with a little bit of bitterness (like dark chocolate).  Finish is thin, with a paper-like remnant.
The Germans may not have it right on David Hasselhoff, but they sure as heck have it right on beer.  This is wonderful stuff, from the pour to the last sip.  A truly wonderful beer.

This is a good Oktoberfest.  Much better then I anticipated.  Pour a nice amber color with a creamy head.  The aroma was very malty and had some fruit in it as well.  The taste was very pleasant.  The malts were very tasty.  The mouthfeel was great because it was creamy.  Quite impressive.  My favorite Oktoberfest so far.

What a letdown.  I had high expectations for this beer because the folks at Spaten-Franziskaner usually put forth solid beers.  Poured a golden-bronze shade, which was lighter than expected.  Looked lively with fizzy bubbles dancing all around.  Smelled of grain, malt, toasted nuts, toffee and caramel.  The aroma seemed to indicate that the beer was going to be balanced.  Tasted smoother than expected, but too weak.  Almost tasted like a run-of-the-mill amber.  This beer was somewhat bittersweet, but lacked the depth and complexity that the champions of Oktoberfest beers master so well.

Great beer. Poured a deep amber in color with a decent off-white head. Malty nose, solid roasted malt flavor with a definite sweetness up front followed up by a mild hoppiness in the aftertaste. Very well balanced, medium in body and smooth. Excellent.
A nice beer. I look for quaffability in an oktoberfest and this beer has it in spades. A nice malt-forward rendition but the sweetness is balanced nicely. A solid german offering.

12 oz bottle. Light red/orange color. 1/2" of white head dissapates quickly leaving a constant surface head. Smell is malt, but there is also a skuny smell (green bottle). Taste is sweet malt, brown sugar, honey, and a bit o’ the skunkiness. There seems to be a hops backing. Balanced finish with some residual sweetness. The skunkiness really detracts from the flavor.   UNINTENTIONAL RERATE (I forget I tasted this before and got another one) 41° Pours copper colored with a small white head. Smells malty.. The flavor is a good amount of malt with a fleeting hops flavor. Not too bad. This doesn’t seem to be as skunky as the last one I had. Same flavors, honey, brown sugar, and some hops, but I don’t taste the skunkiness in it and that makes it alot better. Flavor is getting bumped up a point, as will the aroma and overall score.

Poured a medium amber color with a medium head that went quickly.  Slightly sweet with hints of hops, malt, and caramel.  Very easy to drink with little aftertaste.  Not my favorite Oktoberfest, but it ranks in the top five.

Draft @ Rich O’s - Dull copper pour with a frothy head.  The nose is real fruity - sweet peach and apples esthers abound.  Very clean throughout.  The creamy mouthfeel is the perfect vehicle for the caramel malts in the body.  The body dries out near the finish with champagne-like fruitiness.  Very drinkable!
Spaten Oktoberfest. Dark amber beer with decent carbonation. Very oxidized malt aroma. Very cardboardy taste. Ligh malt with sweet aftertaste. Not much hops.  (October 2004).
Draft. Nice Dark ruby color. Head lasted a little while. A pretty malty tasting brew, sweet earthy flavor, nutty.  Needs more hops i think.

Bottle.  Extremely flowery hops and malt aroma.    Very dark tan color with moderate head.  Tart malt flavor - low carbonation with a hint of orange and not much hops flavor.  Pretty good but not your typical oktoberfest beer.
Pours a dark orange/red, with big foamy bubbly head. Aroma is of fresh malt, oranges and peaches. a little "corny" too! Flavor is smoooth and malty. Quite unique. Thanks to Heemer for this one..
Light gold color with a big foamy head. Slightly malty with a clean finish.

Honey colored with a pillowy head. Great malty aroma with a bit of hops. Sweet palate with light bitterness and full of malt flavors. Round and soft initially and then leads into a long bready finish. Great blend of malt flavors.

Bottle. Pours a nice bronze/copper with a white head. Subtle yet classic aroma of bread, toasted grains and earthy noble hops. Flavor starts with rich malty toasty caramel, a little brown sugar and hay/grassy herbal hops. Starts rich and malty and ends with a punch of balancing hop bitterness. Very well-balanced.  Medium bodied with a creamy texture and satisfying, lively carbonation. Excellent. I don’t know what else you can ask for in a Marzen.

Not much of a smell coming out, but it got alot better from there.  Color looks great, nice amber hues with a white head that dissolved and coated the sides of the glass. Taste was great, the blending of malt and hops was perfect with just a little sweet aftertaste.
Not bad, I thought this was going to be a light beer, but it had caracter. A little dark, with the german traditional signature in it’s flavor.

Poured a yellowish-orange wtih a white head that left a lacing on the glass.  Aroma is not very malty, with more of a hop bite.  Taste has a hint of spice and malt, but tastes paler than most oktoberfests.  Granted, flavor is there, but not the kind of flavor I would expect from an oktoberfest.
Nice orange/amber in color, with a creamy white head. Aroma is somewhat herbal, grainy, and malty. Good malt/hop profile with a clean, soft finish. This is a tasty, sturdy oktoberfest.

Draught.  I don’t remember this a lot except that I drank it in a Flying Saucer pub in Fort Worth Texas while talking with a German priest and a Texas politician.  Sounds like a bad joke.  I know that it was nice and amber colored with a wonderful aroma and great malty taste.  Nice and creamy if I remember correctly.  Of course I do.
Tap.  Clear rich amber color.  Nice long-lasting white head.  Very malty in aroma and flavor.  Per style this is decent.  For personal taste a touch sweet and cloying.  Medium bodied.

Deep amber color, good lacing.  Exceptional balance of malt/hops.  Sweet, lingering aftertaste that encourages another taste.  Very true to the Oktoberfest style.  Introduced the Vienna-Marzen style to the German Oktoberfest

Pours light amber.Off white one half inch head that dissapates to about one eighth quickly and leaves nice lacing.Well balanced aroma.Nothing comes through too strong.Medium mouthfeel and very drinkable.

Whille this beer was dark, it was very clear. It had an average head with above average lacing. I wasn’t able to detect much if any aroma. I’m not sure what contributed to this. The body was good, a little thinner than I would have liked though. Overall I thought this beer was well balanced, but just a bit lacking in boldness.
Not a bad Marzen, very happy to have it over here. Decent malt profile, a bit thin bodied, nice on a woman but not a beer!
Pours a clear dark amber with a medium thick head.  Malty aroma.  Flavor is malty, sweet with a light spice and lightly sour finish.  Light to medium body, crisp, dry, clean finish.

Bottle Pours a clear dark amber with a nice thnick off-white head.  Aroma is of pale grain and malt.  Almost pilsner-like. Some sweet bready notes as well.  Flavor is reminecent of wheat toast with butter and honey. Malty and modest hops are here too.  Carbonation is fairly lively with a clean thin feel.  Trailer is a soft grain and slightly metallic taste.  Not as dark and robust as other Oktoberfest beers but very enh\joyable and pleasant.
Skunky. Green Bottles. Somewhat watery and thin, but with a noticeable maltiness. Seemed better 5-6 years ago...
Very well balanced oktoberfest..Nice amberish color and not to hoppy. A very enjoyable Beer
Orange/Amber Coloring.  Good Offering of Malt and Hops.  Sweet and Balanced.  Very Decent Oktoberfest.  Good Standard for the Style.

I like Octoberfest beers since there available now and im sure ill be missing them in few months.  This isn’t as malty as the other Spaten i remember having but thats good if you ask me.  Has a large fluff head.  The flavour was of sweet malts and well balanced hop level and a dab of spice.  This sure puts me in the mood for some german food and celebrating marzen.
Pours out a light amber, smells and tastes of fairly sweet hops. light alcohol flavor.  light fizzy head.  A pretty good beer all around.

Bottle.  I’ve been trying to get through as many oktoberfests as possible before they are all gone, and that led me to this.  I really don’t remember all that much about it, which tells me it wasn’t anything great.  On the other hand, I don’t remember it being bad either.  Overall a fair Oktober

Bottle (Celebrator glass) Deep orangey amber with thick offwhite head. Dusty nose of malts, noble hops. Smells definitely like a lager, with that trademark stink, similar to an American Dark Lager. Smell is reasonably sweet. Taste is better than the nose, particularly the finish. Starts with a touch of tin coupled with some banana? That was odd. ANyway, the middle is crisp and dusty at the same time. The noble hops help to counteract the big bready malts in the middle. Ultimately, proves to be a bit too sweet and fruity, though I’m sure it’s better than anything the American’s make. Or maybe not. I’ll have to hit the Pub and see...

2004 draught @ MacGreggors in Rochester, NY.  Pours a beautiful deep orange with light reds and yellows swirling about.  Good foamy white head, and while the aroma was not anything out of the ordinary for the style, I found the flavor to be excellent -- plenty of lightly sour yeast flavor is balanced by a solid caramel sweetness, light grainy texture and a bitter/sharp kick on the finish.  Very bready throughout, maybe even a bit too sweet and lacking of complexities, but it wasn’t approaching cloying, and at least the evident malt provides for a good solid medium body.  Lively carbonation and overall an enjoyable experience.
A very decent oktoberfest from spaten.  I do enjoy the darker flavors and appearance of this one, definately among my favorites for the season.
Bottled. Not as light in color as the other German Oktos we tried, and closer to what we accept as the style. Good dark maltiness is well balanced here by its hops.
A very good Octoberfest beer. Nice dark red color to the beer, sweet aroma and long lasting caramel flavor. One of my favorites.

Slightly hazy and golden amber body had medium and steady carbonation and a smallish foamy head that left delicate lacing.  The aroma was richly roasted caramel malt with a touch of noble hops.  Despite the green bottle, there was no skunkiness here, so the store must have treated this six pack nicely while in there care.  The primary taste was very smoothly sweet and bready malt with a refreshing lemony acidity, mild clove spiciness, and a low level of hop bitterness.  I could also detect some notes of bananas and orange peel in the taste.  The mouthfeel was creamy and full but displayed a dry aftertaste.  Drinkable, yet complex, I can easily see how this beer can be downed in vast quantities at this time of the year.

Wow!  I stand corrected.  I am in love with the Marzen.  Maybe it’s because it’s fall...maybe it’s because October is coming up...but these beers are amazing.  And this puppy takes the cake as the best I’ve had thus far--beats out Sam Adams Octoberfest.  It’s nutty with caramel tones--filling your mouth with an alcohol tingliness that does not disturb, rather it caresses your mouth.  This beer is just so good.  Try it.  I find it similar to La Trappe Quadrupel, which I had a couple of months ago and they’re both just plain good.
On tap.  Golden color with big white head.  Aroma is malty.  Taste is malty and caramel with a little hop, but it’s not all that impressive.  Try the Hacker-Pscorr, it’s much better.
(tap) orange copper color, a slightly oily mothful but not too heavy, caramel and scotch notes

On tap. Clear and bright copper color, medium white head. Caramel malt aroma, touch of hops. Has a roasted sweetness, light-medium body, little by way of hops. Crisp and dry aroma, honey sweetness at times.

12 oz. green bottle.  Light copper in color, with nice, large white head that remains quite a while.    The aroma is malty and sweet but not as much as Hacker-Pschorr.  There is also a nice hop aroma.  Medium body but a bit dry on the finish.  It’s a bit light on the malt for the style but it is very clean.  Nice carbonation on palate brings out the flavor and the hop bitterness.
Golden colour with large solid head. Aroma and flavor is dominated by the malts wich leaves a nice impression of caramel and nuts. Palate is very good.

A decent Oktoberfest brew, but I was expecting a little bit more. Malt is the focus with caramel and nutty flavors present. Distinct fruitiness throughout. Decent dryness, along with decent citric/spicy hop bitterness. Mouthfeel and flavor were a bit thinner than expected, but this is still alright.

Pours a dark amber to copper shade, with a thick white head.  Very malty aroma, sweet yet crisp and mildly hoppy.  Flavor is an excellent caramel maltiness, with some spicy notes and a crisp, dry finish.  Good moderately thick mouthfeel, giving the beer a good body but making it easy to drink as well.  I really like this beer, and there’s something about it that just feels like autumn.
(Draught)  Pours a deep golden color with a large white creamy head.  Sweet malt and grass aroma.  Flavor of sweet malt and some caramel and spices.

Medium to light amber color, kind  of clear. Foamy head that seems to last. Good mmoutn feel, taste theroasted malts, lightly, taste some toffee, nothing over powering which is pleasant and very refreshing. Good brew.
Small head on a clear, amber-and-orange beer.  Average malt aromas with a hint of toffee some light orange.    There is some thin sweetness among the flavors as well, with some average carbonation.

Rich amber color with a foamy off-white head that lasts long enough to satisfy and leaves rich lacing as it slowly bubbles away. Nicely carbonated beer with tiny bubbles rapidly rising through the clear body. Aroma is hoppy with sweet undertones of malt. Flavor is crisp, clean, hoppy, and refreshing with a sweet malt finish. Overall, this is truly a delicious beer! I am making it part of my Oktoberfest tradition. One unfortunate detail: four out of the six bottles I sampled had a skunky flavor and aroma (damned green bottles).
Pours a nice amber with a silky white head. Great malt aroma, not too roasty, with a bit of caramel. Taste has an amazing balance with a smooth mouthfell, dry finish, and lots of caramel.

Appearance: clear pale bronze color, with booming, boisterous cream-toned foam atop (I may have optimized the head potential by utilizing a Wehenstephaner weizen glass).
Aroma: soft, spare, tiniest hints of caramel & nuts, glimmers of malt. 
Taste: bright, sweet, slightly coppery feel, mild. No hops felt, malt is all over the flavor, but never too strong. Body, very light, texture is small, finish is too quickly dissipated. A very subdued, but supremely approachable marzen. Geared towards those with less exploratory ambitions in their beer imbibement.
Golden amber with off-white head.  Aroma was caramel, malt, spice, some citrus.  Flavor is sweet, some malt and spice and even fruit.  Decent but not nearly remarkable.
Picked up a single of this one to give it a try. Malty taste, and slightly skunky. Not my favorite but a decent beer. Definately better than the domestics.
My favorite Oktoberfest from the big Munich 6.  This one is better than last years addition and is extremely drinkable.
Bright orange color with a thin lasting white head. Fairly high carbonation. Smell is malty and toasty, and slightly skunky. More bitterness up front than I expected.

Bottle. Darker amber color with a thin white head that leaves lace on the glass throughout from beginning to end. Caramel dominates the flavor and aroma. Soft earthy hops add to the flavor, but the body is just a bit thin.

Most excellent. I’m beginning to really look foreword to the Oktoberfests coming out in the fall. This poured a really nice amber color in a very appropriate dimpled mug at Res’s in Chicago. Very well-balanced and subtle but tasty with a floral nose and good dose of caramel malts. A great example of the style when drank fresh on tap rather than from the green bottles Spaten uses for some reason I will never understand. Tried this directly after the higher-rated Ayinger Oktoberfest and I couldn’t say which one I prefer. Spaten is maybe a hair sweeter but equally good. In fact, they both get the same rating.

Bottle. Medium and smooth off-white head that contained fine sized bubbles. Softly carbonated, transparent and an orange hue. Malty, caramel, hoppy and sweet nose. Sweet, malt and caramel flavor. Smooth palate. Light-medium bodied beer with next to no lacing.

This bottled brew poured a large head of fine to large sized mostly lasting light brown colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body contained  average carbonation, was transparent and caramel brown in color.  Its aroma contains notes of caramel malts and is very nice.  Its mouth feel is initially smooth with a lingering caramel malt flavor.  Its flavor contains caramel malts.   This fine brew is an excellent example of a good German export beer.  The real think at the Oktoberfest is even better!
Pours light amber orange with slight tan head.  Nose is of mild maltyness and subtle hops.  Smooth mouthfeel with nice balanced sweetness.  Slight presence of wet paper.

Bottle pours translucent copper, large frothy white head, good carbonation, with fairly good lacing.   Aroma is of malts, slightly salty, and maybe a bit nutty.   Quite malty on the tongue.   It also appears to be ever so slightly sweet, nutty, and slightly grassy.   Good body, somewhat creamy texture.   Finishes with a light fruit flair, mainly pear, and more grass.   Decent Oktoberfest, but a bit too sweet for what I enjoy.

Damn green bottles.  Metallic malty caramel aroma.  Transparent copper color with a small white head.  Sweet, malty, skunky with hints of caramel mals.  Finish has a small amount of hops.  Decent maarzen.  Kind of thin.
Fruity and caramel malts. Rather light bodied, I could drink lots of this stuff in one sitting. Not surprising the Germans know how to make a Marzen.
Poured toasted brown in color, with a slight head. Malty and sweet, with a baking bread aroma. Good example of the style.
Pours a nice amber color, with a medium foamy off-white head. Tastes of grain with a little sweetness. Some spice and hoppiness towards the finish.
Pours clear amber with a decent head...raisin malty nose...tastes full and earthy...good Oktoberfest beer...

Spaten claims to be the first Marzen beer. This happens to be one of the best Oktoberfest beers (and it’s certinally not a Oktoberfest beer if it’s not offered in Muenchen during Oktoberfest). Not too sweet or thick and has a very spicy, and smoked taste.
Draught. Copper body with a dense one finger head. Notes of raisin, malt, hops, and honey come through. Finish is sweet. Not bad.

bottle-pours a light copper hue with nice rocky head.  aggressive carbonation.  lager aroma-spicy german hops, toasty marzen malting.  some decent spicy flavors but a touch of cardboard in the flavors.  light crisp body.  easy drinking marzen
Light amber. Minimal head. Malt, smoke  and spice aroma. Spiced malt flavour. Interesting.

[bottle - Great European Beerfest 8, Sharp Edge Tavern - East Liberty, PA] Poured a nice coppery/amber color with an extremely thin white head. Roasted malt aroma with a hint of hops and some fruits. Sweet flavor that balances well with the peppery bite of the hops and goes into a nice smooth finish.

The beer has a good  orange/ amber color.  The head is nice and leaves a thin lacing.  It is very balanced yet you can tastes the indivuality of the hops and roasted malts.  Drink this beer in October or November or December or any time you can!

My first Oktoberfest!  It pours beautifully with an off-white eggshell and a beautiful copper/brown color with grat clarity.  Odor is sweet malts, earthy/spicy hops.  Taste is crisp and clean, a bit roasty, pleasent malt character, spicy hops (saaz me thinks?).  Quite grainy.  Very tasty beer.

I love this Marzen. So clean and refreshing. Awesome. 
Beer pours a lovely copper hue and has a little deep white head that sticks for a while. Nose is of roasty spicy malts, lager yeast and depth and spicy saaz hops. Excellently refreshing in the mouth. Notes of roasted pumpkin and spicy hops. Bitter and clean 
Grat

Ahh, the Oktoberfest Ur-Marzen... one of my favorites. I love the deep flavor and the really strong aroma of this beer. Reddish bronze in color with very little head that disappears quickly. The strength of the flavors and bitterness is well balanced with the sweet undertones. I would drink this all year round if I could.

12oz green Bottle. Pours a light amber with a nice medium off-white head, some lacing.  Aroma of toffee, hot water bottle rubber, slight skunkyness, and medium alcohol.  Flavor of light roasted nutty malts, quite sweet candy like flavor, and mild hop bitterness at end, hops very subdued by the overall sweetness.  Body thin/medium.  Overall not bad, very refreshing, good lager, and fine oktoberfest.  Original Review (2.1)Bottle. Nice amber/brown pour, medium head. Oh NO!! Its skunked!!  I can kind of taste what is should taste like but not really; none of the flavors can stand up the skunkiness.  Will re-rate.

Nice looking beer, leaving extensive, intricate lacing on my glass; malty, toasted, caramel aroma; moderately-full bodied, tart and sweet, with a late, building bitterness; clean,  smooth, and quenching. Great year-round!
great looking pour, stunning amber with a white head. great aroma, had a remarkable mix of scents, mostly sweet aroma. has a nice sweet taste. leaves a nice lace whle drinking also

On tap.  Clear bronze coloring with a small white head.  The flavor is almost woody with hints of bread and some caramel or toffee.  The beer was slightly warming as it went down the gullet.  Quite good - best Oktoberfest I’ve had.
Reddish amber body, small white head. Very malty and well balanced w/ a light roasty and carmel flavor.Very drinkable.
I am going to have to agree with cheap plug in the description in having an impeccable taste. it is mighty tasty that wipes your palate clean
This was a really tasty beer.  It was really good out of a frosty mug.  I would buy it again
Good for the style, probably the standard.  Just not something I like every day, though.  It’s almost a summer beer to me.
deep golden, small head. aroma of whole wheat toast and caramel with a whiff of hop.  flavour is a little on the sweet side and could do with a bit more bitterness.  not bad, though.
A heavy amber beer. I struggled to drink more than a few of these guys. Not hoppy at all. Pours with very little head.
Bright white head, dark gold/ light brown .Aroma: Light, sweet malt. Slightly oily texture, malty base. Basic Oktoberfest, malt accented.

Aroma: Do I smell pumpkin? Appearance: Brownish-red with a tinge of orange when held up to light. Amber. Flavour: Sweet, but not too sweet like Lowenbrau is. Pleasant and smooth, although not as smooth as Gordon Biersch's Marzen. The palate is rich, somewhat butterlike in its feel, smooth, comforting, and with weight, a consoling heft to it. Probably my favourite Oktoberfest beer yet. This could be because it is not only an Oktoberfest beer, but also an Oktoberfest Ur-Marzen. Pretty easy to drink - which of course comes in very handy at Oktoberfest when that is the goal [Ziel].
Not getting a ton of aroma out of this one, bit of pleasant malt and slight bitterness in it. Mellow easy going beer. Probably deserves a re-rate.
Amber w/ white head. Balanced malt & hop aroma. Medium feel. Sweet, lightly roasted malt flavour w/ a lightly hoppy finish.
Redish brown with not much of a head. Caramel tosted malt aroma. malty with a hint of toffee, finishes up fairly bitter.
Sadly weak and unsatisfying. There was a lot of head, and the aroma was similar to the other Spaten beers, but the overall experience was not good.

A nicely done Oktoberfest. Usually, I don’t care for the style. This has a malty aroma. Beautiful dark amber color. Very little head when I poured this. The taste is basically a one trick pony and has some malt with a little hops bite. It would be easy to drink a lot of these.

good, found one in my fridge that i must have forgetten to rate. had it yesterday out of a bottle- had been working outside so it was good, went down in 4 swigs. i think its a amber type color, good flavor. not bad all in all
Really good.  One of my favorites, this beer drinks easily and tastes smooth and delicious.  Not very complex, but great all the same.

Acquired via trade. Pours a clear amber color with minimal carbonation and a medium thin off-white head. Thin and quick lacing. The aroma is malty and skunked (green bottle issue?). Medium-bodied with a yin and yang of sweetness and skunkiness throughout, this ended up being a drain pour. The malt and caramel flavors simply could not compete with the unpleasant skunkiness. The finish kept with the theme. I will have to try to seek a fresher bottle out for a re-taste.
Sweet, Malty, probably out of it's prime but it was still a good beer.  Normal head, slightly bitter.
Buttery. Smooth. This is a fine one to drink a few liters of when at an Oktoberfest event. Update 8/30/4: malty, less sweet than Ayinger. More bittering hops than many fest biers.
A bit dryer than I like in an Oktoberfest. Overall nicely balanced, malty and hoppy, and that nice copper color and head straight from the bier garten, ja! Good, good, good..
Malty, spicey nose, clear copper, full sized firm off white head, with lace. Zingy, candied malt flavour, and a bitter, nutty aftertaste. Medium bodied, well balanced. A fine example!
tastes like a light lager but defintely a filling beer, easy on the senses and a hint of sweet flavor.  Much better oktoberfest than most american versions
Not a bad beer... Kind of Bland tasting I was expecting more out of a Marzen

This beer is very similar in flavor to the Löwenbräu Oktoberfestbier, smooth aroma, mild flavor, low Alcoholic % as in any other Oktoberfest beer so you can drink for hours and hours, liter after liter without getting drunk. Nice!

Deep tan in color.  Week aroma, which is not a bad thing.  Had a very full head the quickly disolved.  The taste is malty, with a sweet(almost honey) tasting finish.  Not a bad beer at all...I think I'll have another.
dark golden color with very unusual aroma. decent head, slightly malty and sweet. could benefit from more malt flavor. overall a pretty decent beer.

Nice tall head that disappears after a while. Very light clear yellow body. Nice sweet aroma with hints of malt. Sweet lager taste with a medium bitter aftertaste. Not the most interesting beer but it is alright!! Too sparkling!
Golden coloured. Very mild. Sweet and malty. Quite bland and boring in my opinion.
Poured dark amber with a fluffy white fading head. Has a malty aroma. Malty and slighty fruity taste and is well balanced. A nice beer.
Bottle: Golden dark color with a rich head. Fruity and well balanced malt and hops.

I had SOOO many bottles of this over the few weeks of Oktoberfest and one thing the experience really left me with was this: drink the bottle before it warms! or else your in for a seriously dingy tasting ass of a beer. This aside, it was a smooth musky lager that was a touch grainier than normal but really nothing too special.

Really middle of the road brew.  Like everyone says, malty and caramely (is that a word?), amber pour with faint fast fading head.  It is not bad, but it is not great either.  It's just kind of there.  I'd drink it again without a doubt, but don't know how much out of my way I'd go to do so.
one of my favorite oktoberfests.  caramel and malt notes mixed with a hop bitterness appealed to me.  It seemed heavy on the stomach which made the flavor notes quite ful-bodied.

An amber colored clear beer toped by a white rapidly diminishing head.  Aroma is significantly malty light fruit.  Taste is somewhat sweet but with a nice balance of hopps medium bodied.  Mellow.  A decent beer

Color is a nice light copper amber with a one finger high off-white head thats evenly foamed and smooth, fades down to a thick haze and lace in muddy globs. Aroma has a nice touch of lightly toasty malts, grainy and fresh and breadish sweet. Taste has a nice mellow toasted maltyness thats lightly sweet and bready, pretty easy and calm flavors, nothing overwhelming, notes of light nuttyness comes through in the finish with a favorable light drying. Sure its a bit plain, but nice enough to keep it interesting. Feel is medium bodied, pretty smooth the whole way through, easy little bitterness and a light drying finish. I can see drinking alot of these, as it warmed it was very nice indeed, a bit on the plain side, but something about the subtleness kept me going til the glass was empty. A good drinkin' O-fest.

Poured a fantastic looking massive billowy white head..that sticks a round more than the Paulaner ..a crystal clear amber beer..
Dissapointed about the aroma..compared to Paulaner Marzen its very feeble. not offensive though average indeed.
The taste though I liiked again i got some nice malt profiles this time smooth coffee and creme sort of flavour , milk chocolate comes to mind..very pleasant.
I like a beer to be smooth on the tongue and this does the job.
Quite drinkable..but not overlly so..the lack of carbonation makes sure you wont drink 12 of these babies..but this is an Ok beer

Bottle:
Nice amber color.  Pours a nice creamy head with minute bubbles, some lace, moderate retention.
Nose is malt, caramel, a hint of hops.
Nice creamy muthfeel, sweet malt character with a mild bread aftertatse.  Finishes fairly sweet with a bit of bitter to add balance to it.  Always nice.

One of my favorite Oktoberfest beers from a terrific brewer!  It is a hearty, toasty, delicious tasting beer with a terrific balance of malts (sweetness) and hops (bitterness.)  To further the dichotomy, this leads to a strong, but fruity finish!  Golden pale-pumpkin color.  Delicious bouquet.  Great from start to finish!
Quite goodn I like the slight carmel in the flavor and its overall mildness. Not week in flavor mind you but just very drinkible and smooth. A nice OKT

Aroma: Carmel malty tones with a hint of toasted grains, slight sherry notes of oxidation.  No perceived hops.

Appearance is copper-brown with brilliant clarity, low & thin creamy head - but this persists, with moderate fine carbonation.  Pretty!

Flavor: Rich toasted-toffee malt exposure with low hop flavor & enough bitter to support the malty base.  However there is apparent papery tones of oxidation that are difficult to escape even in brown glass when they travel cross the pond & over the hills to my distant shore.  Regardless, this is a nice exposé of malt, toasted caramel-toffee, with a hint of fruitiness that is otherwise rather clean in the finish.

The Mouthfeel is medium, well carbonated, without a note of grain astringency, slightly acidic due to the carbonation, & sans the oxidation – pleasantly enjoyable.

Overall the biggest factor for any beer that travels from afar is in the care & handling of the distributor, & oxidation figures large enough.  Beyond that ~ oh I’d love to schedule a flight for Bavaria & stay a month during Oktoberfest, or at least until they kick me out!  This is a rich malty experience than any beeker (beer geeker) would envy!

Nice head, Amber color. Some lacing. Tastes very smooth. Very drinkable. Capital Fest and Leinie still better in my opinion. Better than the other 4 I've tried. This is a very good beer. I can see why so many really like it.

12 oz. green bottle. No freshness date that I can decipher. Poured out a bright amber color, with a super fast fading head. It didn't stick around for more than a minute, literally. Aromas of malts, Noble hops, bready yeast, and slight skunk. Good thing I only bought one of these beers, because it just isn't anything to write home about, IMHO. It was decent enough, but nothing spectactular. Finished kind of dry, not much in the way of hops in the finish.
light malty aroma with slight floral hops - orange with a little red - medium white head - malty and slight spice flavor, ending with hoppiness - very easy to drink
Slightly malty aroma.  Good malt backbone throughout.  Finishes slghtly sweet.  A good Marzen.

I didnt really taste much from this Marzen.  On tap at Stuff Yer Face in NB, it lacked anything special about it.  I'll stick to Paulaner.

1 year later...I did enjoy it a little bit better this year.  Especially on Oktoberfest day when I got a free glass and t-shirt.  So I will up the overall impression a bit.

Bottle, poured clear orange-amber with a medium white head.  Sweet malty nose with apricot, cinnamon and floral hops.  Toasty malt flavor with apple, spice cake and a lingering hop finish.  Medium body, creamy carbonation.  Nice autumn offering from Spaten.
Reddish caramel color with white head. Sweet marzen smell with strong malt notes.Lacking a little punch towards the end but is a little hoppier than most oktoberfest beers. Not bad.
A little more hops than expected, but it makes the brew take a good direction.  Excellent malt.  A good and rich Oktoberfest.

Light red with foamy offwhite head. Smells sweet and tangy. No skunky smell. So far so good. No skunky taste either. So far impressed. The beer has a tangy sourness to it. Good amount of bitterness. This is a nice oktoberfest and much better than the  Spaten original which I can't stand in the least.
Bottled. Yes it was a green one. This one wasn't that great. Had the slight skunk taste pretty much through the whole beer. Besides that tasted what it should bee.

Orange amber hue.  Stinky malt nose.  Sticky off-white head.  Pleasantly malted, ligh to medium bodied, finishing with just the right amount of balancing hops.  Creamy, crisp and very quaffable.  PROST!

Strong head when poured from the bottle.  It went away but left enough to make you remember it had lots of to start with.  Excellent medium tan/brown color.  Good mixture of malt and hops.  More hops than I expected for an Oktoberfest.  Definitely a good Oktoberfest from a bottle.
An average oktoberfest, in my opinion.  Decent color, but not much in the way of aroma.  A nice flavor, but still lacking, in my opinion.
Light, herbal nose; yellow color; foamy head. Creamy malt with light citrus tones (lemons) maybe some apple inthe background. Full body and a great balance. Classic!
Grassy and hoppy nose. Golden wit a little head, liveley carbonation. Nice hoppy refreshing aroma with a pleasant mouthfeel.
It was very cold when I had it. Deep amber color...not much of a head. Malty/citur aroma. Not that great of an Oktoberfest.
On draught. Pours dark amber with some bubbles, white foamy head.  Aroma is malty citrus. Flavor is the same. Not as sweet as other Oktoberfests I've had.  Decent, but not exceptional.
Golden colour with a nice white head. Fine lace. Very malty, quite full - almost chewy.
Nice floral aroma to this one, coppery brown, fading head.  Malts and hops woven together, very smooth, caramel flavors with floral and a bit of spicy earthiness to the hop finish.  Very nice.

This beer is the essence of caramel. The body is dark caramel. If you want to get an idea, take some sugar over a spoon and hold it over a flame until it melts and them caramelizes. That's about the color here. The head was very wimpy and since the waiter came back with the beer very quickly, I don't think it was just because of natural dissipation. This was a much maltier beer than the Warsteiner Oktoberfest I had just prior to this, but this also had less hops. There also seemed to be a little prune-like flavor that I sometimes get from beers that use one of the darker German malts.
A great Oktoberfest beer.  Very well balanced with sweet, crisp roasted malt flavor and  crisp finish.

How many liters of this have I consumed? Enough to drown in for sure. Only wish there was a better means of determining if it were fresh. Not an overwhelming beer, but solid and well crafted and made where I can keep reaching for another and another. With a birthday in October this has another reason for long being a favorite.
fresh flowery aroma, golden in colour with a white head, very hoppy, flowery and spiecy character, smooth creamy palate with a peppery finish.

Good looking copper,beer with constant carbonation. Head is medium-sized and well beaded. Aroma is rich-malty,fruity-hoppy,and slightly lagerish(hay,sulfur??). Creamy,well carbonated mouthfeel. Fairly full body. Flavor starts malty,slightly toasty, with the back somewhat empty. Finish is crisp,clean,and delicious,displaying roastiness,before the soft,fruity,hops. Extremely drinkable and tasty!
Golden color with light white head. The taste is like a malty lager with a light bitter finish.

My chick picked out the pre-game beer last night and she chose Spaten Octoberfest, cool! 
Copper / amber in color, uplifted a short lived fizzy tan head.   Pretty good stuff, it was a bit lacking in complexity of flavor and aroma, pretty simple but good. Loads of ceramal malts present themselves in the aroma and flavor, slightly toasty. Nothing stellar but yummy.

White head doesn't last very long at all, but it has the typical amber coloration of a marzen.  MMMMMM, malty aroma, as well as caramel and light roastiness. Very clean and no hop character in the aroma.  Very malty and well balanced w/ a light roasty and carmel flavor; pretty much the same as the aroma.  Finishes clean and malty.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  I like the version from the tap much better, I think the characteristics are a little more pronounced and it's a little more complex, but it's a style I could drink a lot of and not really tire of it.

Bottled.
Golden with an ok head.Some hensfood, perfume-aroma.
Rather sweet and thin.
This is my impression from the bottled version,from the tap at least 18 years ago it was even better.
Medium-clear amber color. Nice malty taste with that classic "German Lager" flavor. Good sweet malty finish.

Reddish amber body, small white head.  Sweet malty aroma, maybe caramel as well.  Little carbonation, smooth palate, tastes very sweet with little to no bitterness.  Maybe I'm just not into Oktoberfest beers too much.

Appeance: This pours a clear a clear amber color with a small white head.
Aroma: The nose is lightly malty & carmelly.
Flavor: This is a slightly malty, light on the hops, light to medium bodied, Oktoberfest. This is a nice beer, but nothing spectacular. I was expecting more maltiness

Had this back to back with Sam Adams Octoberfest to compare the two. This had a richer palate than the Sam Adams. It was also a little lighter in color, but not too light. Thin head. Overall it's slightly better than the Sam, but I still didn't think there were enough hops; I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of beer.
Amber colored, decent head. Malty aroma, a bit of hops. Toasty bready flavor, bitter hop finish. Thin to medium bodied.
Pours a nice amber color, decent head, some lacing. Some sweet malts in the nose along with small hops. Sour malt flavors, sort of grape. Finishes bitter.
Pale golden, bubbly and quickly disappearing head. Aroma is somewhat hoppy. Has a bitter taste, but not a beer to remember.
Light golden with a thin head. Looks a little thin. Aroma is bready. Bittertaste, notes of coffe, expected more body.

Bottled. 
Golden with a fine rocky head. Slight spicy aroma with a malty background. Sweetish roasted malt flavour with a discrete alcohol presence.

Cloudy amber color with a mild hoppy smell and a watery palate.
Nice bubbly acidy taste.  Decent beer for a cold day.
Its a great octoberfest beer. Very light and amber pour, nice with a little bit of hoppiness in its flavor. Medium body.

Very light amber pour, small white head that leaves quick and laces little.  Aroma is light, some light toast and a bit of flowery hops in there as well.  Flavor is mostly some sweet breadiness, a bit of toastiness, and a very little bit of hoppiness.  Medium-thin body, light carbonation.

Sort of a light brownish amber color with an excellent creamy head and fair lacing. Mild aroma-meadowlike and citrusy. Light to medium bodied, caramely sweet with a tangy note to it and a touch of salt. The finish was pleasant and slightly bitter. This one is my favorite of the current crop so far.
Nice deep brown-red color, off-white head.  I liked the sweet malt flavor and the hops nicely balanced it out.  This is a pretty average Marzen, but at least it's a quality one.
Poured a golden amber color.  It had a medium sized off white head.  The aroma was malty, slightly citrusy hop aroma.  It had a dry leathery, yeasty flavor.  First Oktoberfest of the season!

12 oz bottle, lager mug, 50 degrees.  Gigantic, tan, creamy, frothy off white head diminishes slowly.  They body is an amber to brown-orange color and is crystal clear with moderate carbonation.  Caramel, cookie malt (mod); flowery hops (light); apple and pear aromas.  Incredibly clean and smooth tasting compared to the Sam Adams I had earlier. Moderately sweet throughout with a lightly bitter finish.  Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation.  Filling for an Oktoberfest.  The bottom line is: a great malty lager that's readily available.
Smells like road-kill, but tastes pretty good. Flavor is a mellow malt, and slightly metallic.

This is my first Oktoberfest beer I've tried.  It certainly has an interesting flavor which one can be easily identified this as a German beer.  While I don't think I am totally in love with this beer, it is certainly a nice change of pace.

Amber colour with almost no head! Smells of malt with a bit of spice thrown in. Medium-bodied; A strong malty flavour with a bit of the harsher (pepper, etc) spices also showing through. A pretty good beer, not great, and all-around a decent beer for the style. I had my pint from Draught at MacGregor's in Rochester, New York.
I'm sipping one now...beautiful amber color..wonderful aroma....delicious...this is a macrobrew??  much better than Becks Okto. or Lowenbrau Okto....Outstanding!!
Oktoberfest is here. Amber-red color. A light malty aroma. Dry roasted malt character. Somewhat watery, a slight buttery aftertaste. Very refreshing.

Orange-copper color and lively carbonation. Lightly toasted malt aroma plus some grassy hops. Warm flavor. Has some elements in common with Spaten Premium Lager, except this beer has significantly fuller body and flavor. Santa Fe Ski Area serves this beer on the mountainside and it tastes particularly good during a ski break in the beautiful alpine environment of the southwestern United States.
Golden, small white head. Fresh smooth malty aroma with hints hints of bread and citrus. Very tasty with nice malty sweetness. Some breadiness with some notes of honey from the malt.

Poured a orange-brown color, little tan head, little lace.  Tasted very much like the Paulaner Oktoberfest, in that it is an incredibly sweet and caramelly.  A bit acidic, some floral hops that convey into the palate a dandelion flavor.  Not bad for a style that is not one of my favorites.
Bottle. Tasty lager with a bit more sweet malt than normal - gets a bit grainy toward the finish. This blond Oktoberfest is not as interesting as the dark Oktoberfest/Marzen style.

Nice gooey malt. Reddish-munich malt hugh. Low hop. Fresh and well conditioned, the way it ought to be. Up there with the best of Germany and not yet dumbed down like many are becoming. Very drinkable, but a bit more to the chewey side. If you like O'fests, you'd be hard pressed to find anything wrong with this one.
Dark golden with nice white fluffy head. Malt, malt and again malt from the head to the bottom. Perfectly drinkable.
Clear amber appearance with a good sized head.  Toasty, malt aroma.  Fruity, malty taste with a tiny bit of sweetness.  Smooth, creamy finish.

beautiful copper/auburn color with great head. I love spaten's bottles because they fill a weizen glass with a 2 fingered head right to the top, pefect pour everytime. This one has a excellent malt profile in the aroma, you can just chew on the munich malts they're so apparent. Flavor is medium bodied but really easy to drink. A very clean fresh mouthfeel and overall a well made oktoberfest.
Oranngy tint with a thick foamy head.Has tastes of malt with a nice clean finish.Not too bitter.

A quite yumy Oktoberfest.  Lighty mouthfeel, medium bodied and a deep orange hue shines through, with a creamy little head.  Doughy, with some nice malty sweetness, with a nice balance of hops shining through but never taking dominance over the other.
Copper/Orange, thin but sturdy head.  Watery, grainy but clean aroma. Bready flavor, with just of touch of sweetness. Seems a bit watery on the palate.
Medium characteristics all across the board.  Sweet, yet roasty.  Malt balanced with hops.  Good looking head & nice golden color.  One of if not the best oktoberfest.
On tap at Der Steinkeller.  Golden body with a thin white head.  Aroma is light and sweet.  Flavor is pleasant, light sweet fruits and a touch of spice.  A festive concoction, indeed.
very nice, moderately malty aroma; small creamy head that dissipates quickly; medium amber color; slightly bitter, long-lasting finish

Aroma is malty with a hint of fruit. Appearance is a dark orange with good lacing and head. Flavor is malty with some spice and fruit. Slightly bitter and a noticeable sourness. Palate is a little thin. Odd I found this in July being a fall seasonal and all. I guess this has been chillin at the store for a while. Not a great one but certainly a good one.
Very nice dark amber with a good body and smooth taste. It's not as hearty as some Oktoberfests, but certainly pleasant enough.

Ah, tasty. Rather funky in apperance but nothing unpleasant. A bit spicy, perhaps? Very subtle hops peek through a pleasantly malty brew. Nice medium-light body and almost buttery mouthfeel. Very nice sweet-then-dry finish. I expected less out of this and was very happily surprised.
Amber color with small white head. Thin bodied. Sweet malty taste with some fruity flavor. A little hop bitterness also.
From the Sharp Edge European Beerfest: I was pleasently suprised by this oktoberfest.  This is actually a marzen beer rather then a fall marking gimick.
A tastey product from the good folks at Spaten.  Solid medium body that balances the hops just right with the malt.  There is a touch of the sweetness in the finish which makes it so good.
Abundant head. Malt and fruit notes on a moderately bitter background; a hint of spices. Rather short aftertaste. Nice, but I found it a bit thin.

Heavy wheat aspect in aroma and flavor. Deep amber, fairly light bodied. Close to no head. There was a good balance between the hops and malt. Definitely more flavorful than others I've had representing this style.
This is my favorite of the Spaten line, but I really don't think much of any of the Spaten products I've had yet.  This beer was a little too bitter for my tastes.

(2Apr2003--500ml bottle)
One of Spaten's top offerings.
Kind of ugly to look at, with a big, but thin, styrofoam-like head; lumpy with uneven lacing.
Medium copper in color.  Aroma equally disappointing, kind of like apple cider, or a mix of acetaldehyde, hops, and malt sugar.
Once it hits the tongue, however, it's pretty enjoyable.
Fairly dry.  Unspectacular flavor, but certainly without major fault.
Nicely airy and well-carbonated for such a sizeable beer.
Fantastic mouthfeel.
Lightly chalky/astringent, lightly sour, medium/low bitterness.
In summary, it's a great Oktoberfest.
Very rich, creamy mouthfeel. The aroma was malty sweet. The flavor was on the sweet side with a distinct hops bitterness in the finish. Light feeling beer but extremely satisfying.

Beautiful thick foamy white head.  Very dense, thick sheets of lace.  Crystal clear orange/amber body with lots of carbonation.  Dry barley and toastey caramel malts.  Some earthy tones stand out of the nuttiness.  Very clean palate, mildly effervescent.  Sweet and a bit dry on the finish.
Bottle.  Dark golden color with a white head.  A toasted malt aroma and flavor with a dark malty aftertaste.
Medium amber color with a small head. Smooth over the tongue and down the throat. Quite pleased with this one.
Awsome color.  Good smelling beer.  Very good taste and good amount of alcohol.  Good overall beer.

Not a bad beer. Very straight forward. Nice amber color and it has a small white head. Has a slight sweet aroma. Has a malty flavor and you can taste the hops. It also has quite a bit of carbonation. Over all this is a decent beer that is very refreshing.
Aroma of corn, sugar, wheat.  Very harsh on the mouth, with burnt corn and spices.   Mild and thin flavor, a bit watery and a bit skunky.
Reminds me of a Vienna with an off bitter taste.  Not unpleasant but not something I will go back to.
Pleasant rich malt flavor I seem to taste paper. I wonder if this just might be a lot better when fresh?

in the old days this was the cream of the crop. They keep dinking with it and its lost some. I guess all big exports do the samething. Anyway how did they think the public would buy a golden marzenbier. Anyway they corrected that so its back, not quite to its old glory, but not as mutilated as Paulaner Salvator, its more of a double marzen than a dunklesbock these days.
Medium-dark amber. Good head. The lovely malt promised by the aroma is lived up to. A great Märzen
An excellent beer. Loved it from the first smell to the last sip. Pungent flavor that keeps you wanting more.
Deep Amber in color w/ a off-white head.  Nice carmel nose.  Sweet start with a slight bitterness that balances the beer nicely.  A pretty quaffable Marzen.
Bronze color,Thin to medium head,semi sweet taste,dry finish, bitter aftertaste.
Got a case for Christmas... what a good Christmas...........................
Great overall taste with a slight sour (the good kind) aftertaste. It has a medium strength alcohol taste that is actually quite smooth. It is a great Deutsch Oktoberfest!
Malty and not that bitter.  Very refreshing.................................
Fairly OK stuff. Pretty good caramel malt flavor, pleasant hops. Drinkable, but, nothing to go out of your way for.
I wasn''t impressed with the bottle form, but very impressed when served from a tap. It''s a decent, no-nonsense yeasty oktoberfest brew. Try to avoid the bottle variety.

deep golden/light bronze color. head is white and frothy. aroma is decidedly malty! with bready and some yeasty notes as well. flavor is light and malty and not too extravigant....very disappointed in this one due to its relatively high rating

Strange aftertaste, but not a bad tasting beer. Aroma of Heineken (yes thats bad), or other skunky things. Otherwise not a bad beer. I have had it a few times, but it seems to get worse each time I try it.
not one of the best i''ve had. i agree that it has a strange aftertaste. on the plus side i did not find it a gassy as others which is a bonus in my opinion

Bottle:  Clear orange with a medium white head, light grains and some flowery hops, light bodied with ample carbonation, starts and ends lightly sweet, crisp ending with some sweetness, a good beer for a hot day.
Tastes like a watered down version of Optimator.  Not too bad, but not too good either.  There's really nothing else to say.
Nice bready notes. Slightly reddish, very clear color. Nicely balanced bitterness.
cloudy amber with creamy tan head. Faint skunky nose. Nutty malty palate with roasted aftertaste

Decent brew, however pales compared to
Hacker.  Seems to be quite lacking in the malt
category, which is what distinguishes the Hacker 
brew as good to drink.  Will pass on another six.

A frost tipped golden mountain permeating with wholewheat pancakes and drops of sticky maple syrup...zest of orange w/ autumn spice and gleaming red berries floating in thin flutes of champagne..as dry as autumn air and the leaves begin to fall..

Elegant! Noble hops balance the malty sweetness. Nutty, bread-like aroma is in counterpoint with mild hops aroma. Lace on the glass, though the head does not linger. Wonderful mouthfeel and finish. The best Wies'nbier I've ever tasted!
Nice barley taste, but that's about all it has going for it.  A somewhat one-dimensional beer.
Nice head.  Malty, sweet aroma.  Taste sweet and malty with hints of caramel.  Overall I enjoyed this beer.

The aroma was suprisingly full of honey, which disappeared with the head, as well as tea, bread, and almonds.  Malt flavors are mild and grainy.  I prefer hops in the background in a fest beer, but this one had a touch of bitterness in the finish that i don't like.  Above average.  Note:  mine was in a green bottle, and i'm suspicious about how fresh it was, so I'll have to revisit this one.  
ReRate:  I found this to be much better this time around, undoubtedly a fresher sample.  Awesome bready aroma, pumpernickel and whole wheat.  Very dominant whole grain profile throughout.  Super smooth texture, and highly quaffable.
Malty with a slight sweetness.  A good German Bier.  Re-Rate: Very smooth and well-balanced.  Good light brown/copper hue.  One of the best German Oktoberfest beers there is.
Nice solid Oktoberfest.  Good color and nice aroma.  .......................

From a bottle, I poured a large, fluffy, creamy head--but it dissipated so very quickly.  It has a nice balance in the flavors, with some maltiness and tinges of hops, plus enough sweetness.  But the palate flattened too quickly and left the beer lifeless--creamy, but lifeless, like a poor English bitter.

The color of tea. Almost no head and what little there was dissipated immediately. I haven't tasted anything quite like this beer, and I don't know if that's bad, or a sign of my inexperience. Has a sort of manure off-taste, not that I've tasted that. Metallic aftertaste (from a bottle).
I drank this beer in a German beer tent at a festival near my house in Jersey. For about 5 hours. I loved it! Good malt and hop combo and put me 3 sheets to the wind. Two Mugs up for this beer.

Attended Oktoberfest at Old World in Huntington Beach last Friday.  A couple pitchers of this stuff, a big ol'' slab of Wienerschnitzel, and some fine polka music can really put you in the mood.  Sweet, bready aroma.  Sweet, roasted, caramel, malty flavor with a hint of coffee and spicyness.

The aroma is a nice promise of things to come, with sweet malt notes and perhaps a hint of caramel.  The appearance is nice, though not as pretty as some Oktoberfests, with a typically white head and deep orange body.  The flavor is excellent, exemplifying the style.  There are sweet malt notes with just enough hops to keep it from going over the edge into sugary.  The palate is average.  Overall, this is probably the best Oktoberfest I''ve had.  Other brewers take note:  the brewer did not attempt to make this beer about how much hoppiness the drinker can stand.

9/30/07: Re-rate. Draught at Charlie’s Ale House, Wheaton, IL. Despite some adjustment within categories, I give this brew the same overall score as I did 5 years ago. Malty, German aroma. Copper body with an off-white head. Excellent lace. Malty flavor, dry. A good o’fest. no hint of hops. Moderately sweet. Flavorful. It appears Charlie’s takes care of their tap lines as the character of this brew shines through as it was meant to. 10/26/02: Sweet caramel aroma. Thick, fine bubble head with reddish hue. Good lacing. A little thin on flavor, but makes for a smooth, easy drinking brew. No bite whatsoever. Good aftertaste. Drinkability makes for a good session beer. Although not low in alcohol, I could see drinking many large mugs of the stuff at Oktoberfest in Munich. Ar 8, Ap 5, Fl 6, Pal 5, Ov 14

Gold and amber colored. Big head split quickly, but left some clingy lace work. Slight malt smell and flavors, but no discernable spice. Subtle hop finish. I don''t know what I was expecting, but this one just lacked ''something''.
clear yellow/golden colour. Malty, sweet aroma. a bit sweet fruity, malty, a little hoppy taste. Smooth, perhaps a little bitter palate.
Best out of all Oktoberfest beers. Clean refreshing and finishes well.......
I really enjoyed this brew, super smooth. I give it: B+.....................

Malty - bread like aroma. Small, quickly dimishing, fizzy, off-white head. Light, orange - almost copper colored appearance. Moderate, sweet flavor with a litle bit of fruity hoppiness to it. Good, full body.
Not my favorite style but this is one of the better ones, smooth and sweet.
I think this is my favorite Oktoberfest. Appropriately sweet and a little grassy. Smoooth mouthfeel.
Yum.  Exquisitely smooth.  Very good oktoberfest, but I prefer the Paulaner.
Mild malt aroma, Malty fruity sweet flavor. Faint aftertaste of grape Kool-aid.
Good Octoberfest.  It did not disapoint.  I was given another one from JB on 10/16/06.  Still very good.
Amber gold color witha thick creamy head and good amount of lace.  slightly sour malt aroma with hoppy undertones.  strong malt flavor with a sweet malty finish
Amber? barely dark gold.  Slightly skunky aroma.  Thinnish sweet malt flavor (corn-y?).  Not thick enough in mouthfeel for an octoberfest. This is a pretty poor example of an octoberfest.

Good malty aroma and creamy head that sticks to the glass.  The flavor was too creamy; I'd like to try this in Germany ... wonder if the import version varies.  Good, overall, but not the best of the O-fests.
Malty, soapy aroma. Sweetish, malty, bit herbal taste with lots of fruit (prune). A bit sticky, but clean and a nice fruity finish.

Draught @ Headkeeper:  This one pours a clear amber color.  There was a very small off white head that left no lacing.  The nose is good.  Malty and biscuity, with some earthy hops.  The taste is also good.  Malts, earthy hops, biscuit.  Very smooth.

Copper color, medium head. A light bodied marzen-style beer. Nice malts and slightly sweet. Mild hops. Good full flavor. Nice balance. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
A good Octoberfest beer. Nice German Beer aroma, clean taste and finish.....

I can see why people like this one so much - an Okto rating above a 3.5 is an accomplishment!  The hoppage (is that a word?) is just right - a perfect balance.  And the body is mild and drinkable, yet rich in a tapestry of flavors.  H-Pschorr is still better, though.

Rating is for draft...
Nice beer.  Dark amber color with a thick, creamy head.  Easy to drink.  Very little aftertaste and very clean.
Kind of a tinny smell to the beginning, I took my time drinking this one, it seemed okay and I would recommend it to my friends,
Dark amber.  nice thick caramel malt flavors - not too syrupy thick, just right.  nice sweet short finish.
Ah, one of the nicest parts of fall.  Oktoberfest.  A good beer, a little too sweet, however.
Deep amber color with a fruity, almost peachy nose.   Caramel in the body with a bitterness that sticks its head out slightly.   Finish is somewhat sweet.   Good stuff.
This was an OK brew.  Pretty easy to drink.  Pours kind of brassy amber in color.  Creamy, quick fading head.  Very smooth, a bit hoppy but  really more of a full bodied mild beer.

I seem to remember that Spaten was my least favorite of the Munich Maerzens ten years ago.  Not so today--perhaps evidence of Paulaner's/Hacker-Pschorr's deterioration.  Wonderful classic  Maerzen flavors combined in a great balance.  The key here is the roasted malt flavors, which give the sweet malt the needed relief.  Just great, and a bargain at $5.50/six.
Blond with a bit a brown. Malty and yeasty. Only a slight bitterness to it. Seemed to finish a little dry. Very good stuff.

Light amber hue with fine head and spotted lace. Aroma is malty-sweet and slightly yeasty---quite nice...Flavor features a nice balance of sweet and roasted malts with well-judged hops and moderate carbonation for bite. A slight tang accompanies the balanced finish. Body is right for this style--moderate--and the combination of fine balance and a substantial flavor profile make this one of the leaders of the pack.

Truly the most beautiful thing to come from Spaten.  If I could paint my house this color believe me, I would.  Thick billowing head packed with silky smooth malt.  4.1
update: 10/2/2009
Bready, floral aroma with a very floral and light flavor.  One of the drier oktoberfest’s I’ve had but it is still on the top of my list.
A good sweet malty smell, but the sweet is too overpowering in the taste. Has a real nice blend of hopps and malt, that still makes it a good beer.
Unbeleivably sweet, malty taste and aroma. Nice color and body. Excellent marzen.
This was quite enjoyable.  Nice malts, nuts, caramel.  Smooth and creamy.  Sme nice hoppiness to the finish.

re-rate Had this last night on draft. A light amber, nice head and lace. Nose was full of fresh  malt, caramel, hallertau's, nuts and others. Medium bodied, almost soft with malt galore, smooth as hell, spicy hops and unbelievable drinkability.

Aroma of caramel, grape, perfume, almond extract, and Pils malts.  Extremely delicate mouthfeel; soft carbonation.  Intertwined flavors of fig and plum with predominant Pils malt flavors.  Undertones of grassy, minimally spicy hops, unfortunately, capped with a long minerally/doughy malt blend. Above average, but far from special.

Light brown colour, nice big off white head.  Malty aroma, perhaps a little banana.  Small lace around the top of my glass.  This one began with a bit too much malt for me, but the hops came out in the end.  My first Oktoberfest, so I will try more this fall to make a better comparision.
not very enjoyable, looks crappy and smells crappy and has kinda a buttery taste, but I have trouble giving any oktoberfest a truly bad rating

Just a bit of a malty pepper nose floats above an amber lake of grain. This is a bit ordinary and safe. I'm sometimes conflicted between judging something that is easy to drink, but somehow wishing there was a bit more. It's easy going down, not too challenging. It presents a very nice hop and malt blend, but the flavor perhaps leaves too quickly.
